PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome back Senator Evans, visiting Australia, and ask him in his capacity as the Minister representing the Prime Minister, to the background of the industrial turmoil experienced by the Australian community of recent times under Labor's law and practice and the national coalminers strike which is continuing today: why hasn't the Prime Minister condemned this industrial thuggery of union bosses which is hurting the interests of all Australians well beyond the parties to the dispute? Does the Prime Minister have no influence with Labor's Accord partners, the ACTU leadership, or does he just prefer to abdicate his responsibility in favour of his predecessor, Mr Hawke? Doesn't real national leadership demand more than a few phone calls on the way to the airport?

—The Prime Minister's concern throughout in this matter has been to try to get this dispute resolved and also to address its underlying causes, not to grandstand and make political capital out of something that is potentially very damaging to the Australian economy if it is not contained. That is exactly the way in which his involvement in the matter has been proceeding.

PARA.TAB: His involvement, as I understand it, began last Tuesday when he talked to the unions concerned about the basic position they had taken and his concerns about the way in which they were seeking to escalate what was an obviously legitimate ground of industrial difference into a matter of much larger national significance. As a result of that, he later talked to the chief executive officer of CRA, on Wednesday of last week, and that led to conversations for the first time for some considerable time between the ACTU secretary and Mr Davis, all of which was important in creating the circumstances for what subsequently happened.

As a result of those discussions, negotiations were entered into between Tim Pallas, the assistant secretary of the ACTU, and the CEO of Comalco, Mr Terry Palmer. Together they drew up a basis for settlement for further negotiations between CRA, including Comalco, and the ACTU. Included in that basis for settlement, which was reached on Wednesday night following the involvement of the Prime Minister, were agreements on essential principles: agreement by the company to drop litigation against individuals on strike in Weipa; agreement by the company on the principle of not discriminating against workers who choose to bargain collectively; agreement by the company to the principle of equal pay for work of equal value; and from the CEO of Comalco, in the context of assuring the Prime Minister that `We will sort out the details tomorrow'—which was the way he put it—agreement to report to the commission by 2 o'clock the following day. Faxing this agreement to the Prime Minister on Wednesday night, the ACTU assistant secretary said that the ACTU was confident this constituted an agreement.

That is where it was on Wednesday night following the intervention of the Prime Minister. For the Prime Minister to express on that basis the optimism that he did last week is perfectly understandable. The point is that the Prime Minister kick-started a process which has now followed through into negotiation between CRA and the ACTU and, more importantly than anything else, it has resulted in the matter now being dealt where it belongs—that is, in the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

The chief executive officer of CRA said on Thursday that he `welcomed the intervention of the Prime Minister in seeking a solution to the unnecessary widening of industrial action related to Comalco's operations'. CRA added—this is on Thursday—that it was willing to respond immediately to the PM's suggestion that it should enter into discussions with the ACTU; it was willing immediately to start proceedings in the AIRC to address the disparities which had arisen between award conditions at Weipa and those applying to people on staff contracts.

As a result of all this occurring, the matter did find its way into the Industrial Relations Commission through the intervention and involvement of the president on Friday night. There was a compulsory conference on Saturday. It was foreshadowed that, if that compulsory conference failed to fully resolve the issues, it would be dealt with by way of arbitration commencing today, and that is the basis on which the matter has proceeded.

Mr Hawke's involvement has been limited to being involved as an advocate for the ACTU on the particular question of equal pay for equal work—the substantive issue which is now before the commission and being addressed right now. In fact, I think Mr Hawke, in his address to the commission, started in 1891; he is probably up to about 1920 by now, and I am sure it will be a very helpful contribution. But to talk in terms of Mr Hawke or anyone else other than the Prime Minister being involved in actually bringing this matter to a resolution is to completely misunderstand and to wilfully misunderstand the course of events.

The ACTU said that it would make its best endeavours on Saturday to stop the coalminers going out, but it was not confident about that. It did say that it would stop the maritime strike going ahead, and it did succeed in doing just that. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, all you really succeeded in doing is demonstrating the failure of the Prime Minister, but what we want to know is: why won't he condemn the leadership of the coalminers unions who are continuing this national strike whilst the matter is before the commission? Why does he simply attach blame to CRA, the company which at all times acted within the law? Doesn't the Prime Minister understand that national leadership in fact requires acting in the interests of all Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —What the Prime Minister wants to do, and is succeeding in doing, is get this matter brought to a sensible and quiet resolution in the commission, where it needs to be. After his discussions with the trade union movement, he has already succeeded, with the help of the trade union movement, in getting the maritime strike off, and it is to be hoped that that will be the outcome so far as the rest of it is concerned.

PARA.TAB: So far as CRA's role in all of this is concerned, maybe it has acted, technically, within the terms of the act. That has not been denied. But it has certainly acted against the spirit of it. Even that voice of capitalist Australia, the Australian Financial Review, made that absolutely clear this morning, that there was ground to be concerned about the way in which the system was evolving, when it said:

ANSWER.PARA: In this situation, many employees appear to have decided that membership of the union no longer makes sense.

PARA.TAB: This may turn out to be a mistake since it is always possible that the company, once its workforce is largely deunionised, will become rather more parsimonious.

ANSWER.PARA: That is the matter in issue. That is what the Australian trade union movement is concerned about, and that is the issue of principle—the protection of Australian workers—that the Prime Minister is concerned about. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Bob Collins, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The minister would be aware of claims over the weekend by the federal opposition that the Prime Minister's statements regarding the APEC free trade agreement were `absurdly boastful'. Can the minister advise the Senate of what new opportunities Australian farmers stand to gain from the inclusion of agriculture under the APEC trade and investment liberalisation?

—I am aware of those very silly statements made at the weekend by Mr Downer—the person that the coalition wishes to inflict on Australia as its foreign minister—regarding the Prime Minister's role in those APEC negotiations.

PARA.TAB: Senator Panizza interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, Senator Panizza, Mr Downer clearly indicated that he is one of those people who, if he won tattslotto, would whinge about the price of the ticket. It is a fact that all of these put Australia first advocates in the coalition were praying for two results over the weekend: one, the escalation and deterioration of the industrial dispute at Weipa; and, two, the failure of APEC. Fortunately for Australia, and unfortunately for the coalition, neither of those things eventuated.

PARA.TAB: The inclusion of agriculture in the APEC trade and investment liberalisation agreement does have the potential to provide a substantial boost in confidence for Australia's farmers.Farmers, of course, well understand the positive implications of what was achieved at APEC, even if Mr Downer does not. The President of the National Farmers Federation, Mr McGauchie, has congratulated the government for keeping regional leaders up to their commitments.

The National Farmers Federation has estimated that our farmers stand to generate another $2.9 billion a year from more liberalised trade as a result of this agreement. This is in addition to the $1 billion a year of additional trade that is expected to flow from the successful outcome of the Uruguay Round. The NFF says this will be a major boost to all rural communities and will provide all states and regions across Australia with much needed additional export income. Mr McGauchie says that we must turn the Osaka agreement into tangible trade reform and ensure that all sectors, including agriculture, and all measures, including tariffs, non-tariff barriers and export subsidies, are gradually phased out.

The substantive statements that have been made by a number of our major trading partners following the Osaka agreement are very heartening indeed in terms of their commitments to make substantial tariff reductions early in the new year following the agreement.This government, which led the push to resist rural protectionism at APEC, wholeheartedly agrees.

The agreement by leaders in Osaka over the weekend is another milestone in the development of APEC. The action agenda provides for comprehensive coverage without exceptions. The commitment to the 2010-2020 end dates has been reaffirmed, with flexibility within this process to determine the pace of liberalisation for sensitive sectors. The agenda covers all tariff and non-tariff barriers as well as export subsidies and trade facilitation measures. Countries will now prepare individual action plans for submission in 1996. This is without doubt a major outcome for Australia and, in particular, its primary producers.

The broad suite of agriculture reforms introduced by this government since the early 1980s are resulting in the development of more efficient and market oriented rural industries. These reforms have been achieved in close consultation with all the major stakeholders—in particular, the National Farmers Federation—to ensure that this country's rural industries are well placed to take advantage of this trade liberalisation in the APEC region.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. (Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —What CRA has obviously been about is trying to squeeze unions out of the play, doing so in a way which was not contemplated in the terms of the legislation, by forcing people to accept individual contracts less than the awards; rather, it has done it by the more subtle and circuitous route of offering returns that are well above what they can achieve in terms of the current awards. But the net result of that process will be, if it is followed through to fruition—and CRA has undoubtedly hoped this would be the case—to create a situation where union members, one by one, drop off from their union membership and the union ceases to be, for all practical purposes, an effective voice in the enterprise bargaining for that particular company.

PARA.TAB: The matter in issue was very clearly spelt out, as I say again, by the Australian Financial Review. If anyone is the voice of the business interests in this country, if anyone would be thought to understand business psychology and if anyone might be thought to adequately or accurately represent CRA's motivations in its editorials, it could be expected to be the Australian Financial Review. What the Australian Financial Review says—I say again that it may turn out to be a mistake for union members to decide that their union membership no longer makes any sense in the face of these generous contracts—is:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . since it is always possible that the company, once its workforce is largely deunionised, will become rather more parsimonious.

Amen to that. Of course it is possible. We were not born yesterday, any of us. The habits of hundreds of years, of millennia, do not change in the way in which business enterprises are conducted. Interests remain at odds with each other. You do need protections built into the system to ensure that workers who individually have no power, as against collective corporate enterprises, will in fact have some capacity to apply that particular power.

PARA.TAB: It is in that particular context that the government has been concerned about the way in which the legislation has operated. It is in this particular context that the government is concerned to see a sensible outcome achieved on this matter before the industrial commission. It is for that reason that we are very pleased to see this matter now being litigated before the commission of what equal pay for equal work—that well-established principle—means in this new context. This is the industrial relations context in which this particular issue is being now fought out and it is a perfectly understandable concern that the ACTU, the union movement, should have and it is perfectly understandable that the government should have taken the position that it has taken in this.

We understand the nature of the principles that are involved here. We want to see these issues resolved in a way that does not create unfairness, particularly in the longer term, for the ordinary working people. We want to see an environment created, at the same time, where this does not become an explosive industrial conflict which will work against the national interest.

It is for all these reasons that we have approached the issue, and the Prime Minister has approached the issue, in the way that we have. He has not been concerned to act stridently or in any posturing fashion. He has been concerned to work away behind the scenes to identify the true matters at stake, to dissuade the parties from taking unnecessary industrial action and at the same time to persuade the company concerned about the necessity of it playing a little bit more in accordance with the spirit of the rules, not just the strict black letter. Because it is only by playing in accordance with the spirit of the rules, as everyone has been doing to the great advantage of this country for the last decade, that we can continue to get the kind of productivity gains out of the work force and we can continue to get industrial harmony and stability maintained in the way that has done so much for the good of this country. That is the basis on which we have been approaching this matter this week. To approach it in the way that you would do if you were in office, with all the attitudes that you have to these issues and your absolute contempt for the underlying interests of the work force, would be to do no more than, as everyone knows, throw a lighted match into a petrol can. That is not the way to conduct industrial relations; it never has been and it never will. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Family Services. Minister, on Friday you launched the book Families and cultural diversity in Australia at the national conference of the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia. Can you detail some of the themes which highlight the diversity that exists in Australian society?

—I thank Senator Reynolds for this question. Families and cultural diversity in Australia is a splendid book produced by the Australian Institute of Family Studies and published by Allen and Unwin. It is just another one on the list of publications, quite excellent publications, coming out of the International Year of the Family.

PARA.TAB: This book is an account of cultural change within Australia and within Australian families. While it documents fascinating differences in cultural and family values, it draws on similarities and consistencies—for example, the strong attachment to family, the importance of children, the expectations of strong family support and respect for age. It highlights very beautifully and very powerfully the fact that, although we are in a period of rapid change, the importance and consistency of the family are at the core of not only Australian society but in particular our multicultural Australian society.

It is also very appropriate that this book, started in the International Year of the Family, should be launched in the International Year for Tolerance. What it highlights too is the amazing comment from Senator Minchin, who very recently called for a cut in migration. Senator Minchin said that he would like to see a reduction in the extraordinarily large—25 per cent—increase in this year's intake. An opposition that goes around saying that it believes in the family and at the same time calls for a 25 per cent cut in migration gives a very clear message that it does not understand either ethnic communities, migration or—

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia.

—Those opposite certainly do not understand Australia. For example, the opposition certainly do not know of the policy whereby it is planned that over 60 per cent of the migrants in 1995-96 will come in under the family reunion program. A cut to immigration would mean a cut to family reunions and the extension of those families.

PARA.TAB: Here is an opposition that claims that it supports the family and at the same time is campaigning to cut family reunions. In the face of the evidence of a book like this that talks about the importance of the family for multicultural Australia, this is a quite extraordinary, contradictory approach by the opposition.

I am very pleased that the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia saw the opportunity to launch this book and to see the importance they put on families and cultural diversity in Australia. When reading this book we see a number of examples of different cultures in Australia. One of the other points that is raised and highlighted very extensively is the importance of child care—

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you read it?

—Yes, Senator Woods—to Australian families and the importance of quality child care. For many of the migrant families with two parents working child care has been critical in getting established in this country.

PARA.TAB: They want child care, and quality child care, but another policy from the opposition is to bag quality child care. You have no sensitivity about the importance of family reunion. You do not care about the quality of child care, which is so critical to assisting these families in getting established. If you really want to know more about Australian families, you should read this book. It is a very splendid account of why Australia's government policies are right in this area. Families of all sorts and diversity in Australia are welcomed and supported by this government. Our policies are a clear indication of that, and they are completely opposite to yours.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Ray, representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. Do you agree that it is essential for the ACTU and striking Comalco workers at Weipa to honour any agreement brought down by the President of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, because, if the striking workers were prepared to ignore the previous AIRC determination to return to work, what assurance is there that they will adhere to any other request from the commission? —I address my question to Senator Ray, representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. Does the minister agree that it is not in the national interests that the CRA contracts dispute be escalated? Does the minister agree that the principles of natural justice demand that all Australians, workers included, have the right to be represented by others, in a court or in any negotiation? Does the minister agree that the AIRC arbitration hearing is the correct forum for the resolution of the present dispute? Will the minister admit that the politicisation of the dispute is contrary to the public interest? PARA.TAB: Of the issues they raise that are most concerning small business, the biggest issue is unemployment. In that same survey the No. 1 issue is unemployment. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Does the government believe there is scope for banks to further reduce home loan interest rates? Has the presence in the market of mortgage originators like Aussie Home Loans and lenders like the superannuation members home loans scheme brought more competition into the home lending market and put pressure on banks? In view of this more competitive market, should borrowers for home loans shop around in the market?

—Of course it is true that those seeking mortgages to cover their home loans should shop around in this market. It is a more contestable market. If consumers use consumer power to cause greater competition, they will reap the rewards of that greater competition. They are already doing so by virtue of how the market is now developing.

PARA.TAB: Yes, the existence in the market of mortgage originators such as Aussie Home Loans and lenders like the superannuation members home loans scheme are bringing that much needed competition to this market. For our part, the government will continue to point out that this is a competitive market. With consumers using their power and us using our influence, I am sure that the level of mortgage rates can be further reduced.

Falling long-term mortgage rates and the unprecedented competition in the home loan market are indeed, as I have said, pushing down mortgage interest rates now. Since December 1994 the variable home loan rate charged by banks has been constant at 10.5 per cent, but the average interest rate being charged on the stock of loans outstanding has fallen from 10.01 per cent in December 1994 to 9.67 per cent in September 1995. The fall in the average interest rate reflects the increasing pressure on major banks from mortgage originators like Aussie Home Loans and lenders like the superannuation members home loans scheme.

Mortgage originators are now accounting for a growing share of new loans and their variable rate mortgages are around 1 1/4 percentage points below that of the major banks. Indeed, one company on its own, Aussie Home Loans, accounted for $2 billion of the $11 billion growth in home loans by all lenders between December 1994 and September 1995.

Mr President, for their part, the major banks are responding by trying to compete in the new loan market through such things as honeymoon loans. While projecting their margins on the large existing stock of mortgages by maintaining standard variable rates of 10.5 per cent, so-called honeymoon loans now account for over 20 per cent of the housing stock and are freely available at rates around 2.5 percentage points below the variable rate. The rate on honeymoon loans has come down from 8.4 per cent in May of this year to 7.9 per cent in September. I might just note that the Advance Bank has just announced a honeymoon rate of 7.75 per cent.

Fixed rate loans account for around a quarter of all outstanding mortgages. The rate on a three-year fixed mortgage fell from 10.3 per cent in December last year to 9.6 per cent in September. At present, home buyers can get a three-year fixed rate mortgage at 9.25 per cent. In those circumstances, it is clear that this market is a more competitive market. There are gains for mortgagees seeking new mortgages to make the institutions compete between themselves and that is bringing the major banks under pressure. I certainly hope that that will mean that they too will enter more full-bloodedly into this competitive market.

The winners in all of this are Australian home owners and those who borrow money to finance the purchase of their homes. Creating a contestable market such as this is fundamental to government policy to ensure that home buyers get the best possible deal from the lending institutions in the field.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question also is addressed to Senator Cook, the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. Minister, I ask you to clarify your strong support of Carmen Lawrence in the Senate last week. Why do you not believe the testimony of seven of your Western Australian ALP colleagues who clearly recollect the Easton matter being discussed in the Western Australian cabinet meeting?
—Order! Minister, I do not know what this has to do with the Senate, I do not know what this has to do with your portfolio, but it is up to you whether you want to answer it.

—I do not know what it has to do with my portfolio either, Mr President. I am asked to clarify a position I expressed in the Senate. This is an inappropriate forum in which to do so—I note that—but since it has been put to me, and I am not one for ducking questions, I will answer it.

PARA.TAB: I said last week that I know Carmen Lawrence, that I have known Carmen Lawrence for many, many years. My experience of Carmen Lawrence is in many tight situations over that time. I believe Carmen Lawrence to be a truthful person. That is what I said and, notwithstanding the findings of this royal commission, I believe that to be the case.

I also said in my remarks that one of the problems I have with the royal commission's findings is that they make a declaratory assertion about the honesty of some witnesses and remain silent about the honesty of other witnesses. In those circumstances, a reasonable conclusion is to say that there is here a contest of memories, not of accuracy, if people perceive a similar set of circumstances differently. That is the truth of this sorry tale.

I am shocked and dismayed at the feeding frenzy that has emerged since and the pressure that that has put on Carmen Lawrence, because frankly I think it is unfair. I was asked for my view; that is my view. Nothing in the royal commission shakes that view.

I conclude by saying that I know some of the other witnesses that the royal commission did not comment on at any length in its findings—two of whom I mentioned last week. One of them is Joe Berinson, a former minister in this parliament, and the other is Ross Love, a person whom I know personally. I believe their evidence was not given sufficient force or weight in the finding. But it is hard to say what force or weight the particular evidence of individuals was given since the royal commissioner made a declaratory assertion about whom he believed, without saying in any analytical way why that was the case. In those circumstances, I cannot regard his findings as anything that would shake my faith in my deep-seated conviction that Carmen Lawrence is a truthful person.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook, do you believe seven of your Western Australian parliamentary ministerial colleagues lied?

—I do not go to their evidence because, as I said in my answer to the original question just a minute ago, it appears to me from all I know about this case and from what I have followed in this case that what we have from similar circumstances is differing recollections. That does not go to the honesty or veracity of individuals.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order on the issue of relevance. The question was quite specific, minister: why don't you believe seven of your Western Australian colleagues rather than Dr Lawrence? That was the question. Could you answer that question?
—Order! There is no point of order.

—In contradistinction to that interjection and misuse of standing orders, I was answering the question. In answer to that question, I do not judge what the others have said. Your additional question is the one I am prepared to stand in this chamber and answer with all the conviction and honesty I can bring to it. With all of my knowledge of Carmen Lawrence, I can say—hand on heart, if you wish, being aware of the oath of office I have made to this place—that I believe her to be a truthful person.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Has the minister seen recent media reports suggesting that the United States pre-Olympic drug testing program is ineffective? In particular, is the minister aware of widespread criticism of a recent United States Swimming decision in the case of a positive steroid test? Can the minister advise of the current situation in the United States of America regarding drug testing? Further, can the minister advise the Senate as to actions the federal government is taking to strengthen US resolve in the fight against drugs in sport?

—I have seen the media reports that Senator Collins refers to. United States Swimming has confirmed that a 15-year-old swimmer tested positive for the anabolic steroid Mesterolone at the 1995 US national championships following the 1,500-metre freestyle event. US Swimming conducted a national board of review which voted 2 to 1 to sanction the swimmer with two years probation, despite the fact that Mesterolone is not manufactured or distributed in the United States and therefore can only be obtained illegally.

PARA.TAB: I am concerned about this decision and the message that it sends around the world regarding the US position on drugs in sport. In particular, this US Swimming decision may cast international doubt on US credibility in taking a strong stand generally on the drugs in sport issue. I understand that there is an appeal process in place and that it may be that all the facts regarding this case may not be yet known.

In general, the United States Olympic Committee is responsible for the implementation of the competition testing program for Olympic sports in the United States of America. A number of sports work with the USOC to conduct out-of-competition testing, which is the most effective means of deterring athletes from doping. Unfortunately, sports are not bound to work with the USOC. At present, only eight out of 41 sports participate in the USOC out-of-competition testing program.

I am also concerned about this situation and am fully aware that Australian athletes have reservations about the lack of effective testing in the US. In an annual survey conducted last year by the Australian Sports Drug Agency, 25 per cent of Australian athletes who responded to the survey believed the US was a country in which drugs in sport was a problem.

It is most regrettable that the number one ranked sports country in the world has not yet been able to introduce an effective out-of-competition drug testing program for its Olympic sports, especially as that country is to host the Olympic Games next year. ASDA will continue to seek information on the USOC testing program and will monitor any changes.

Although the USOC's recent decision not to introduce a new and effective out-of-competition testing program is disappointing, this does not mean that US Olympic athletes will avoid appropriate testing programs. A number of international federations, such as FINA and the IAAF, have introduced world wide out-of-competition testing programs where internationally ranked athletes are given no advance warning of their selection for an out-of-competition test. In the US, these tests are being conducted by an international independent testing body and not by the USOC.

I think the situation in the USA is not ideal. I can assure Senator Jacinta Collins and the Senate that I will be continuing to work actively in international forums to ensure that Australian athletes can compete in a drug-free sporting environment. Some of those steps included the historic MOU that I have signed with the International Olympic Committee and with SOCOG in pursuit of a drug-free Sydney 2000. That agreement is just another measure to ensure that Sydney will host a drug-free Olympic Games. I can assure you that we will be continuing to ensure that Australia maintains its strong international commitment on this issue. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Justice, Senator Bolkus: why has the government rejected the application for Commonwealth legal aid by the Tasmanian gay activists Nick Toonen and Rodney Croome to fund a challenge to the Tasmanian anti-gay laws, relying upon the Commonwealth Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Act? Is it not true that the two activists met all the criteria for funding? How do you reconcile this with your own comments during the debate on this bill that, while you could give no assurances, the guidelines for funding public interest cases appeared relevant to this case?

—In terms of reconciling my own statements, those statements are on the record. I gave an assurance at the time that I would raise the matter with the Attorney-General, which I did. In terms of the final outcome of the funding application, I have no idea as to whether a decision was made and for what reason. I will find out for you and pass on that information as well.

—Minister, doesn't this expose the rhetoric that you have referred to as simply that? Given that the government's Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Act can only be effective through a High Court challenge, can the minister outline what support the government will offer to Tasmanian gays and lesbians in their efforts to overturn the abhorrent sodomy laws of Tasmania?

—No, I gave you an assurance as to what I would do, and I did it. I am advised—just flicking through the question time brief here—that Mr Toonen and Mr Croome have issued a press release making some sorts of claims. I am advised that a letter had been sent from the Legal Aid and Family Services Branch of the AG's department explaining in detail why legal aid had been refused.

PARA.TAB: I am further advised that the application was assessed in accordance with the means and merit test applied to all applications for assistance and was unsuccessful. In terms of any particular reason as to why, that is a decision for the funding authority, which I am not.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I refer the minister to the question asked by Senator Margetts last week about the grenade explosion at the Australian Defence Industries plant at St Marys in answer to which you promised a rigorous investigation. Will you ensure the Senate that that investigation will address allegations that workers have been working a succession of 12-hour shifts in order to fulfil the order on time, and that the normal protective shields were not in place? As sole owner of ADI, does the government accept any responsibility with respect to safety standards at ADI; and, if so, what?

—Whether we own ADI or not, we would expect them to have the highest safety standards, especially as they are dealing in the munitions area. I indicated to Senator Margetts last week that both Comcare and the state authorities were having an inquiry into these matters, and also that ADI were having an internal investigation for their own purposes. Certainly, I would expect those matters which you have raised—all safety matters—to be investigated after the occurrence of such a regrettable incident.

PARA.TAB: I will make inquiries to ensure that those sorts of matters that you have raised are going to be raised. But I have a full expectation that they are going to be covered. Any other inquiry that left those sorts of areas out would be an inadequate inquiry from my point of view.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Has the government conducted any studies—and I stress `any studies'—whatsoever to ascertain whether the expected $3 billion each year increased farm based exports arising from the APEC trade agreement are ecologically sustainable? Has the government given any consideration to increased greenhouse gas emissions arising as a result of increased trade in bulk goods or has the government totally ignored environmental considerations in its negotiations over trade?

—It is a little premature to be doing a cost-benefit analysis of the environmental implications of this when you are talking about benefits that are going to be realised over a considerable period of time and which are still only in the early stage of their calculation, quite apart from implementation. But the point is, as the Prime Minister was saying yesterday and throughout, indeed, the negotiations leading up to the final passage of the Osaka action agenda, there is going to be an absolutely phenomenal increase in the demand for agricultural produce in this region as a result of the economic growth within the region, the improving standards of living flowing from that growth, and all the other consequences that we can already begin to measure. I am having difficulty finding the relevant bit of my brief in this respect, but the implications of this in quantitative terms—
—Weren't you there?

—This was part of the value that the Prime Minister added to the exercise. My role was just engaged in clearing the dust away from the arena so that he and his fellow leaders could add the real value to the occasion. I make absolutely no bones about the minor character of my contribution as compared with the important injection of horsepower in which the Prime Minister and his fellow colleagues were involved.

PARA.TAB: That is, of course, the point about these APEC meetings: the real momentum for change has to come from within the domestic economies themselves. The best way of ensuring that that momentum occurs is for there to be top down driving of the process in each country, with the mutual support and reinforcement that flows from leaders having the sense that they are engaged in a common cause. That is what Mr Keating has added to the APEC process since he initiated this new series of leaders meetings in Seattle in 1993. That really will be where the real value, I think, is perceived in the longer term.

The short point I am making though, in answer to Senator Coulter's question, is that there is going to be a phenomenal increase in demand for agricultural products from around the region. Somebody has to supply that demand, if it is to be met. We are very confident of our capacity to do so, and we want to be very much a part of that action. What will happen as a result of the reduction of trade barriers is that the some of the constraints to the more economically sensible sources of supply will be removed. That is the basis on which the Australian farmers are so confident about these outcomes.

To talk about the greenhouse contribution that will flow from the bulk carriage of grains halfway around the world I think is to make a fairly trivial point by comparison with the nature of the benefits that can be expected to flow from that particular process. But, to the extent that there are environmental consequences of this or any other trade policy outcomes, we will of course take them into account over the long haul that decision making becomes necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I take it from Senator Collins's earlier answer that the benefits of $2.9 billion have already been calculated. The present minister's reply has indicated that no environmental considerations have been given. Is the government totally ignoring the advice of the world's leading scientists on greenhouse, which indicates that increasing trade in bulk goods is inconsistent with an effective attack on rising CO(2) levels caused by the burning of fossil fuel? Has the government any concern that the climate change that these same scientists now say has already begun may lead to much lower agricultural production in Australia and may mean, like the last few years of drought, that average production in Australia may not even be achieved?

—Doing almost anything other than sitting in small rural retreats, counting your beads, wearing kaftans and chanting `Om' is likely to be inconsistent with some increase in CO(2) emissions from the community in question. That's just life. What you have to do is try to reduce the incidence of such emissions and have sensible policy solutions which recognise the realities about the world in which we live and try to do something to address them in the least cost way so far as impact on the environment is concerned. That is exactly what we will be doing.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the fact that the government is proposing to spend an additional $1.4 billion this financial year over and above the $123.7 billion sought in the 1995 budget. I also refer to the shortfall in the proceeds of the sale of Qantas, to the debacle surrounding the sale or non-sale of ANL and to the uncertainty surrounding the proposed next sale of the Commonwealth Bank. I ask: is it not a fact that the budget's stated objective of a budget surplus this year of about $700 million is now likely to turn out to be a deficit which could be as high as $1 billion or more? What actions does the government propose to take following this further run-down by it of Australia's national savings to counter the inevitable additional blow-out of Australia's huge balance of payments deficit and the upward pressure on interest rates that will result?

—This question can be characterised as a fishing expedition, and entirely speculative in nature and selective in choice of references. It is a fishing expedition because Senator Short does not know what he is talking about. Nor could he or anyone else because the mid-term review has not been completed and published, so the status of the budget at this stage is not known. Senator Short just does not know. Nonetheless, he is parading his lack of knowledge as fact in this chamber, which is, I think, fairly typical of Senator Short.

PARA.TAB: In terms of being selective in choice of references, what Senator Short has done is made a number of references which do affect the budget bottom line in one way or another, but what he has chosen to do is to omit one of the major reasons that might affect the budget bottom line—that is, his complicity, along with the Australian Democrats, in knocking back some budget bills which would reduce the level of surplus. His complicity, as a Liberal Party member, in voting in this chamber with the Australian Democrats to knock back taxing bills to reduce the level of the surplus, is selectively omitted from this question in what is typically a way—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on a point of order: the minister has said that that part of the question was omitted. By his own admission, he has said that it is irrelevant. He is now going into why the government wants to put the sales tax on building products back into the tax system. Senator Short's question goes to why the budget is in deficit now and not surplus, not about their plans to put a new tax on building products.
—The earlier part of Senator Cook's answer was irrelevant because he was attacking the questioner, but I think he is starting to get relevant and I ask you to keep on that track, Senator Cook.

—Thank you. The reason why I raise this point is not because of the false interjection under a point of order taken just a moment ago by Senator Campbell. The reason why I am making this point is to say that those opposite have conspired to reduce the level of surplus by voting positively to do so and now, by perambulating some sort of sentimental concern about the budget, they do not escape the criticism of their earlier actions in reducing the level of the surplus.

PARA.TAB: The reason why this government brought down a budget which was in surplus this year was to put downward pressure on interest rates in Australia. Every person who borrows money for home loans wants to see downward pressure on interest rates. One of the ways of doing that is to lift public savings. Lifting public savings means having a budget which is in surplus. That is what we brought down in May of this year.

This is a fishing expedition, as I have said, because the answer to the question is not known until the mid-term review is brought down. The mid-term review would normally be presented to the first sitting of the parliament in the ensuing year. That would be the first sitting of the parliament in 1996. But yesterday the Treasurer announced that he will bring forward the mid-term review, among a number of other changes that he will make, to clear the decks for an election to be held properly next year without affecting the economic management of this country.

The mid-term review will be, as I understand what the Treasurer said, brought down before Christmas. All I can suggest is that, rather than engaging in wild and inflammatory speculation, as Senator Short is now doing, he actually sit in his place, sit up straight, look forward, both hands on desk, and wait for the actual facts to be delivered.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. After that quite amazing answer, I ask again: does the minister deny that the proposed surplus is now virtually certain to be a significant deficit for this financial year? Does the minister agree that, because the government is totally incapable of controlling its insatiable expenditure, it will be forced to raise existing taxes or introduce new taxes to balance its books? Which new taxes will be introduced by the government after the next election? Will they include a wealth tax and will they include the capital gains tax on the family home, as had earlier been proposed? Will they also, of course, include the restoration of taxes that the Senate has already responsibly rejected, such as the iniquitous proposed tax on building products?

—There are three elements to this. Let me deal with them quickly. Firstly, on element 1, I will wait until the mid-term review, but I do acknowledge that the opposition has reduced the level of the surplus, and that is your responsibility, not ours. Secondly, it is not the government's intention to introduce new taxes. You can speculate about that as much as you like. That is inflammatory; that is electioneering. You are just playing politics. The public should disregard your remarks as being politically tainted.

PARA.TAB: The third part to this question is `let us look at the opposition's election policy'. In fact, you cannot because it is not there. There is nothing to see other than a row of promises which hand out money and mean that so far you have given $11 billion in handouts to favourite sectors of the economy while, at the same time, promising to get your budget into deficit and while, at the same time, promising to slash expenditure. It is an incredible formulation and it is a witch's brew that no-one will buy. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Alston this day, relating to an industrial dispute in Weipa, Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the tragedy of it is that when we have a peripatetic foreign minister who only occasionally visits Australia, he really loses touch with what is going on out there, particularly the issues that are of concern to ordinary Australians and, indeed, ordinary workers. It must be a long time since he had to deal with the trade union movement, particularly with Mr Kelty. If he did, he would understand what has been happening in recent days. It is perfectly clear that what is going on is a power struggle. The trade union movement is not interested in the welfare of the workers; it is interested in the welfare of the trade union bosses.

PARA.TAB: Quite clearly their interest is to maintain as many people on the drip feed as possible and to negotiate on their behalf—in other words, you treat them like cretins, you take their membership subscriptions and you make sure you decide what is in their best interests rather than consider what is happening on the ground at Weipa. If this wandering minstrel did take a good look at what was happening in Weipa, he would know that overwhelmingly the workers there are very satisfied with the staff salary arrangements which have been negotiated and that there is only a very small number who are holding out—presumably the dyed-in-the-wool unionists who are not particularly interested in negotiating higher levels of productivity and do not know what is in their best interests. Ninety per cent of them on the ground do. They are the ones who have been getting up to a $20,000 wage differential as a result.

There is no question about equal pay for equal work of equal value. These people are getting more money because they are contributing more and are adding more to the value of the company. They are the ones who deserve to be paid on that basis. It is know as performance pay in common parlance. The tragedy of the situation is that you have lost sight of what workers are really interested in.

We have the spectacle of the trade union movement desperately trying to stop workers from getting more than the award. They want to drag everyone else down to the award level. They do not want to get out there and persuade the workers why they should actually be more constructive, why they should not work in close cooperation and why these staff arrangements that have been so successful over the last five years in a variety of workplaces around the country should not exist.

This is a quiet revolution that has been going on and yet clearly Bill Kelty has been asleep on his own watch. He has only just woken up to the fact that the trade union movement is seeing the ground move from beneath it and that the interests of the workers are not synonymous with the interests of the trade union movement. Indeed, the workers know that the old them and us dichotomy is not in anyone's best interests.

If you go to Hamersley or the New Zealand site you will find time again the workers, some of whom still belong to trade unions I might add, saying that they have never had it better and they would never think of going back to the old regime. They are not interested in the mindless industrial conflict and confrontation that is now being promoted by Mr Kelty as a desperate last resort to cover the fact that the union movement is very unhappy with his intervention on behalf of Lindsay Fox and others in recent times.

Mr Kelty has lost sight of the main game. He is no longer interested in the welfare of the workers. That is why I thought it was quite extraordinary that Senator Evans had the gall to quote the Financial Review editorial. Presumably his minders thought that no-one else in the chamber reads the Financial Review or, if they do, they would not have the ability to quote from the editorial.

I will go to the very heart of what it was that Senator Evans thought assisted his case. He said that CRA was not acting in the spirit of the legislation because, as the editorial says, it may turn out to be a mistake that many employees appear to have decided that membership of the union no longer makes sense. Then it went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . this won't be the case, paying annual union dues would still seem to make sense, if only as a type of insurance policy.

PARA.TAB: The fact, however, is that this should be up to each individual worker to decide. Provided they aren't forced to leave the union, the decision about whether or not to do so should be theirs, not the union movement's.

SPEECH.PARA: That is precisely what is happening. Senator Murphy ought to know that even at Weipa—

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't know. You don't know anything about it.

—I know because I have looked into the issue. There are many workers at Weipa who still belong to the trade union movement and say that it is a form of insurance, but the fact is that they know the benefits derived from signing on to a staff agreement. They are interested in that because they are much more prepared to have a constructive approach. They do not want the old business of the unions telling them what is in their best interests and the unions simply negotiating a lowest common denominator and holding the old line in favour of hard fought gains. (Time expired)

—I listened to what Senator Alston said. He said that we have to stop this dichotomy of them and us. That is correct. He said that there ought to be more cooperation between the work force and the employers. One would have hoped that that is what everybody wants. When you look at the language used by Senator Alston, you wonder whether the party that he represents is really interested in that.

PARA.TAB: He talks about the power struggle—that all the unions are interested in is the welfare of the union bosses. They do not want to take away the food drip that comes to their bosses. They take the membership subscription, and that is all they are interested in. As you go through Senator Alston's speech, you will see that he is dumping on the union movement. We are not going to get this dispute or any other dispute settled if the leadership of the Liberal Party are going to go to the public and consistently dump on and ridicule the union movement.

Of course the union movement can be criticised for things that it does wrong, but there should not be, as has happened here, a blanket condemnation of what it does. To say of one section of this community that because they belong to a particular group they are wrong, that they are people who have nothing but hatred in their hearts—which belies the very thing that they allege they stand for—is not going to get us anywhere. The real trouble with this present struggle is that it has brought from the opposition an expression of opinion about union matters and industrial relations which is going to be very dangerous for both employer and employee if it is allowed to come into operation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a few words to say on this matter. Senator Ray totally ignored the question I asked him this afternoon. He agreed that the striking CRA workers of Comalco at Weipa should adhere to what the industrial relations commissioner tells them to do, bearing in mind that to date they have failed to carry out what the industrial commissioner had to say. The minister chose to ignore that question, so I presume that his heart is not in it. He does not really believe that the union will adhere to what the Industrial Relations Commission may say.

PARA.TAB: Senator Ray also ignored the question I asked him about whether Mr Keating is going to take some solid leadership in this case. Mind you, Senator Ray said last week it was better for politicians to keep out of industrial disputes. Within 24 hours of Mr Keating saying in Osaka that the government was taking over the dispute, the next thing we know is that Mr Hawke has got the dispute, so we do not quite know where we stand.

I think it was Senator Gareth Evans who said last week, when he was decrying the contract system up at Weipa or anywhere else, that once you are in a contract, there is no going back. I think he is the one who said it—there is so much coming and going of ministers here, excuse me if I have got the wrong fellow. It was either Senator Evans, Senator Cook or Senator Ray. With this round robin of ministers in here, you do not quite know.

The point is that it is a total lie. Everyone should know by now that you only need to be on a contract at Weipa for a month. If you do not like the contract after that time, you are quite entitled to go back to collective bargaining. In fact, there have been one or two who have done that in the past few months.

The cry in this strike is equal pay for equal work. No-one decries that. But with a contract system, there is another ingredient to the formula that no-one over there has mentioned: equal responsibility. It is a question of equal pay for equal work and equal responsibility.

Government senators can look quizzical, but they have to work out what those responsibilities are. When you look at equal pay for equal work, you have to work out whether the hours are the same. In the contract, they are not. They are knocking off when they have finished the job. If a job is not finished by a certain time and the company wants it finished, under the contract system you finish it. Then there is the question of whether there is strike or no strike—whether there is a contract or no contract, with those responsibilities. Also, the contracts are enforceable at law, both on the company and on the employee. As you see, the responsibilities of those under contract are far greater than under the collective system. Mind you, as I have already said, if you are on a contract, after only 30 days you can go back to collective bargaining, but there are not too many who go back.

Why do companies have contracts like this? It is not to squash the unions. The unions have lost the faith of workers right around Australia. I doubt whether anybody on the government side has ever been in business and have had to employ people from their own pocket instead of from the government pocket. Anyone who has been in business will understand that a company wants to know that if they sign a contract with an overseas company they are going to be able to deliver, and not wonder whether or not their work force is working. With a contract system, they know whether they are going to be available to work and fill that contract. That is the basis of this argument and this government has failed badly on all points.

TALK.START.PARA: —With regard to the way in which opposition senators have been conducting their questioning on this matter, their responses in terms of taking note of answers or any other contributions they may make, it has enlightened us—ultimately, it will enlighten the people of Australia—as to exactly what the opposition's policy is on industrial relations. Most working Australians would be starting to think to themselves, `We're not too sure that that is exactly what we want.' In fact, most of them will be saying, `It is exactly what we don't want.'

PARA.TAB: The opposition had a very poor policy during the last federal election. I would have to say it was rejected resoundingly by the Australian electorate, particularly by working Australians. Even non-working Australians—even those hoping to get a job, those on unemployment—would say that that was not the type of industrial relations system they wanted, should they get a job.

With regard to the attack that you continually launch against the trade union movement, you say that this is all about choice, and the contract workers have made a choice. That really denies the fact that over many, many years it has been union members and their funds that have won all the basic entitlements that all working Australians enjoy today. You can run the counter argument and say that every pay increase that union members achieve when they go to the arbitration commission and to courts should only go to workers who are members of unions. I am sure you would argue vehemently that that was discrimination. You would say that unions are seeking to line the pockets of their members. But that is not so in this case—you say it is okay for some workers who do exactly the same work, on the basis that they have agreed to a certain set of company conditions, to get paid significantly more than their colleagues who have chosen to want to bargain collectively for wage increases and other conditions. You say that is fine; that is their problem.

I put it to you that that is a fairly unAustralian way of dealing with things. It is an unfair way of dealing with things. I think it is about time that we really looked at this issue in the context in which it should be looked at. From my own experience when I was secretary of the timber workers union, I have seen the documentation that North Broken Hill Peko presented to workers, saying they would get significant pay increases if they became non-union members, if they would sign individual contracts. Of course, Senator Panizza says, `Well, okay, after one month, if you don't like it, you can go back to collective bargaining'.

If we look at the Weipa work force, there is a significant number—I cannot think of the percentage at the moment—who are new workers. I put it to you that they are being told, `Here is the contract. If you want a job with this company, that is what you will be employed under. If you don't want the job under that contract, there is somebody else waiting for the job who will take the contract and we will employ those people who will take the contract, not those who wish to either become union members or who are union members and want to bargain collectively.' As I said, I think this whole debate is enlightening us. It is illuminating the opposition's position.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't have to leave the union on those contracts, and you know it.

—I know full well where you will come from on industrial relations, senator. Sometimes I often felt when I was secretary of the timberworkers union that, given the union members' money and our efforts through the particular union to win pay rises and conditions for workers in that particular industry, any gains should go only to the workers who had paid for all of the costs to run all of the arguments. You have to accept that that would be un-Australian and unfair to other workers. Working Australians understand that there is a clear right to be treated fairly. I know that they will reject the opposition when it comes around to industrial relations.

—Senator Alston talked about mindless confrontation. In my years as a trade union official I experienced lots of confrontation. It was not always on one side; it was on both sides. None of it was mindless. It may have been bloody-minded, unflinching and maybe sad in many cases, but not mindless.

PARA.TAB: Let us focus on the history of Weipa for a moment. One can imagine companies seeking a different form of industrial relations and a different relationship with their employees if they are at all times involved in industrial disputation matters that are difficult for them to handle in terms of management. If you look at Weipa, over many years industrial awards were negotiated and upgraded without any confrontation and without any dispute at all. It was really a backwater and a very quiet place for industrial relations.

But, of course, the confrontation occurred because the company decided, as it had in other places, that it wanted to move towards the elimination of trade unions at the workplace. It therefore offered the idea of individual contracts. It confronted the unions; the confrontation did not occur the other way. Certainly, the unions never set out to eliminate the company.

If you look at that and compare it with other companies throughout this country where negotiated agreements on a collective basis have been carried through, you will find that they have been found to be very satisfactory. Indeed, in the negotiations of those agreements many suggestions have been made from the union side as to how to better manage and how to get a better bottom line result for the company and for themselves. They realise that one must work to create wealth before wages and salaries can be paid and before money can be set aside for more modern machinery and to expand the company. They realise that.

It is a question of working together fairly cooperatively to create the biggest cake possible. There is always the question of how much of the cake each person gets. Regardless of the situation of how cooperative people may be—let us make no mistake that the company has said publicly that it is competing for leadership of the work force against the trade unions—there is always a question of a conflict of interest when it comes to the bottom line. Once the profit is made, there is always the consideration by the company as to how much it believes it should keep for the process that I described before of development of the company, new equipment and new management processes. There is the question of how much the workers get by way of a wage package. That conflict is there and it will always be there. In many cases there may not be a great conflict. There may be a small gap between the two parties.

Every company that has ever been set up—either a small one or a large one—looks at the bottom line and seeks to get the highest possible profit within reason and in conformity with maintaining the company in a prosperous state for some years to come for the benefit either for a single owner or for the shareholders. In turn, the employees want to get a decent wage to provide for their families.

There is nothing evil on either side, but the conflict is always there. Any fool who suggests that it is all right and moral to have no unions and that workers at the work face should not have an organisation to represent them had better go back to the drawing board and read a little bit of history to try to get some experience or talk to people who have had experience. If they did they would realise that that conflict will always be there and that there needs to be a representative of labour and a representative of capital.

Senator Panizza talked about going back to the old system of collective bargaining. I have talked to people who have been up there recently and they have told me that people are either ashamed of having signed the contracts individually or afraid they will be removed from the site if they are seen talking to militant trade union leaders. There is no doubt that they are afraid and that that pressure is coming from the company.

For many years when I negotiated awards I felt maybe it would be reasonable for only members of unions who were parties to those awards to get any increase in pay or paid according to the award. But companies, without any exception, said that any award payment that went to trade unionists had to go to non-unionists. Now we have CRA turning that right on its head and saying it is all right to give increases to non-unionists but the unions cannot have them. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Coulter this day, relating to the environmental impact of trade agreements.

SPEECH.PARA: One is very disturbed to find that, increasingly, this government is taking the country down a number of blind alleys. One of those blind alleys is assuming that the future lies with increased trade, particularly increased trade in bulk exports from Australia. Specifically in the area of agricultural production, the assumption that lies behind the recently signed APEC agreement is that, firstly, we can produce the food—the $2.9 billion of additional food that Senator Collins talked about today—without further environmental deterioration.

PARA.TAB: I think everybody in this chamber would know that we have in this country increasing salinisation, increasing loss of topsoil, pollution of our water supplies, exhaustion of our water supplies, loss of nutrient, loss of soil structure and loss of species. In every respect, agricultural production in this country is not yet on a sustainable basis, yet the government assumes, evidently, that we can meet demand for increased food production. Quite clearly they have recognised that.

By the year 2020, Asia will be in need of a great deal more food consequent upon its population increase. So the question arises: can we produce the food? Will we be able to produce the food? Certainly by the year 2020 we will already have serious climate change. That has come out of the recent deliberations of the 200-odd scientists who are advising the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change in relation to the greenhouse issue.

By then we will have climate change, although the government chooses to ignore this. We may well be in severe drought. For that reason, we may not be able to produce the food. But all this is being ignored by the government by going into these negotiations with its eye on simply the narrow economics of trade and not looking at what respected scientists from around the world are saying about the environmental consequences.

Secondly, having produced the food that Asia will undoubtedly need, we need to be able to transport that food to those countries. When one looks at transport as it is currently organised, as it is fossil fuel powered, one comes to the conclusion that the transport in a greenhouse world will not be available. We have to change very drastically the technology we use in that transport or we will not be able to transport that food without serious and further greenhouse consequences.

Be assured that well before the year 2010 or the year 2020 governments, unlike the governments of today, will be addressing the greenhouse problem because there will already be serious consequences evident. The world will be taking a different perspective. Yet we go down this blind alley of assuming the future will be like the past only writ larger. We will produce more; we will have more environmental impacts. Somehow we can sustain that. We will use more fossil fuel, but somehow we will address the greenhouse problem.

There is no evidence at present that the government is taking these problems seriously. The government should be starting its economic analysis, by not looking purely at economics but looking at the real world that scientists are describing in which there is serious, continuing and accelerating environmental deterioration. This is the beginning of a sane and sensible analysis of trade policy. This the government, together with other governments, is simply not doing.

There are enormous opportunities for Australia if only we were to recognise that the future will be different from the past. There are opportunities in alternative energy areas, some of which I have outlined in previous speeches. There are opportunities in terms of sharing that technology not in a competitive way but rather in a cooperative way. These are the things that we should be doing.

I find it very depressing today to hear Senator Gareth Evans make light of the very serious question which I asked. He suggested that we should all go away and say `om' to ourselves. That was not a serious answer to a very serious question. It is depressing that on such a serious matter the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) chose to answer in that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will recall that we asked the same kinds of questions about the Uruguay Round of GATT. We wanted to know what kind of work the government had been doing into the social and environmental impacts of a massive change to trade policy.

PARA.TAB: On that occasion the government's response was very much similar to today's. There was an assumption that there were so many benefits absolutely assured, from our jumping with two feet, and I believe quite naively, into the way we negotiated the Uruguay Round of GATT, that there was absolutely no reason to put any of this in jeopardy by checking.

The irony is that they did not check on the Uruguay Round of GATT. What is more, they did not even check on the economic benefits, so much so that more than a year down the track since it was negotiated and signed we are over a billion dollars a month on average down the tube even in terms of our trade. The economic benefits that were so confidently predicted were $5 billion once we got past five years; $5 billion benefits.

We have not even got that far and we are already $10 million down the tube at least. It seems to me we are doing everybody a disservice unless we look at the actual impacts. The very least the Australian government could be doing is actually arguing in Australia's best interest, instead of arguing naively that, if Australia leads the charge in free trade, bulk trade and commodity trade at all costs, then we will benefit.
As far as I can see, it has not been looked at in these environmental terms: how much wool can you produce? How much iron ore can you produce?
