DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Environment, Recreation and the Arts Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts on waste disposal. I seek leave to incorporate the response in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The response read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Government Response to the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts' Report on Waste Disposal
HOSPITAL WASTES

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 1

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that the Government investigate the need for legislation relating to the transport of hospital wastes across borders and implement an appropriate strategy to reduce the risks associated with the transport and treatment of hospital wastes (Paragraph 3.105).

In light of the existing or planned initiatives for reducing the risks associated with the transport of hospital wastes, additional legislation is unlikely to be required. Four separate but related national initiatives exist to reduce the risks associated with the transport, storage and treatment of hospital wastes:

PARA.TAB: `National Guidelines for the Management of Clinical and Related Wastes', which provide the overarching framework for the management of hospital wastes;
`Australian Code for the Transport' of Dangerous Goods by Road and Rail', which provides a national approach to the transport of hospital wastes;
`National Guidelines for the Management of Wastes: National Manifest and Classification System', which provides a tracking system for hospital wastes; and

SPEECH.PARA: A national standard is being developed which is expected to cover the storage and handling of some hospital wastes classified as Class 6.2 Dangerous Goods (Infectious Substances).

The National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) is revising the `National Guidelines for the Management of Clinical and Related Wastes'. This revision is taking account of new technologies for waste treatment, rising community concerns about the risks associated with the transport and disposal of hospital wastes, and recent Government initiatives with respect to waste issues.

The purpose of the Guidelines, which were published in 1988 by the NHMRC, is to recommend procedures for the safe packaging, labelling, storage, transport and disposal of such wastes. They are intended to assist authorities and practitioners in determining the appropriate waste management strategy. The Guidelines provide a basis for the development of any current and future strategy for the management of clinical and related wastes in Australia, particularly for hospitals and other similar health care organisations.

The National Guidelines have been well received. Most hospitals have made use of the Guidelines in developing their own waste policy and procedures. The Guidelines recommend coding standards for the three most hazardous categories of clinical wastes (i.e. infectious, cytotoxic and radioactive wastes). These standards are now well adopted throughout Australia.

In relation to the transport of hospital wastes, the Guidelines also recommended that in adhering to local transport regulations, reference should also be made to the `Australian Code for the Transport of Dangerous Goods by Road and Rail'.

Before additional legislation could be considered, however, States and Territories should be consulted to ascertain whether they have experienced problems in enforcing the relevant requirements of the Australian Code which is generally endorsed by all States and Territories. They should also be consulted in order to determine whether they are satisfied with the Code in regard to the transport of hospital wastes. If any State finds that the Australian Code does not adequately address the issue of hospital wastes, mechanisms exist for the State to initiate revision of the Code.

The third initiative affecting the transport of hospital wastes across State and Territory borders is the `National Guidelines for the Management of Wastes: National Manifest and Classification System'. These Guidelines have been prepared by the Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council (ANZECC) and provide a system for tracking certain, usually hazardous, wastes across State borders. Amongst the wastes subject to this system are clinical and pharmaceutical wastes which are made up of the following categories: infectious substances, pathogenic substances, pharmaceuticals and residues, cytotoxic substances, and wastes from the production and preparation of pharmaceutical products.

The system requires that the local authority in the receiving State or Territory is notified of a proposed movement of waste, and that the waste is manifested with a waste transport certificate throughout its movement.
The system is already operative in Victoria and South Australia and is being introduced in Queensland and New South Wales. The Guidelines are also going through the process of ANZECC endorsement.

In addition, the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission (NOHSC) is developing a national standard for the storage and handling of dangerous goods. Currently some hospital waste is classified as Class 6.2 Dangerous Goods (Infectious Substances). It is anticipated that the storage and handling of these goods will be covered by the finalised standard.

It will, however, be important to ensure that these initiatives are complementary, avoid duplication and are implemented in a co-ordinated manner. This could be assisted by increased consultation with the relevant authorities responsible for the management of hospital wastes.
MUNICIPAL INCINERATION

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 2

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that approvals for the construction of incinerators should include recycling and waste to energy facilities (Paragraph 3.107).

The Commonwealth considers that incineration with waste-to-energy facilities is a potentially feasible option for waste management but it would need to be justified on environmental, social and economic grounds. While incineration of domestic waste is currently not widely used in Australia, the construction and operation of any incineration facility should be within strict environmental and health guidelines and include a waste-to-energy capacity. Responsibility for the determination of these guidelines is presently shared between Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments, and the establishment of the National Environment Protection Council (NEPC) will promote a national approach to the setting of environment protection measures in relevant areas of waste management.

Responsibility for the granting of approvals for the construction of incinerators typically lies with the State and Territory Governments rather than the Commonwealth Government. As such it would be most appropriate for State and Territory Governments to determine what conditions are attached to any approvals for particular incinerators.
HIGH TEMPERATURE INCINERATION

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 3

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that technologies designed to reuse or recycle be given priority, and environmentally friendlier alternative technologies for the destruction of scheduled waste be considered in preference to high temperature incineration (Paragraph 5.37).
This recommendation is consistent with the position taken by ANZECC and is supported.

On 10 July 1992 ANZECC considered the draft report of the Independent Panel on Intractable Waste, which had been established to investigate the extent and production of scheduled waste and alternative disposal technologies, and decided to abandon the proposal to establish a centralised high temperature waste disposal facility.

This decision reflected a conceptual shift away from one of managing all of Australia's scheduled waste as a single waste. stream and disposing of it through the establishment of a centralised disposal facility, to one of acknowledging the separate components of the scheduled waste stream and placing reliance on a range of emerging technologies for treating the different parts of the scheduled waste stream.

The development of management plans for the treatment of scheduled wastes has been initiated. The process will include a consideration of all issues, including technical, health, environmental, economic and social aspects.
SCHEDULED WASTE

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 4

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that enterprises be required to disclose the quantities of scheduled wastes they have stored and that these be stored in National Environment Protection Council approved premises, and that an agreement for their disposal or a research proposal for their reuse or recycling be made with National Environment Protection Council by the year 2001 (Paragraph 5.138).

Under mirror legislation, the NEPC has two functions: to make national environment protection measures (NEPMS) and to report on their implementation and effectiveness across Australia. The Council, which will be established in 1995, will be empowered to make NEPMs that relate to, amongst other issues, environmental impacts associated with hazardous wastes and the reuse and recycling of used materials.

The Council does not have control over implementation of measures as this is left to each jurisdiction. Both the Intergovernmental Agreement on the Environment (IGAE) and the NEPC legislation make it clear that the implementation and enforcement of national measures are the responsibility of each jurisdiction.

In 1993 ANZECC agreed to develop a national strategy to manage Australia's scheduled wastes. The aims of this strategy are to establish conditions for the safe management and disposal of scheduled wastes and to determine agreed dates by which the production and use of scheduled wastes are to cease.

ANZECC has instituted a process of developing management plans for each class of scheduled waste. Over the next three years, management plans will be endorsed by ANZECC as they are produced. In developing these management plans, environmental performance criteria will be established. Facilities will have to meet these performance criteria in order to be licensed to treat such wastes. Each management plan will specify (inter alia) notifiable quantities of waste, the requirements for storage of waste, and a deadline for disposal of waste stockpiles.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 5

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that enterprises be required to have scheduled waste disposed of according to the terms of an agreement with NEPC by an environmentally acceptable process at a rate which is commercially feasible (Paragraph 5.139).

NEPC has the power to pass national environment protection measures on environmental impacts associated with hazardous wastes and the reuse and recycling of used materials. In developing national environment protection measures, NEPC is required to take into account economic and commercial feasibility factors.

NEPC however, does not have the power to enter into agreements on the disposal methods of scheduled wastes. ANZECC is addressing such issues in its development of management plans (see response to Recommendation 4).

A transfer of responsibility for co-ordination of the scheduled waste issue from ANZECC to NEPC does not appear to have any advantages and may itself delay appropriate action. Even if a transfer of responsibility did occur, under the NEPC scheme implementation is left to individual jurisdictions. Hence it would be for individual governments to implement and enforce agreements on disposal of scheduled wastes.
CEMENT KILNS

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 6

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that the Government investigate the potential and feasibility of using cement kilns for the disposal of particular waste streams (Paragraph 6.37).

The opportunities for disposing of particular waste streams should be examined on a case-by-case basis and would be best undertaken by State and Territory Governments, which are responsible for regulating both waste management activities and cement production facilities in their jurisdictions.

Cement kilns is several States currently use a variety of materials as energy sources (e.g. used tyres). While it is recognised that such practices as energy reclamation are a preferable option to landfill disposal, recognition needs to be given to the potential hazards that could be created. Compliance with State and Territory environment protection relations is required. The future use of these and other materials will be dependent on, among other things, the economics of the practice and community concerns about using cement kilns for waste disposal purposes.

A review of the availability of technologies for the treatment of scheduled wastes is being conducted by the Environment Protection Agency (EPA) within the Commonwealth Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories. The Cement Industry Federation Limited has advised that the current cement kiln operators are not interested in burning scheduled waste materials in cement kilns in the foreseeable future, primarily because of the potential for adverse public reaction.

On this basis, while from a technical viewpoint cement kilns may have the potential to destroy scheduled wastes, it appears unlikely for non-technical reasons that this will occur on a commercial scale in the foreseeable future.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 7

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that the Government investigate the avenues available to regulate the use of materials for recycling in preference to their use as a supplementary fuel (Paragraph 6.39).

The approach adopted by the Government in the `National Waste Minimisation and Recycling Strategy' is a co-operative rather than a regulatory approach. On the basis of environmental, technological, social and economic considerations, recycling of materials may be preferable in some circumstances to the use of those materials as a supplementary fuel, although in other circumstances the reverse may also be true. Any decision to support waste-to-energy should be made on the basis of a case by case assessment. To a large extent, it will be market demand and technological advancements that will dictate the fate of recyclable materials.

As the responsibility for waste management and recycling generally lies with State, Territory and local Governments, it would be more appropriate for these governments to investigate policy options for ensuring materials are recycled rather than used as-supplementary fuels.
INDEPENDENT PANELS

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 8

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that independent panels be established to facilitate the settlement of ongoing disputes with regard to waste management issues (Paragraph 7.43).

Independent panels have had some success in addressing community conflict in relation to complex waste issues. This is likely to continue to be an approach adopted by the Government where appropriate.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 9

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that the members of these panels be determined by the National Environment Protection Council and not have members from the State or Territory in which the dispute occurs (Paragraph 7.44).

This recommendation is outside the mandate of the NEPC but is an appropriate issue for consideration by ANZECC. It should be noted that the co-operative framework within which the Government operates on waste issues necessitates involvement by all relevant States and Territories. A dispute resolution panel should not exclude the responsible or proponent State or Territory. Issues requiring resolution would in practice be addressed on a case-by-case basis.
IMPORT OF SCHEDULED WASTES

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 10

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that a permanent ban on the import and export of scheduled wastes be implemented except in cases where technologies are developed which recycle them into useful products which are not hazardous (Paragraph 9.35).
Australia is committed to meeting its obligations under the Basel Convention, including that it will take appropriate measures to:

PARA.TAB: `Ensure that the transboundary movement of hazardous wastes and other wastes is reduced to the minimum consistent with the environmentally sound and efficient management of such wastes, and is considered in a manner which will protect human health and the environment against the adverse effects which may result from such movement' (Article 4.1.d)).

SPEECH.PARA: The Government considers that Australia's stockpiles of scheduled wastes should be treated within its own borders. Accordingly exports of these materials will only be approved under exceptional circumstances, such as where the wastes proposed for export would otherwise pose a significant risk of injury to human health or the environment, and where the importing country possesses facilities where the waste can be treated without damage to human health or the environment.
Approval of imports of scheduled wastes would be limited to:

PARA.TAB: importation of waste in very small quantities for scientific purposes; or

importation where Australia has developed technology to treat a particular waste and where treatment is not available in the originating country and the treatment of these wastes within Australia would have an overall positive impact on the environment.

SPEECH.PARA: Although there is a limited number of technologies currently available to treat scheduled wastes in Australia, there is a range of emerging technologies likely to be available within a few years.
RECYCLING

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 11

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that where technology is available governments work with industry to encourage the use of recycled materials instead of raw materials (Paragraph 11.50).
Several initiatives have been undertaken by the Commonwealth Government to encourage industry to use recycled materials in preference to raw materials, including:

PARA.TAB: ANZECC has established a working group to address standards and regulations that present barriers to the use of recycled products:
with funding from the EPA, an Eco Re Design project is being conducted which, among other things, is assisting industry in investigating design opportunities for using recycled materials; and

through the Cleaner Production program, which includes an industry workshop series, the EPA has encouraged industry to recycle and reuse materials as part of the implementation of cleaner production methods.

SPEECH.PARA: CONSULTATIVE PROCESSES

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 12

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that as a matter of urgency, Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency be required to establish formal and informal consultative processes with local, State and Territory governments, industry and the broader community on all the major principles of waste management, particularly those relating to the National Waste Minimisation and Recycling Strategy (Paragraph 11.62).

The EPA actively consults on waste issues with States and Territories through ANZECC, and with Australia's external territories. Government consultative processes are developed in accordance with the particular issue being addressed. There are many examples where these consultative processes include the establishment of advisory groups which draw their membership from a wide cross-section of the community.
WASTE REDUCTION TARGETS

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 13

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that the Government give priority to the measurement, review and monitoring of performance against the waste reduction targets contained in the National Waste Minimisation and Recycling Strategy, and that the Minister provide details of the actions taken when responding to this report in Parliament (Paragraph 11.65).

The report `Monitoring of Performance Against Waste Minimisation and Recycling Targets' was commissioned by the EPA and released in November 1994 as part of its commitment to monitor progress against national waste minimisation and recycling targets. In future, the National Waste Database, currently being developed, will provide information to waste managers and the community on waste generation and progress towards achieving a 50 per cent reduction in the amount of waste going to landfill by the year 2000.
MONITORING PROGRAM

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 14

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that as a matter of urgency, the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency monitor the effectiveness of all measures adopted so as to ensure that the desired outcome is achieved, and provide ongoing reports to this Committee (Paragraph 11.67).

Following the completion of the report `Monitoring of Performance Against Waste Minimisation and Recycling Targets', the EPA is considering priority areas for action. In a number of instances it appears that progress towards some recycling targets has been slow and discussions are under way within ANZECC to identify ways to address these shortcomings. The EPA will provide the Committee with copies of relevant reports as they become available. In order to monitor performance, obtain information and develop waste minimisation polices, the EPA consults widely with Commonwealth, State and Territory Government departments, local government, industry and non-government organisations (e.g. environment groups).
REVIEW OF TECHNOLOGIES FOR DISPOSAL OF SCHEDULED WASTES

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 15

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that emphasis be given to the prompt dissemination to local, State and Territory governments, industry and the broader community of the information collected in the review of available technology for the treatment of scheduled waste (Paragraph 11.69).

The EPA has under way a consultancy to `Review the Availability of Technologies for the Treatment of Scheduled Wastes'. Four reports will be provided over an 18 month period under this consultancy which will provide an independent source of information on the current status of the development and availability within Australia of technologies for treating scheduled wastes.
The Review will also provide a good overview to holders of scheduled wastes of the technologies which are available within Austraha and the types of waste which can be treated by them.

The EPA will make this information publicly available to relevant government, industry and community groups. Under the Intergovernmental Agreement on the Environment, this information should be provided to the Norfolk Island Government and the Indian Ocean Territories. The EPA will make the report available to members of the public upon request. The information will also be included on the National Environment Industries Database being developed by the EPA. The Database will incorporate information on Australia's environment management capabilities, for use by industry, the community and governments at all levels.

The Commonwealth also facilitates access by Local Government to information on environmental issues, and related education and training, through the National Local Government Environment Resource Program (NLGERP). As part of the NLGERP, an Environmental Information and Support for Local Government (EIS) service has been established to assist councils to find and use information on the many issues associated with integrated environmental management. NLGERP is funded by the Department of Housing and Regional Development under the Local Government Development Program.
LOCAL GOVERNMENT

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 16

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that the Government:
recognise the central role of local governments in waste management;
include representatives of Australian local government associations in national waste management planning;
assist local government to disseminate information about the costs and benefits of waste management planning;
encourage local governments to, exchange information about developments in waste management (Paragraph 11.70).

The Commonwealth supports the active involvement by local government in national waste management activities and often seeks local government representation on advisory and planning committees relating to a range of waste issues. The Commonwealth Government also supports the dissemination and exchange of information on waste issues and regards this as being essential to the improvement of waste management practices in Australia. A variety of initiatives have already been implemented which will increase local governments' access to information on waste issues, for example:

PARA.TAB: a waste minimisation category has been included within the Local Government Development Program administered by the Department of Housing and Regional Development with funding from the EPA. The category was established to support demonstration activities with the results to be made available to other local governments;

the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories has established a computer-based electronic network (`Council Net') which enables local governments to exchange information on a broad range of issues including waste management;

with funding from the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories, Environment Resource Officers have been employed by local government associations in all of the states to facilitate an exchange of information between Commonwealth and local governments and also from one local government to another. Waste management is one of the issues which the officers are concerned with. As a result of increased funding in 1995-96, an additional part time Environment Resource Officer will be employed in each State to deal specifically with waste issues.

the Environment Information and Support for Local Govemment (EIS) service has been established to assist councils to find and use information on the many issues associated with integrated environmental management (see response to Recommendation 15).

SPEECH.PARA: NATIONAL STANDARDS

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 17

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that NEPC be requested to give the determination of national standards priority on its agenda (Paragraph 11.73).

NEPC has a wider mandate than just setting standards. NEPC has the power to develop national environment protection measures, which may include standards, guidelines, goals or protocols. NEPC's role also extends to reporting on the effectiveness of the implementation of measures.
This recommendation to give priority to the setting of national standards will be referred to NEPC in the context of its deliberations on its work program.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion to take note of the government response and I would like to make a few remarks about it. The government's response to this report has been awaited by some members of the community with great anticipation, and I am pleased to say that the response is, in general terms, positive.

PARA.TAB: I would rather not spend too much time considering the first recommendation in regard to hospital waste. However, I do note that the response stated that the interstate transport of hospital wastes, which had been undertaken in some instances to avoid local requirements, was being considered under a number of intergovernmental initiatives—not the least of which were the national guidelines for the management of clinical and related wastes as well as the Australian code for the transport of dangerous goods by road and rail.

Rather than spend time on that recommendation, I would like to note some of the other responses to the committee's report. As a member of the committee, I was particularly keen to see that these recommendations were responded to. The second recommendation of the committee stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that approvals for the construction of incinerators—
that meant waste disposal incinerators—
should include recycling and waste to energy facilities . . .
Part of the government's response was that:

Responsibility for the granting of approvals for the construction of incinerators typically lies with the State and Territory Governments rather than the Commonwealth Government. As such it would be most appropriate for State and Territory Governments to determine what conditions . . .

I would suggest that that is rather much a cop-out, because it would not be inappropriate for the federal government to undertake research into this sort of matter and make recommendations, and that was very much the theme of the initial report.

PARA.TAB: The committee saw that the Commonwealth government had a role in establishing research and models for the most appropriate way of dealing with some of the problems. To read in the government's response that, as usual, the federal government would rather not adopt that role but leave it to the states to dream up their own ways of dealing with things really shows that this is a case of the federal government not undertaking the role which we have a right to expect them to.

That criticism does not apply to all of the government responses, just to a couple that I will deal with in making these remarks. With regard to high temperature incineration, the third recommendation of the committee was that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . technologies designed to reuse or recycle be given priority, and environmentally friendlier alternative technologies for the destruction of scheduled waste be considered in preference to high temperature incineration . . .
I am pleased to read that the government's response in the first instance was to say:
This recommendation is consistent with the position taken by ANZECC and is supported.
The government's response further noted:

This decision reflected a conceptual shift away from one of managing all of Australia's scheduled waste as a single waste stream and disposing of it through the establishment of a centralised disposal facility, to one of acknowledging the separate components of the scheduled waste stream and placing reliance on a range of emerging technologies for treating the different parts of the scheduled waste stream.
We are very pleased to note that response, because it is very much in accord with the sort of evidence that the committee received.

PARA.TAB: I would like to remind the Senate that on page 4 of the committee's report, which we tabled in September 1994, we noted at point 1.14 Professor Worner's very interesting evidence to the committee. Professor Worner is the scientific adviser for the Illawarra Technology Corporation Ltd. He brought to the committee the concept that there is no such thing as waste; it is just a resource that wants some innovative idea on how it can be used.

With this refreshing attitude we move away from the idea that waste is a troublesome and somewhat inconvenient substance to the concept that waste is something which is a challenge to our capacity to innovate and derive some benefit from. By doing that we move right away from the idea that waste has to be burnt in a high temperature incinerator to the concept of waste being something for which we can explore alternative uses and, therefore, alternative benefits. This concept brings us to an entirely different approach to what is appropriate to place in landfills.
Skipping recommendations Nos 4 and 5 and the associated responses, I look at recommendation 6, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that the Government investigate the potential and feasibility of using cement kilns for the disposal of particular waste streams—
The government response was:
The opportunities for disposing of particular waste streams should be examined on a case-by-case basis and would be best undertaken by State and Territory Governments—

Again that is somewhat of a cop-out. It is important to note that there is another reason for criticising that response, apart from the criticism that it is a cop-out. The government response continues:
The future use of these and other materials will be dependent on, among other things, the economics of the practice and community concerns about using cement kilns for waste disposal purposes.

As far as I am concerned, here is a direct opportunity for the Commonwealth government to help the community determine whether their concerns are properly based. That is what governments are for. The federal government can and should use its resources to conduct research, to lead the debate and to make sure the community is informed about the potential advantages and disadvantages of different ways of disposing of waste.

PARA.TAB: In recommendation 7, where the committee recommended that the government investigate the avenues available to regulate the use of materials for recycling in preference to their use as a supplementary fuel, the government response was, essentially, that these opportunities should be examined on a case by case assessment and that, to a large extent, market demand will determine that. Here is a distinct role for national leadership.

Many of the waste management options are driven by threshold quantities. We all know that newspapers, used tyres, waste oil and construction materials are good examples of this tendency. We know there are several potential uses for tyres. To abandon the question of regulation and to rely solely on the market is an abrogation of government responsibility and is a strategy which could well lead to confusion and a set of practices which are contradictory.

To be specific here, three used tyres are a nuisance. If they are in the backyard, most people would recognise them as a nuisance. Thirty used tyres are somewhat of a headache. But when you have 3,000 used tyres, they become a real problem to store, to transport, to reuse or to dispose of. But at that stage significant costs and significant potential benefits are likely. If we have three million tyres, that would be a significant resource and would enable the establishment of reprocessing facilities, infrastructure, marketing et cetera.

Legislation can and should be used to encourage the aggregation of such a resource. If it is illegal to dump tyres, if it is illegal to burn them in the backyard or if it is illegal to dispose of them in certain other ways, then it becomes more likely that a significant resource can be aggregated. My point is that legislative leadership does have a role. It is just not good enough to avoid that role and leave that matter to the market, as this response has done.

However, in general terms, I am rather pleased that essentially the response—for example, in answer to the committee's recommendation 11 that where technology is available governments work with industry to encourage the use of recycled materials instead of raw materials—tells us that the government is doing that, as it does with recommendation 12, which is about a consultative process. In particular, we suggest in recommendation 13 some waste reduction targets, and the response tells us that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the National Waste Database, currently being developed, will provide information to waste managers and the community on waste generation and progress towards achieving a 50% reduction in the amount of waste going to landfill by the year 2000.
Also, I am pleased to notice that, in a recent edition of the Daily Telegraph Mirror, we have been advised that New South Wales is substantially increasing its fines for illegally dumped waste.

PARA.TAB: So, in general, the government is moving towards some of the recommendations which we made. Also, I am pleased to see that this issue has achieved a higher priority than it had before the committee reported.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE MAJORITY REPORT OF THE SENATE SELECT COMMITTEE ON ABC MANAGEMENT AND OPERATIONS

The government notes that the general conclusion of the Select Committee majority report is that the basic structure of the ABC is sound and the organisation is stronger and more relevant to the community than it was ten years ago.

That the majority report can draw this conclusion about the ABC's performance reflects in part this government's record and commitment to ensuring that the ABC is equipped to deliver its charter responsibilities and continues to provide services that are relevant to and valued by the community.

The government initiated triennial funding arrangements in 1988-89 which allow the ABC to plan for the future with a high degree of certainty. The triennial funding arrangements have maintained ABC funding in real terms since the exemption of the ABC from the efficiency dividend in 1991 and also allow the ABC to retain revenue generated from its commercial activities. This funding stability provided by the government indicates the importance the government attaches to the role of the ABC.
In the 1995-96 Budget, the ABC, together with other triennially funded agencies, was exempted from running costs reductions applying to all other Commonwealth departments and agencies.

A number of recent initiatives by the government have broadened the scope of ABC services. These include extension of ABC Fine Music, ABC Triple J, and the Second Regional Radio initiative which are providing additional ABC radio services to regional Australia. The government has provided $5.4 million to assist the ABC to establish the Australia Television satellite service. The government has also allocated to the ABC a satellite Pay TV licence for two channels and has provided $12.5 million to assist ABC participation in Pay TV.

The government notes that many of the majority report's recommendations impinge on areas which are properly the responsibility of the ABC. There is a comprehensive legislative framework of controls and reporting requirements to ensure that the ABC board is accountable to the Parliament and the Minister for the exercise of these responsibilities:

the ABC board is required to prepare a corporate plan for a period of not less than three years, including forecasts of revenue and expenditure, and to immediately notify the Minister of matters that have arisen that may significantly affect the achievement of the corporate plan's objectives, strategies, or forecasts of revenue or expenditure;
the board is required to prepare estimates, in such form as the Minister directs, of receipts and expenditure for each financial year or for any other period specified by the Minister;

the ABC is subject to Audit Act requirements including requirements in relation to the keeping of proper accounts, audit of accounts and records of financial transactions by the Auditor-General, and the preparation of an Annual Report and financial statements audited by the Auditor-General which are to be tabled in Parliament

ABC use of Budget funds is subject to regular scrutiny by Senate Legislation Committees. Parliament is also able to seek information about the ABC's day-to-day operations through, for example, questions on notice and Parliamentary inquiries.

The Parliament has also given the ABC the ability to act commercially, though such activities must relate to ABC functions. The government has developed a framework to ensure that the ABC is accountable for its commercial activities and that these involve no detriment to ABC core activities, including:

structural separation (ie use of subsidiary companies) as a condition of providing funding assistance to ATV; the allocation of pay TV Licence C was legally contingent upon the establishment of a separate corporate structure

reporting arrangements to ensure there is an appropriate level of scrutiny of ABC commercial activities, consistent with the ABC's independence and the ABC board's accountability for all ABC activities

PARA.TAB: reporting requirements for ATV and ABC pay TV include provision of annual financial statements, immediate notification of significant events to the Minister and provision of six monthly activity reports
separate financial reporting for ABC Enterprises and the development of auditable cost allocation guidelines.

This letter is to inform you of the ABC's response to. the Report of the Senate Select Committee on ABC Management and Operations.

The board welcomed the major findings of the Report. The statements recognising the importance of the ABC in the lives of all Australians and the ABC's high reputation both within Australia and overseas were particularly pleasing. We agree with the Committee when it said that the basic structure of the ABC is sound and that the need for a quality independent national broadcaster is greater today than it was a decade ago.

The committee's support for an independent national broadcaster, playing an essential part in this Australian democracy, is very much appreciated. The comments in relation to adequate funding were equally welcome.
The board has carefully considered the recommendations of the majority report and the comments in the minority report. Attached is the ABC's response to each recommendation.

You will see that all recommendations relevant to ABC Editorial Policies have been referred to the Editorial Policies Working Group (with board and management representation). The Group is working to develop the next edition of the booklet. The booklet will undergo more substantial rewriting on this occasion than has been the case when a new edition is published. A discussion paper which included the relevant Committee recommendations has been distributed throughout the ABC, calling for staff input. The National Advisory Council and the Independent Complaints Review Panel were also asked to contribute. The comments and suggestions are currently being reviewed by the Working Group, after which drafting and further consultation will take place.

At this stage, it is difficult to predict the final outcome of the drafting and consultative processes. However I can assure you that the full board (to whom the Working Group reports) is committed to developing a clear, comprehensive and consistent set of policies to guide ABC personnel in their working lives and to safeguard the independence of the Corporation.

In the same way that recommendations covering editorial matters have been referred to the editorial group, recommendations covering human resources have been referred to the Human Resources board of Management. These matters were the subject of initial discussions at the recent meeting of the Joint Consultative Committee (JCC). The JCC, established under section 81 of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983, includes representatives of the corporation and relevant unions. Discussions will continue at subsequent meetings.

The recommendation in relation to Business News Australia (BNA) has been overtaken by events. You will no doubt be aware that the ABC has decided to end the BNA service when present contractual arrangements are concluded. In other instances, you will see that the thrust of the recommendations has already been implemented.

The ABC will consider further the recommendations in relation to Australia Television and will discuss them with you in due course. You are aware that the board is currently reviewing aspects of the Australia Television service in light of the fact that it has not attracted sufficient sponsorship to achieve revenue targets.
In relation to the subscription television recommendation, the board itself will consistently assess whether any, and if so what, effects on ABC editorial and
program independence might arise once the two subscription channels have commenced operation.

I note that the committee has treated a range of ABC activities which involve some element of marketing or revenue raising as being "commercial". This is a confusing description in that many of these activities exist in order to provide a service and any "commercial" component is incidental

Board guidelines ensure that all revenue raising activity compiles with fair competition practices; full transparency and accountability, including a range of credible performance indicators; strict financial controls and audits; and meets the ABC's Charter objectives. The close integration of ABC activities without an over burdening bureaucratic structure has given life to the majority of ABC products and services. Introduction of an administratively more complex and costly structure would, in the ABC's view, provide little advantage or value and in reality would more likely reduce the viability, variety and range of products available, disadvantaging many Australians.

The board welcomes the recognition that decentralisation may warrant an increase in funding to meet the costs involved. Within financial constraints, the board encourages efforts to keep a sensible spread of staff and resources across Australia. The ABC is pleased that the relevant industrial unions have offered to work cooperatively and constructively with us to this end.

The Corporate Plan is currently undergoing its annual review in preparation for commencement on 1 July next. It is anticipated that the new version win spell out more clearly the ABC's ongoing commitment to its staff.

The board has no comment to make in relation to the composition of and appointments to the board, except to confirm the ABC position advanced throughout the inquiry process that these are matters for the Governor General acting on the advice of government. The board does not intend to take up the recommendation to establish a separate, full-time secretariat.
Please do not hesitate to contact me if you require any further information.
Yours sincerely,
MARK ARMSTRONG

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Vanstone, I present a report of the committee entitled Organised Criminal Paedophile Activity, together with the transcript of evidence. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: In February 1994 the Review of Commonwealth Law Enforcement Arrangements said that there were allegations about the existence of networks of paedophiles operating in Australia and that the extent of the networks and their activities remained unknown. The report recommended that organised paedophile networks should be added to the areas of major organised crime that the National Crime Authority was expected to focus on, and the government accepted this recommendation. In December 1994 the committee agreed to conduct an inquiry into the extent to which organised paedophile networks had become established in Australia, and related matters such as the adequacy of police resources and the role of the National Crime Authority in tackling this area of criminal activity. To some extent the conclusions reached on the scope of organised paedophile activity depend on the breadth or narrowness of definitions adopted for such key terms as `paedophile', `child pornography' and `organised networks'. Yet obviously those terms are used with widely varying definitions.

PARA.TAB: The information presented to the committee was that most sexual offences against children are committed by their relatives and neighbours who are not paedophiles in the strict sense of the term and who do not operate in any organised or network way. To the extent that two or more paedophiles group together to commit offences, the numbers involved have almost invariably been very small and the groupings very much ad hoc and on a peer-to-peer basis. More commonly, where there are contacts between paedophile offenders, they consist of loose, informal networks of peer-to-peer contacts. The committee did not receive any evidence that organised paedophile groups and networks have ever resembled in size, aims, structures, methods or longevity the organised crime groups which provide the main focus for the National Crime Authority's work.

Again, the committee did not receive evidence of any commercial production of illegal child pornography in Australia. Most of the current illegal material that undoubtedly is possessed by many paedophiles appears to be made by them, obtained by informal trading of homemade material among paedophiles assisted by informal networking, or obtained from overseas. There is no evidence of organised promotion or arrangement of tours by Australian paedophiles to overseas destinations known to be attractive to them. However, informal networking among paedophiles may assist some tourists going overseas to commit paedophile offences.

In light of the evidence on the nature and extent of organised paedophile activity, the committee found it necessary to make only limited recommendations for change. The committee considered it essential that any focus by law enforcement agencies on organised paedophilia is not at the expense of resources devoted to the majority of cases of child sexual abuse. While clearly paedophile networking should not be ignored, an over-emphasis on it risks distracting community attention from the majority of child sex offenders—the lone offenders who are all too frequently members of the same family or household as their victims.

The committee noted that the National Crime Authority is to complete its own strategic intelligence assessment of organised paedophile activity early in 1996. Mr Sherman, the authority chairperson, told the committee in August that if the authority assessment matched the committee's he did not propose that the National Crime Authority stay around in that area creating a role for itself. The committee endorsed this view. The specialist units in state and territory police forces have the experience, facilities and expertise in investigating child sexual assault that the National Crime Authority does not have.

In coming to this view, the committee recognised that there was scope for improvement in the way that the various police forces work together to detect paedophile offenders. Police told the committee that cooperation amongst their forces was generally good, but they agreed that there could be improvements.

Another area where the committee considered that improvements could be made is in the detection of child pornography which has been imported electronically via computer links. At present, no particular agency appears to have responsibility for the surveillance of the computer transmission of pornographic material. The committee believes the Commonwealth government should accept responsibility for the detection of offences involving the transmission of child pornography using the telephone network. This responsibility ought to be resolved by direct arrangements between the specialist state and territory units and whichever Commonwealth agency is considered to be most suitable for the job. The committee considered, however, that the National Crime Authority was not the suitable agency in this case.

In addition, the committee believes that there are obvious benefits in Australian law enforcement agencies working cooperatively to equip themselves with the necessary computer training, expertise and access to specialised software and hardware tools needed to keep them abreast of the actual and potential use of computers for criminal paedophile purposes. We have made recommendations to this effect. The committee also recommended that the Minister for Justice explore the possibility of establishing a single, well publicised e-mail address accessible through the Internet to which computer users can report any indications they come across of computer distribution of child pornography—in effect, an e-mail hotline.

Another area in which the committee recommended changes concerned the activity of Australian paedophiles in South-East Asia. The committee recommended that the government take steps to improve the arrangements between the Thai, Cambodian and other South-East Asian authorities to assist in the detection and obtaining of evidence to enable the prosecution of Australians committing child sex offences in those countries. The committee also made recommendations designed to improve the flow of information to the Australian Federal Police about the illegal activities of Australian paedophiles overseas.

Some non-government organisations argued that improved record keeping on suspected and convicted child sex offenders was needed to assist them to vet their staff and persons working through them. It was said that police records do not always contain the names of persons notified as abusers to child welfare agencies, and better integration of agencies records was required. It seemed to the committee that what was sought ideally was a national register of known and suspected child sex offenders. The committee made no recommendation on this issue.

The committee has identified in its report its concerns with the scope of the proposals put to it. In particular, the committee did not favour the view that the register should include the names of alleged offenders who had not been convicted. I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to comment briefly on the report of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority entitled Organised Criminal Paedophile Activity. The committee found that there is very little, if any, organised paedophile criminal activity as we understand that term, not that that is any consolation. It does mean that such activity is more widely dispersed, is more prevalent than we suspected and is more difficult to investigate, identify and prosecute. It is no consolation that many Australian paedophiles travel overseas to indulge in these crimes.

PARA.TAB: While we have relevant legislation to prosecute those people, it is proving extremely difficult to do this and does depend to a large extent on the effective cooperation of the police forces in the countries the paedophiles travel to to commit these crimes. When they return, it does mean that Australian children are more at risk. It is difficult to apprehend offenders when they are not organised and therefore not easily identifiable.

The report found that most sexual offences against children are committed by their relatives and neighbours who are not paedophiles in the strict sense of the term and who do not operate in an organised or networked way. To cope with this particular situation the committee made a number of recommendations which, to a large extent, are related to resources and to the organisation of these resources by our law enforcement agencies. These recommendations relate to training, access to specialist expertise and, obviously, access to criminal intelligence databases such as the one operated by the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence.

The committee suggested further that there should be formal agreements between relevant law enforcement agencies relating to information sharing which could be used in this particular case. It has asked the Minister for Justice to raise these matters with the Australasian Police Ministers Council to examine to what extent action is necessary.

The committee recommended that the Minister for Justice take steps to ensure that Australian law enforcement agencies contribute to and draw on the expertise and software tools of overseas law enforcement agencies. That brings me back to the point that I raised before that we need to step up the cooperation and arrangements that exist between Australian and overseas police forces. In that context, the Thai police force and law enforcement agencies in Cambodia were mentioned. The committee also recommended that the government take steps to ensure that all personnel working overseas in countries believed to be attractive to visiting Australian paedophiles are made aware that any information they happen to come across about the illegal activities of such paedophiles should be reported to the Australian Federal Police for further investigation and prosecution in Australia.

While this necessarily limited inquiry found no evidence of organised paedophile activity, there is no doubt from the evidence before the committee that such activities are being pursued in Australia, very often in conjunction with child pornography. I trust and hope that the government will take seriously the committee's recommendation to make the Australian law enforcement agencies' work in this area more effective.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: This report arose essentially from several crises around the world, particularly the failure of the Barings Brothers bank out of the action by Nick Leeson in the Singapore exchange a little over a year ago. There were also other major crashes at about the same time. I guess the other most famous one was Orange County in the US, where there were losses of $US1.76 billion. They were to do with futures on interest rates. The Baring Brothers one was futures on stocks and bonds. There were quite a few others in the last few years that achieved notoriety around the world.

PARA.TAB: Our committee commenced an inquiry into this matter with relevance for Australia in November last year. We found on the evidence that what happened in Singapore was, in fact, a management problem in that the dealer was acting also as the backroom accountant and was not being supervised by management. So the fundamental lesson to be learnt from the Baring Brothers failure is that dealers dealing in derivatives need to be separate from the accountant who is doing the settlement—handling the money, in other words. They need to be separate and, beyond that, management overseeing these two groups needs to understand what is going on. That did not happen in the Leeson-Baring Brothers incident in Singapore.

We took evidence from the Australian entities that organise transactions in derivatives, specifically the Sydney Futures Exchange, the Australian Stock Exchange and also the Australian Securities Commission. The evidence was that the chance of this non-separation happening in Australia was, in fact, virtually impossible. There is close supervision by the exchanges of the processing of derivative products, a clear separation of dealing from accounting, and a clear recognition by management of overseeing these matters. Each of the exchanges goes to a lot of trouble to make sure that they understand the positions that have been taken by firms and by individuals, which was something that did not take place, for instance, in Singapore.

The other important thing to note is that there is now, following that Baring Brothers failure—and part of that was due to a lack of understanding between rival exchanges as to contracts taken out in two rival exchanges—a worldwide move to try to coordinate an understanding of the positions taken by players in the derivatives market. The committee welcomes that.

Our main conclusions are that for Australia there is no need for additional legislation over this area. We believe the market is working well, but an eye needs to be kept on it. We recommend, in fact, to the Australian Securities Commission that in the annual report they should give a synopsis of the derivatives market as it operates here in Australia.

We do not believe there should be any restriction on raising new products. There are new products in the derivatives market being thought about and put on the market on a reasonably regular basis. We do not believe there should be any legislative controls on that process, but when they are incorporated, there needs to be the key principles of separation of dealers from the people who pay the money, the accountants, with management overseeing the lot. Our committee found that we in Australia are fortunate; we do have a good system. As I said, the only thing that is missing and which our exchanges are looking at, and are actively involved in, is the matter of international cooperation on positions taken by traders in this business.

The final main recommendation is that there should be more effort made by the people involved in the industry to make sure people around the periphery and others, the general public, have a better understanding of what derivatives are and when they are used. They are, in fact, a risk reduction means for people in the financial markets. They are a means of reducing risk, particularly for major players in the industry, and they do add value. They are a genuine addition to the markets and a good thing for the market. I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—In the time available to me to deal with this important report, Australia's relations with Thailand, I would like to deal with two points before making some general comments on the Australia-Thailand relationship. The first specific point relates to an earlier report by the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade and a recommendation in its report on human rights. The second point relates to other recent reports of the committee.

PARA.TAB: In November 1993, we tabled a report entitled Australia's relations with Indonesia. One of its recommendations dealt with the inclusion of an assessment of progress towards the establishment and protection of human rights in that country by Australia's development assistance agency. The government's response to that report seems to imply that the committee was in some way recommending a change to the policy by which the development assistance program is not linked to human rights performance. The committee was in fact aware of that policy and was not recommending a change.

The government's response to the report also made the point that virtually all development assistance, such as women in development or poverty alleviation projects, has human rights implications. The report I have just tabled on relations with Thailand includes a recommendation that the development assistance agency target projects which are directed towards improving human rights in that country. In making this recommendation, the committee is not asking the Australian government to change its policy and link development assistance with progress towards human rights.

The paragraph immediately before the recommendation explicitly says that this is not the case. It points out that the specific human rights emphasis in the development assistance program in Thailand is not definable. This country is prepared to spend $44.9 million on development assistance in Thailand. It also emphasises the universality of human rights. It is surely not unreasonable, therefore, to expect some focus on programs which, following consultation with the Thai authorities, have an emphasis on human rights. We would hope that those who prepare the government response are aware not only of this recommendation but also of what seems to be a gap in our assistance program.

The second point I would like to make relates to another report tabled recently by the joint standing committee. It was very noticeable, although the section of the report which dealt with prostitution was only three pages out of 110, this was the only section which received media attention. The report's title was Human rights and progress towards democracy in Burma, and that faithfully reflects its emphasis. It would be a pity if the same thing happened to the report on relationships with Thailand. Although trafficking in women for the purposes of prostitution is an important issue, it is only a small part of our report, which deals with the bilateral relationship between Australia and Thailand.

A look at the table of contents makes it clear that this report deals with the bilateral relationship in detail. To do this, for example, it describes the Thai economy and sets out the trading relationship between the two nations. Part 3 deals with a number of important Australian connections and opportunities, including defence, legal and educational relationships. It looks at Thailand's relations with its neighbours and piracy in the region.

Viewed as a whole, this report seeks to improve a relationship which was described as `longstanding, close and cordial'. It was also put to us that just after the Second World War this relationship was at its peak and has not achieved those heights since. While there is nothing wrong with the bilateral relationship, it lacks something. Thailand is a very important nation in South-East Asia and it would be very easy to make a selfish, national interest case in favour of a close relationship. Another reason could be that the two nations get on well at a personal level.

The committee has made a number of recommendations which it hopes will be effective in broadening and deepening the relationship. While many reasons could be advanced to achieve this end, this is the one which has guided the committee in its deliberations. It believes that Australia has a range of skills and expertise in a number of areas which may be of use to Thailand.

In framing these recommendations, we were conscious that many require consultation with Thai authorities before they can be adopted and that they will make the decisions about our offers of assistance. This is how it should be. We would also hope that the Australian government will look at these recommendations positively and look for ways to incorporate ideas from this report into the existing policy framework. Parliamentary committees often feel that government responses to reports are unjustly dismissive of their efforts. I very much hope that this will not be the case with this report. I commend the report to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: So as not to spend too long on it, I shall refer to some of the matters raised in the letter that they have sent to me, Senator McMullan, Mr Langmore, Mr Smyth, Mr Simon Crean, Mr Snowdon, Mr Free, Mr Ronaldson and Mrs Gallus. in the ACT—
