TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Airports Bill 1995 and the Airports (Transitional) Bill 1995 which establish the framework for the leasing of 22 Federal Airports Corporation airports. The bills typify the Labor Party's approach to privatisation and are a case study of the way that the Minister for Transport, Mr Brereton, deals with his portfolio. The coalition supports the privatisation of the airports but will be moving a number of amendments to these bills.

PARA.TAB: The transitional bill sets out the legislative framework for leasing the 22 airports and the Sydney West airport, and for resolving the financial and personnel issues raised by the leasing process. The Airports Bill establishes the regulatory system that would apply to the airports once they are leased and would apply to the successful tenderers. The airports would be leased for a period of 50 years with an option of a 49-year extension.

A number of sections of the bill are particularly interesting. Part 3, for instance, would establish a 49 per cent limit on foreign ownership of airport lessee companies, a five per cent limit on ownership by airlines, and a 15 per cent limit on the cross-ownership of the Sydney-Melbourne airport pair and the Brisbane-Sydney airport pair.

Part 5 sets out a range of land use, planning and business controls. Airport operators would be required to submit master plans and master development plans to the Minister for Transport for approval. Airport operators would also be required to submit their environmental plans for approval.

One of the key issues raised by the leasing process is that of the maintenance of existing service levels and a hopeful reduction in charges. It is interesting to note that only some weeks ago the minister decided to enforce upon the industry an increase in the charges that would lift the sale price of the airports. One of the reasons for leasing the airports was hopefully to organise a system whereby, with the efficiencies generated, there would be a reduction in charges which would benefit not only the consumers but also the tourism industry. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, the ACCC, already has the power to monitor the charges imposed by airport lessees. Part 8 of the bill would enable it to monitor the quality of the service that it provides.

One of the most interesting aspects of this bill is the Labor Party's attitude to privatisation. The 22 airports are another of those national assets that the Labor Party promised to keep in public hands. The now Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said in 1985 that the privatisation of authorities like the Commonwealth Bank or TAA was:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . simply vandalism of Australia's great public authorities, which in no way deals with the problem of cutting recurrent expenditures.
He also said:
The Labor Party will fight tooth and nail to keep these public authorities in the hands of the Commonwealth.
I remember over the years hearing ALP members and senators speaking in horrified terms about the possibility of airports being privatised.

PARA.TAB: As recently as 1986 the then Minister for Transport, Mr Morris, said that privatising the airlines and the airports was a dangerous policy. The ALP's 1991 platform said, `Labor will ensure the Federal Airports Corporation remains in full public ownership, operates on an efficient basis and continues to develop along competitive lines and establish similar public owned undertakings where appropriate.' Yet today we are debating the privatisation of the airports. We have already seen Qantas sold, and now we have a bill which will privatise the airports—a device in the government's view to reduce temporarily the budget deficit rather than encourage competition and the development of innovative services. The light on the hill has turned out to be a neon sign saying, `Labor principles for sale at a price.' That is what it is all about. It has nothing to do with the matter of efficiency, competition or of saying that certain things should be run by the private sector. It is simply a matter of saying, `We cannot resist getting our hands on the dollars.'

I think it is important to recognise the great work done by the Federal Airports Corporation. When the corporation came into being in about 1988, there was a little pea and thimble trick; a little creative accounting. The FAC was given some $600 million of debt on assets where there was not a debt in the past. The taxpayers of Australia paid for the construction of airports. The FAC was given a debt of $600 million and was told to do all the expansions that could be done to improve the efficiency of airports, which is what it did. It did it very effectively without coming back to the budget. Now the government is saying, `You have an asset which is worth a lot of money.' Estimates floating around the place show it to be in the order of $2 billion. I guess the scoping study would have a more accurate figure than that. The government is saying, `Here is an opportunity for us to bring back money and then artificially reduce the budget deficit.' It is the old pea and thimble trick.

The way the government has approached the privatisation process is a case study of how this government operates. It has been characterised by ruthlessness, arrogance and a determination to crush anyone who disagrees with its views. The list of casualties in the Department of Transport alone and the statutory authorities under Mr Brereton's control is an extensive one. We have seen the resignation of the head of the Civil Aviation Authority, Mr Doug Roser. We have seen the resignation of Vanessa Fanning, the Principal Aviation Adviser to the Department of Transport. We have seen the movement of Graham Evans, the Secretary to the Department of Transport. We have seen the resignation of Bill Swingler, the Chief Executive of the Federal Airports Corporation, who, when the government took off him the role of determining airport charges, took the view `What else have we got?' and thought it better to resign. Just recently, we have seen the resignation of Mr Sandy White, the General Manager of Sydney West airport at Badgerys Creek.

Mr Brereton sacked the board of ANL and replaced them with his mates, Mr Neville Wran and Mr Malcolm Turnbull. The FAC board made the mistake of questioning a lot of the things that were being done in regard to the leasing process, so Mr Brereton got rid of them too. It is interesting that, on the very day that I attended the opening of the Brisbane international airport—which is, again, a credit to the Federal Airports Corporation—and when the speeches were given, a senior person in the FAC remarked to me, `This is the first time the minister has said a nice word about the FAC.' The then chairman of the board responded in glowing terms about what the FAC had done—and quite correctly so.

On that day, there was an item on the AAP saying that the board of the FAC was resigning. The curious thing was that no-one on the board of the FAC knew they were resigning. It was only a few days later that someone told them that they had to resign. What a way to run a business! What a way to run a government! That is the way this minister operates. He got rid of the whole board, and he again brought in a board of his own.

The minister ignored any objections raised by people throughout the consultation process. For example, he ignored the industry's concerns about the demand management provisions in the bill. Part 13 of the bill would give the minister wide ranging powers to impose a demand management scheme on the airport without consulting the airport operator or the airport users. The minister did not consult with the local authorities around the airport. In his second reading speech to the House of Representatives on these bills, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Commonwealth has undertaken extensive consultation with a range of interested parties, including the states and territories, local government, the airlines, the aviation industry, other airport users and potential investors.

This is totally untrue. I have been visited by and received letters from local government people—and maybe my colleagues on the other side have received similar letters—who assure me that they have had no consultation whatsoever. They only knew about the draft bills put by this government when they read about them in the newspapers. How can you trust a government like this? How can you trust a minister like this? The minister must have known darn well that there was no consultation, yet he made the statement—which was also in the second reading speech in the Senate—that he had consulted with local government.

PARA.TAB: There are some concerns from local government people, and I understand their concerns. They would like to have a clause in this legislation that requires the same good neighbour practice that occurs with the Federal Airports Corporation, as they believe that it has worked fairly well. There are some in local government who would like to go a lot further, but generally the view of the people on the mayoral councils and the people who are interested in these major airports is that they would like a similar type of clause in the legislation—which is presently not there—requiring the same good neighbour approach that was in the Federal Airports Corporation legislation.
Senator Calvert interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Calvert, the reason for it is that they would be able to get a fair return based on the sorts of services provided to the airport, but not to the extent that it could damage the efficiency and cost of running the airport.

PARA.TAB: The coalition's position is that we support the leases. We always have. We have not changed. It is this government that has decided that it is going to make sacrifices. These sacred cows of the Labor Party have said, `We would never privatise the airports. That would be dangerous,' and other things like that. Imagine, Senator Forshaw, what the left wing of your party is thinking about this now. These were icons of the Labor Party—but not any more, for just 30 pieces of silver. You have a price. You are not as cheap as the Democrats, but you are getting close.

Our position is we will only support these bills on two conditions. One is that the government resolves the noise problem of Sydney airport by reopening the east-west runway and conducts a genuine EIS on Sydney West airport. We have debated this in recent days, but the reason for this particular amendment is that, until October last year, Sydney had two active runways—two runways, two active runways. In November last year the third runway was completed. Lo and behold, we have three runways, but only one and seven-eighths are active.

As a result of that, people—mainly in the north, but certainly in the south around Kurnell—were subject to aircraft noise that they never dreamed of. They believe they were deceived and lied to. The only way to address this problem is to give the authorities three active runways so that they can have the flexibility to address the three competing ends—noise, safety and capacity.

That mode of operation is one that is supported by just about everyone, except those who are instructed otherwise by this government. There have been only two groups that have actually come out and supported the government. One is the Air Services people, and you have to expect that. As I said the other day, they have said quite openly that their job is to respond to government policy and to support government policy. They have got no option.

The other group was the airlines. As I mentioned in the debate on the Sydney Airport Curfew Bill the other day, their credibility is not helped by the fact that the minister ran around town two weeks earlier saying, `I'm going to get these airlines to sing my song.' He has got the power to do that. He has got the power to frighten them. But, offset against that, we have got experts—the pilots, the air traffic controllers and people like Flight Transportation Associates out of Massachusetts—

TALK.START.PARA: —The air traffic controllers haven't supported you at all.
—I am glad you interjected on that, Senator. The air traffic controllers said that you could happily operate three runways if there was the political will to do it.
—You could do it, but it is not safe.
—We had Senator Bob Collins in here when he had to defend the near miss in 1991 or thereabouts swearing that this mode of operation was perfectly safe.

PARA.TAB: We will be moving an amendment to bring forward Adelaide airport into the first tranche of airport privatisation. The reason for that is that this is what the South Australians wanted. It wasn't a knee-jerk reaction on our part. Adelaide is in the same category as Perth. The sale of the Adelaide airport is not affected one way or another by the sale of the Sydney or Badgerys Creek airports. It is a stand-alone operation with regard to the sale, the same as Perth.

Under the government's proposal, this would have been delayed at least a year past the sale of the first tranche. The view of the financial institutions and of all the prospective buyers when consulted about this was that they did not know why Adelaide was not included in the first place—no reason at all. I will be moving amendments in the committee stage to incorporate these conditions in the bills.

Our first condition relates to Sydney's disastrous aircraft noise problem. The government's decision to concentrate the noise generated to the north and south has devastated the lives of some hundreds of thousands of people. Air Services argue that some 75,000 are affected by the noise, but that figure does not take into account many areas affected by aircraft in places such as Ku-Ring-Gai. They weren't included. They weren't on the contours of being affected. The methodology used by Air Services is based on a survey conducted in 1992 in areas that had been subjected to aircraft noise for years. The results were not applicable to areas where the aircraft noise level has changed dramatically.

The concentration of aircraft in the approaches to the parallel runways is more than just an annoyance; it raises a whole lot of other serious concerns in respect of health and safety. According to Sydney University's Faculty of Medicine, the health effects could include an increase in cardiovascular disease, hypertension due to stress, sleep disturbance and so on.

The concentration of aircraft movements in the approaches to the parallel runways has dramatically increased the risk of an air accident in the suburbs. It is not the fact that the potential will increase, but the fact that these aircraft are now crossing urban areas. It has been calculated by some people that in many instances they are crossing some 60 kilometres of built-up areas. When various questions were raised on this matter, the point was made that this was a policy decision.

There have been a lot of policy decisions. One was to virtually close the east-west runway; another one was to narrow the flight corridors; and another one was a crazy one suggested by the minister to increase the glide path on landings from three degrees to six degrees. That was discounted even by the Air Services people. They couldn't bring themselves to accept that.

According to Professor Cross, a statistician from the University of New South Wales, the risk of a crash of a scheduled aircraft in Marrickville with the third runway operating is one in 15.6 years. In any 10-year period, between one and two crashes could be expected. That is the potential. These are the sorts of problems raised. They are the reasons why we will move two amendments.

To recapitulate, the first amendment reinforces that it is not for people in parliament—as this government has done—to tell an airport operator or the equivalent of Air Services how to run its airport. It gives them the flexibility with three active runways to come up with a solution that will address those three major competing problems—noise, capacity and safety. The second amendment will simply bring forward the sale of Adelaide airport and put it in the same category as Perth. To argue, as the minister has done, that this will somehow delay the extension of Adelaide airport is as phoney as all the other things that this minister says from time to time when he gets half a chance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak on these airport bills. I must confess that I find Senator Parer's remarks somewhat remarkable in light of the fact that somewhere amongst all that negativity and criticism he has disclosed that, contrary to appearances, the coalition does support these bills with some quite minor amendments.

PARA.TAB: I was a little antagonised by some of the comments he made earlier about what is typical about this government and what is typical about the behaviour of the Australian Labor Party. I find it quite remarkable that Senator Parer and others on the other side see there being some virtue in this negative approach; see that there is a virtue in saying, `We will not support this, even though we do support it. We will try to create a situation where nothing occurs. We will support it, but we will not give it support on the floor and we will not give it support in the community. We will not accept responsibility for our view. We will not offer an alternative policy.'

The Airports Bill puts forward a framework to allow for long-term leases of the major airports that are presently administered by the FAC. It does not necessarily change the operational limitations on airports. By retaining the legal ownership of the airports, the federal government is ensuring that the regulatory powers and planning regulations they have in relation to airports are retained. The whole effect and purpose of this bill is not to visit some sort of further affliction on the general community but to protect the community interest, the communities surrounding the airports and also those who utilise the airports.

I would take this opportunity to look a little more closely at some of the restrictions this bill puts in place and what effect their non-compliance has. Section 14 of the bill requires that there be a single lessee; that the lessee be a qualified company, which is defined in the definitions section of the bill as being a company over which the Commonwealth has constitutional power; and that the lease provides for the use of the site as an airport, except in relation to Sydney West or airports where there is a joint user. The fact is that, if there is non-compliance with these particular terms of a lease, or if there is non-compliance in the transfer of a lease or the extension of a lease, the lease becomes void. In fact, there can be no stronger requirement than, if there is non-compliance, that the legal document which purports to be a lease has no effect whatsoever.

The bill also sets out extensive limitations in relation to the type of company that can take up a lease on the airports. The foreign ownership of the company is limited to 49 per cent; airline ownership of any company which takes up a lease is limited to five per cent; and there is a limitation of 15 per cent on cross-ownership for companies that have the lease of Sydney and Melbourne or Sydney and Brisbane airports. This means there are safeguards in place to ensure that a monopoly is not established and that there is ongoing competition between the airports to ensure continuing efficiencies and a better service for both the airlines and the people who utilise them.

An amendment has been foreshadowed by Senator Parer which I have not had the advantage of perusing, but I assume that I will see it at some stage. I suppose I can take a bit of a guess, from Senator Parer's comments and the general thrust of the coalition arguments in relation to the airports, at what it contains—particularly in connection with Kingsford Smith and Sydney West airports.

I suppose the coalition's view always is that what is bad news for the community is good news for them because it may reflect badly on the government. I would think there must be some concern within the community to see an amendment being put up which essentially would delay the construction of Sydney West airport and, by doing so, make it more difficult to curtail and resolve the noise problems that presently exist at Kingsford Smith. The fact is that a large amount of the revenue that will be obtained from the leasing of all these major airports will go towards the construction of Sydney West.

The amendment to be put forward by Senator Parer and the coalition, which says, effectively, that there can be no leasing of Kingsford Smith, would have two major effects. If you have a look at the profitability of the various major airports covered by this bill—19 in all—the largest profit earner by some distance is Sydney airport, which last year earned $62.6 million. Even though Sydney earned that amount, the total dividend paid to the government by the FAC for all those 19 major airports was only $8 million. The reason for this is very clear: there is major cross-subsidisation between Sydney airport and other airports that are less profitable. Melbourne and Brisbane, admittedly, do make a profit but certainly not in the same range as Sydney.

What is the effect of the amendment proposed by the coalition? It means, essentially, that the source of income which is needed to construct Sydney West will not be available. What is the solution? The solution for the coalition is no real solution; it is just an attempt to stymie the process, to stop the community being provided with a solution, to stop Sydney West airport going ahead and to ensure that everyone is tied up going nowhere and achieving nothing.

The bill does provide a number of other limitations in relation to planning aspects of the airport. It requires substantive approval by the minister to a number of matters that involve the operations of the airport and the planning provisions, particularly in regard to Sydney West. All these are retained. What is lost by the leasing out of the airport is the ongoing requirement by this government to inject capital into the airports. It has to be noted that the FAC over the last few years—since about 1988—has substantially improved the standard infrastructure of all the airports in preparation for this leasing out. But this is a process that cannot go on.

This government and the ALP see there being many other priorities—that, if there is a capacity to have an ongoing and worthwhile infrastructure by way of the airports, where the capital input is being provided by a private source leaving public moneys available for other priorities of the government, they see it as a worthwhile thing. The other priorities of the government are Medicare, education, Working Nation and the provision of long-term jobs for those who have been out of work for a long time—all provisions on which we can spend our money that make it better for members of the community, rather than spending it on putting more capital into the airports when a private company would quite happily do that. My view is that, where there is an alternative available, as there is, and that it is possible to put into place safeguards, as they have been put forward in this bill, we should inject the government funds into our higher priority areas.

I have a few comments to make about some of the issues raised by Senator Parer which were not strictly in relation to this bill. But these raised again, I suppose, our last debate—and they do say that generals always fight their last battles—in relation to the safety issue at Kingsford-Smith. Senator Parer clearly continues to not understand or intentionally misunderstand the position that, because it is possible to run intersecting runways reasonably safely, it is equivalent to intersecting runways being the safest option.

The fact is that no-one has ever asserted—whether it be BASI, Airservices Australia, me or any other member of the committee—that it is unsafe or impossible to safely operate intersecting runways. What has been asserted by all those parties, and particularly by the government members of the committee, is that it is safer to have parallel runways; that it is not worth while taking the risk of having intersecting runways when the option of having parallel runways is available. As I pointed out on the occasion when last I was on my feet, it was always the policy of the coalition to support the construction of the third runway. However, now they have found there is a political issue to be made of it, they are tap dancing around, trying to say that the position is the same whilst at the same time, in fact, opposing its construction.

The government readily recognises the difficulty of airport noise. There is certainly a large amount of sympathy from me and many other members of the government as to the effects of noise on the community surrounding the airport. Attempts have been made to reduce that by placing restrictions on the pathways that the planes are taking and by requiring noise amelioration in the homes, schools and churches that surround the airport to ensure that at least when people are inside and all the doors and windows are closed they are not as badly affected as they were. Despite all that, a proposition such as closing down the airport completely or removing all international flights out to Sydney West, if it is ever constructed, is just not a viable option.

A substantial amount of Sydney, New South Wales and the Australian economy is dependent on tourism, and the airport is an essential part of that. There certainly is some scope in the future once Sydney West is built possibly to ensure that some of the noise is shared by the Sydney West airport, but I cannot see, and I do not think any responsible or reasonable member of the coalition would ever suggest, Kingsford Smith being closed.

I have not had the opportunity to view the other portions of the amendment that Senator Parer is proposing. I suppose we will have the opportunity of debating that in committee, so I will not attempt to deal with those now. I do wish to mention a few matters raised about the Labor Party's change of position and the fact that some time in the past government members have opposed a proposition to privatise the airport, as this is described.

I have to say this bill and the scheme which it proposes clearly is not a complete disposal of the ownership of the airports. As I said earlier, this bill only envisages a lease of 50 years plus a further extension of 49 years. Upon the end of that term, I suppose it will be up to the government of the day to determine whether those airports go back into public ownership or whether the private leasing continues. But I think there is a major difference in principle and in policy between a sale of an asset owned by the government and leasing, though long term, as proposed in this bill.

Secondly, I would like to say that no policy is immutable. I suppose if you have been out of government for a while you might forget this but circumstances change, views change, new ideas come to the fore and different approaches are revealed. Because a policy that appeared the best option at a particular time was chosen does not necessarily mean that that policy is unchangeable forever.

I always have an open mind to see whether something can be done in a better way. I do not think it is necessary to say that because 100 years ago a certain policy was the right one it is necessarily the right one now. Major mistakes have been made. I am a member of a party that once believed in a white Australia policy. Because that was the policy of the people involved in the party at the time who thought it was the right one does not mean it is the right one now. I, and many people in the Australian community, do not think so.

I think this airport bill does something worth while. It allows us to protect the community interest, to retain a long-term ownership of the airports and, at the same time, to free up resources of the government to be utilised in areas where I think there is a higher priority—that is, in health, in the support of families and in reducing the number of long-term unemployed. I commend the bill to you.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to take up the time of the Senate since the government has handled things so badly that we have over 70 bills to go. I just want to make a few points about airports in general. The opposition's case has been very well put by Senator Parer in opening this debate. We are dealing with two bills—the Airports Bill 1995 and the Airports (Transitional) Bill 1995, which transfers the ownership of some airports which essentially are owned by the Commonwealth through the Federal Airports Corporation.

PARA.TAB: Airports are terribly important facilities for a country. They are comparable with seaports in bygone centuries. They can bring a great deal of wealth to a community if they are properly handled. When this government came to power we had the Department of Civil Aviation which owned the great majority of airfields in Australia—the majority from a use point of view. A lot of smaller strips were owned by councils and private individuals but essentially the DCA owned most airfields. Its whole approach was just to provide an airfield or an aerodrome and provide landing facilities for the aviation industry.

When Labor came to power it decided to split the Department of Civil Aviation, under its economic rationalist theories, and create a Federal Airports Corporation to look after the airfields and a Civil Aviation Authority to look after all the rest of the aviation business. The objective in doing that was quite a laudable one. It was to create a more efficient structure and thereby lower the cost to the community, because transport is a very big factor in Australia's GDP. It takes a very large slice of what we do and the cost implications from transport flow through to everything in the Australian community. So anything that can keep the costs down is a help.

But the Labor Party, with its usual inability to handle economic matters, did not handle the FAC very efficiently. It sold the airfields to the newly created Federal Airports Corporation at highly inflated values and then demanded a high return on those. It also did not give the Federal Airports Corporation any directive other than it had to make money out of the airfields. The government did not counsel the corporation quietly on the needs to operate airfields in an efficient way. The FAC took the view that it had a monopoly and that the consumer was going to pay.

We did see a very sharp increase in prices when the FAC took over. To illustrate the point, if you look at the airports around Australia, you will see that Australian capital cities have a primary airport to which the passenger aircraft go and secondary airports where the charter and some of the commuters operators go and training takes place. Those secondary airports probably got by—this was the case in respect of an airfield I know quite well—with a chief groundsman and maybe two or three staff. Once the FAC was ensconced there was a staff of 10 or 12 people—all of them on very high salaries, all of them getting new cars every year, mobile phones, the whole lot, and the overhead went up.

Some of those secondary airports, on FAC figures, make a loss. They make a loss because they are carrying a large bureaucratic staffing establishment, which they will never be able to support in a creation of tomcats because the business simply cannot be generated from those secondary airports to carry the managerial strata they have on top. Also, they put a very heavy figure in for depreciation each year.

Several months ago the government tried to increase or put pressure on the FAC to increase those charges a great deal more. That would have been entirely counterproductive. Fortunately, the airlines were effective enough in protesting against it and stopped it going through. But had that gone through we would have had this high income on paper from the airfields, which would have enabled the FAC and the government to get a much higher price for those airfields when they were sold. That would have built into the cost structure of Australian aviation an artificially high capital cost to purchase the airfields, which would have to be amortised and built in in perpetuity.

Whatever changes take place in the future, we need to get some stability and permanence into the business of the ownership and management of airports. I do not wish to rehash the argument that this chamber has spent so much time over about noise at Sydney airport, parallel runways, cross-runways, and the rest of it, but the fact of the matter is that you are always going to have a noise problem with airports.

Aircraft are getting quieter and quieter with the advances in technology, but there will always be some noise. You cannot solve the problem by building new airports, by moving to a greenfield site 30 miles away from the present one, because as soon as you put in a big airfield, you have to have communications links and road and rail links to it. While it might be in virginal bushland when it starts, these links attract people because of cheaper housing and cheaper land. Ten or 15 years later, as is happening now at Tullamarine, you will find you have a noise problem. So we have to cope with this noise problem.

The government has to do something in the way of defining approach paths and saying, `This airfield is here for the foreseeable future. These are the approach paths and departure paths from the airport. Anyone who lives under there has to put up with some noise.' There has to be some degree of permanence in this. We cannot just keep moving.

In this country, although it is relatively underpopulated, spaces or sites for airfields are restricted. It would be very hard to find anywhere at the Sydney basin that you could set up new airports or just a new airfield because the land is at a premium.

Another advantage of having airports that are recognised is that it concentrates aircraft and maintenance at those points. If we have a plethora of small airfields the way the United States has, surveillance by the regulatory authority becomes that much more difficult. It is highly desirable that we try to maintain the system that we have developed in this country—purely, I suppose, by trial and error—over the last 40 or 60 years of having a primary airport for the capital city and a secondary airport.

At the present time the only airports that are being sold are the primary airports, but later on the secondary airports, at places like Moorabbin, Bankstown, Parafield and Archerfield will be sold. I hope there is provision for those airfields to be linked to the primary airports which are being sold at the present time because I see one supporting the other. The high volume traffic which will always go through the primary airports with passenger movements, with the regular public transport services, provides a big economic base and those airports can be, and should be, very profitable.

The supporting airports, the secondary airports, by the very nature of their role simply have difficulties in paying their way, even if they do not have the bloated staff that the Federal Airports Corporation has imposed on them at the present time. But they are essential in so far as they provide a training and support facility for the industry that is necessary to keep it in place. With those few words, I finish my speech by saying that I have much pleasure in supporting the amendments moved by Senator Parer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must at least congratulate Senator MacGibbon on keeping his contribution short because he did not make the same error as Senator Parer did, which was to go on for about 20 minutes and regurgitate all of the old, hackneyed arguments and really contribute nothing of substance to the debate on these very important airport bills.

PARA.TAB: I would like to recap very quickly on the purpose of these bills because it is important to note that, when it comes to changes in position, it is the opposition that has constantly changed its position in respect of aircraft noise issues and airport issues in Sydney. In fact, they have had more go-arounds and aborted landings than you would probably get from a Qantas jet prior to the construction of the third runway at Sydney.

The airport bills that are currently before the Senate are an integral part of the government's overall strategy with respect to reforming the operations, development and regulation of federal airports throughout Australia. But of course the particular focus in this debate has been on the operations at Kingsford Smith airport and the proposed Sydney West airport, and also with respect to Adelaide airport as a result of the opposition's proposed amendments.

Let me just reiterate—of course it has been so well covered by the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) in introducing the bill and also by Senator Neal in her contribution—that the strategy is to provide for the leasing of major airports throughout Australia in two stages—the first stage being the four major airports of Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane and Perth to be leased in the first phase. That leasing in Sydney will be jointly leased with the new airport at Badgerys Creek, known as Sydney West airport.

The proposal is that the leases be by way of 50-year leases, with the option for a further 49 years. There are specific requirements within the bill that require each lessee to be a company set up to operate the airport and that there be only one company assuming each particular lease. There are, of course, other particular restrictions with respect to ownership and control, namely, a 49 per cent limit on foreign ownership and a five per cent limit on airline ownership. There will be a 15 per cent limit on cross-ownership for Sydney and Sydney West-Melbourne and Sydney and Sydney West-Brisbane airports.

The government's proposals in respect of the leasing of the airports have been carefully thought out, market tested and designed to ensure the maximum return to the taxpayer whilst also ensuring that the Commonwealth ultimately maintains ownership of the airports and, in particular, and most importantly, of course, continuation of Commonwealth regulatory control.

During his contribution, Senator Parer referred to privatisation, and particularly to the government's decision to propose this leasing arrangement for airports. He tried to take a cheap shot at the ALP by suggesting that somehow this was a massive turnaround by the Labor Party on this issue. Of course there is no doubt that in a party like the Australian Labor Party, which represents people right across the length and breadth of the country and not just particular sectional interests, there has been a rigorous debate on the issue of privatisation of government assets. What is important is that we are prepared to change when change becomes necessary, to revisit long held policies of the Labor Party and to take the responsible decisions, sometimes at some political cost. We are prepared to take those responsible decisions when they are in the interests of the country and in the interests of the economy. There is no doubt that this decision is.

As I said, the government's proposals have been carefully developed and market tested. That is important because when you then come to look at the amendments proposed by the opposition you have proposals which will strangle that entire process. We have an opposition that comes into the Senate and into the House and says, `We are in favour of privatisation. In fact, we have been telling you for years that you should privatise, sell off all these government assets.' They propose that with very little regard to all of the things that flow from it, such as the need to maintain regulation. They have had a policy over the years of `flog it all off as quickly as you can'.

They come into the Senate and say that they are in favour of privatisation and support these bills. However, because of base political expediency in the run-up to an election, they want to do a backflip and dissect the legislation. Firstly, they propose that the leasing arrangements for Sydney's Kingsford Smith airport be held up until the east-west runway is reopened.

That is a position that they have come to in recent times. It has really only been over the course of the last few months that that decision was taken by the opposition. They have come to that decision notwithstanding the fact that they have known about the proposals with respect to the development of Sydney West airport, its interrelationship with Kingsford Smith and the government's strategy on leasing federal airports for some time.

It is no accident that the opposition has made this quick decision to tack onto the airport bills a significant constraint that the sale should not go ahead until the east-west runway is reopened. They quite mistakenly think that they can gain some sort of political mileage out of this and that they can save the seat of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) by appealing to the people who are disaffected by aircraft noise. They tried this tactic with respect to the airport curfew bill. It did not work then and I have no doubt that it will not work this time.

The second proposal that they have put up is that Adelaide airport should be included within the first phase. I will deal with the proposal, which once again has been advanced my Senator Parer on behalf of the Leader of the Opposition, the member for Bennelong, to reopen the east-west runway. I have heard Senator Parer speak about this quite often and I have also heard the Leader of the Opposition speak about it. I have read into Hansard their comments about what they said a couple of years ago when they supported the construction of the third runway, the parallel runway.

I have detailed those comments and I do not need to go through them again other than to say that at the time the decision was made to construct the third runway they knew full well that the east-west runway would be closed once the third runway was opened. I will quote two members of the opposition whom I have not referred to in the past. It is very enlightening to read what they said. The Leader of the National Party, Mr Fischer, said on 13 August 1991:

SPEECH.PARA: The federal government must make three decisions: firstly, to accept the expert advice that the third runway is environmentally more friendly than the present two runway set-up; secondly, that safety is of paramount importance; and, finally, the vital tourist industry must no longer be choked off through lack of sensible economic thinking.

It is worth while concentrating on what the Leader of National Party, Tim Fischer, said on that occasion. He said that three decisions should be made. He said the first one was to accept the expert advice. I would suggest that such experts would be Air Services Australia, the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation, the Federal Airports Corporation and air traffic controllers.

PARA.TAB: Tim Fischer also said that the third runway is environmentally more friendly than the present two runway set-up. The option to build the third runway because the present operation at Sydney—namely, the intersecting runway operation—was less environmentally friendly was clearly identified. That system distributed aircraft noise over more residents in Sydney than the parallel runway operation we have now does. Tim Fischer was correct. He recognised that at that time.

Tim Fischer said that safety is of paramount importance. We have had lengthy debates about safety with respect to this issue. It has been said time and time again to remind the opposition that the position of the experts and the position accepted by the government is that parallel runway operations are inherently safer than intersecting operations. I will come back to that point in a moment.

Tim Fischer said that the third decision to be made was that `the vital tourist industry must no longer be choked off through lack of sensible economic thinking'. That is precisely what the opposition's amendment will do. If you excise from the proposal the leasing of Sydney airport and delay it until such time as the east-west runway is reopened, you will strangle the process that is integral to making Sydney West airport operational. This has been made very clear. An essential part of the funding arrangements for the construction of Sydney West airport results from the leasing of Kingsford Smith airport.

The opposition's amendment will destroy or certainly delay for a significant period of time the construction of Sydney West airport. That would have a significant impact on the tourist industry, but it would not be a beneficial impact. It could well have a disastrous impact. The minister announced in the budget that the construction of the two runways at Sydney West airport would be fast-tracked in order to make them operational in time for the 2000 Olympics in Sydney. The opposition is putting in jeopardy that very tight timetable. We cannot afford to have this sort of politicking, this sort of base political expediency, simply to save the member for Bennelong's neck. We cannot afford to have that sort of approach to such an important issue.

The other effect is that the longer you delay, the longer you procrastinate, the longer you fool around with all of the issues relating to the construction of Sydney West airport, which is subject to a most rigorous EIS project, and the longer you subject the residents of Sydney to increased noise, the more pressure you will create with airlines and others seeking changes to such things as curfews at Mascot airport. We will not accept that. The history has been that, whenever the problems are exacerbated at Sydney airport, we immediately get calls for certain other changes to reduce congestion. That is why the construction of Sydney West airport is vital to this process.

The other point that I wish to come back to is this issue of sharing the load, which seems to be at the heart of this proposal by the opposition to put a constraint upon the implementation of the leasing process by deferring the sale of Sydney airport until the east-west runway is opened. As I have said, I have heard Senator Parer and the Leader of the Opposition speak many times on this. But I actually looked at what was said by the first speaker for the opposition when this matter was debated in the other place, and that was Mrs Bishop, the member for Mackellar. On 17 October she said that privatisation, in respect of Kingsford Smith airport, should be delayed—

SPEECH.PARA: until such time as the question of the noise burden over Sydney is dealt with in an equitable and fair manner and there is a resumption of full operation of the east-west runway at that airport.

I think it is incredible that the member for Mackellar would raise that issue and talk about the distribution of noise in a more equitable and fair manner across Sydney, because Mackellar has to be one of the few electorates in Sydney that has very little, if any, aircraft noise and has never had noise.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is compassion.

—This is what is so fascinating about the opposition's position. They want to share the load. They want to distribute it over more electorates in Sydney. They actually have run the disgraceful line of argument that this is some political decision by the minister, the member for Kingsford-Smith, to take the noise away from his electorate. That is not actually correct. There is still noise over parts of Kingsford-Smith. In fact, the airport is in his electorate. But if you look at the electorates in Sydney that are affected—in addition to Bennelong, which is held by the Leader of the Opposition—all the other electorates are Labor electorates. Grayndler has the most intense noise and has always had it. Sydney, Lowe, and even the electorates of Blaxland—which has the Bankstown airport—and Parramatta have experienced increased noise. Of course the other area in Sydney, Kurnell, whilst in a Liberal electorate, has been a solid Labor voting area ever since I can remember.

PARA.TAB: When the member for Mackellar talks about distributing the noise, you never hear it being said, `Let's put some noise over Mackellar or Bradfield or Warringah or Wentworth.' You cannot say that because, using the existing or even a changed configuration of the operation of Sydney airport's runways, you cannot have planes flying over those electorates.

So let us not have any more of this hypocrisy from the opposition about sharing the load. Let us not have any more of this nonsense, this false argument that somehow the current operations have been designed to benefit the Labor Party. It is the Labor electorates that are receiving that noise. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens are not inclined to vote in favour of these airport bills. We do not like the idea of privatising the management of airports in Australia. Australian airports, as represented by Sydney, for instance, which are managed by the Federal Airports Corporation, a public company, have been deemed to be fourth lowest in operating costs and charges in a study of 40 major international airports. The Federal Airport Corporation's productivity is higher than in Europe, and the Federal Airports Corporation is a profitable company.

PARA.TAB: So why do we want to privatise airports? One justification is to eliminate the cross-subsidies the major airports pay to support the smaller regional and general airports. Why is that such a great goal? All that will do is make it harder to support smaller airports. It will shift the cost burden from international and major domestic route fliers to the taxpayer or to regional fliers and private planes if cost recovery avenues are pursued. Why is that such an important goal, especially since the cross-subsidies do not seem to make the major international airports excessively expensive or uncompetitive?

Where are the guarantees that a private operator, in what will in effect become, in the case of Perth, a private monopoly, will operate in the best interests of the consumers? I do not see any indication that, in the history of market operations, private monopolies feel obliged to operate in that way; that is, to decrease charges and make sure the consumers are the beneficiaries of any lower charges. If it is a monopoly, it is certainly not in their interests to do so.

As to the impact on consumers in major airports, what guarantee is there that elimination of cross-subsidies would make things cheaper? In other countries, including those with private airports, this does not seem to be the case. It may be a situation where the private company becomes more competitive because it is able to cream off the profits of government changing cross-subsidy policy. So they will have less costs and they will just pocket the rest.

I would also like to question the basis of productivity gains in terms of passengers per staff member. These are often not productive or beneficial at all from the viewpoint of consumers if it simply means cutting back staff so that they are always busy. Passengers requiring assistance from the Federal Airports Corporation may have to wait longer.

The benefits of privatisation are therefore dubious, except for the companies managing airports. To the government's credit, they seem to recognise that taking responsibility for airports out of the public domain means that public goals and wider considerations not having to do with bottom line figures will no longer be able to be pursued directly—I hope they were once. Accountability is no longer direct.

The alternative is to regulate and specify what the duties, obligations and requirements are for private companies. These fall mainly in the social and environmental sphere. The fact that the government did not always consider these issues and that, if it ignored them, there were no guidelines or regulations to enforce them to act, means that having explicit guidelines may be considered to be a bonus. But it does not change the fact that the ability of the people to pursue broader agendas which include aspects of airport activities has been reduced. I will speak about it later because, if you are incorporating those rules into a lease condition, the communities are concerned that any changes to those planning arrangements that occurred at the time the lease was sold may well not be subject to any stringent guidelines if the community do not know about them.

The cross-ownership or cross-control issues seem to have been resolved reasonably. There have also been attempts, through limits on foreign ownership, to limit the absolute foreign control implied in ownership of over 50 per cent of stock. However, I am not so certain that a simple restriction limiting foreign ownership to 49 per cent limits effective foreign control, or that effective control in this case has been considered or addressed as thoroughly as it has been for cross-control of multiple airports.

The requirements, obligations and regulation of airport ownership seem to be reasonable. Attempts are made to assure minimum environmental standards of both state and Commonwealth will be met on the basis that the airports remain Commonwealth land, so falling under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act as well as falling under state legislation. This is important since some states seem willing to override environmental regulations or requirements in the interests of commerce. The process of establishing the requirements, obligations and regulations seemed much less consultative than we would have liked.

There are also concerns about the ability of the Commonwealth to make exemptions by regulation under clause 132. In questions to government, it also appears that the standard procedure will primarily be for administration of environmental requirements by the Department of Transport rather than the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency.

We do have concerns that community consultation is still seen by government as consultation with relevant state agencies and local government representatives or organisations rather than consultation with the community or community based non-government organisations. In particular, we would like a commitment from government to consult with local government NGOs on airport issues. Often these local environmental bodies are the people with the most expertise on the local environment. They include the naturalists who actually spend time learning about that environment and have some idea of what the local bush or swamp really is in terms of diversity of species, ecological interaction, seasonal significance and importance to migratory species.

I would like to note how little is known about the Australian ecology. In Perth, at Murdoch University—and there are probably more ecologists per square inch at Murdoch University than anywhere else in Western Australia—which includes a small area of bush amidst extensive housing development, a PhD student in zoology recently discovered two new species of lizards in the course of his PhD research. The point to take away is how little we know and how significant remnant ecological islands can be.

These remnant ecological islands are often not conservation reserves, often not intentionally biotic islands. They are often areas where the land use has meant they were difficult to develop or unable to be developed. For example, the old explosives reserve at Woodman's Point in Perth, because it was not regularly burnt over, is now the last example of the Rottnest cypress coastal environment that once was typical of the entire coastal region, the offshore islands and the Swan River foreshore. It only survived because you cannot have fires on explosives reserves. Likewise, the undiscovered lizard species at Murdoch probably only survived because the university had not had the desire or capital to develop its back acreage.

Airports, with their buffer zones to avoid proximity to noise and potentially dangerous runways, are often similar biotic islands. Development of airports may then have great significance to species. Often, the local naturalists are the only ones who will have any real idea of this impact. The generalists of the state EPAs—that is when there are enough people to employ to be staff in EPAs—seldom have this sort of detailed knowledge. It is therefore extremely important to build in a liaison with local groups.

It is also very important to have a direct link with the community. The voice of the community is increasingly being represented by—in terms of federal government communication—local government associations. The process is far from universal and far from reaching the stage where talking to a local council—that is if it gets to the local council—can be taken as the equivalent of talking to the local people. In Western Australia—and it might be the case in other states—the federal government only talks to the local government associations. Therefore, the communication is very indirect. So when we are told that Belmont council, Guildford council and so on have been advised, it has only been through the local government associations. That means the communication has been very indirect and not satisfactory, according to those councils.

In such a circumstance, it is important to have a mechanism for direct consultation to discover and address the real concerns of the people affected. I can just imagine, if it were a change affecting a particular industry, how the industry would feel if you said, `Oh, we're only going to talk to the Chamber of Commerce and Industry and not actually talk to the industries concerned.' This is the kind of thing that has been happening in these cases.

Even when there are circumstances where the federal government does finally talk to local councils, there are a number of councils which, I am sorry to say, are not used to making their decisions open. They are actually used to keeping decisions close to themselves. It is only when the community forces them to open up those decisions that they have some sort of process, if at all. So we have to deal with the fact that in many cases we are responding to the community, as in Sydney, but there are lots of places around Australia which may well be affected by these changes to the Federal Airports Corporation airports which do not even know what the implications are because their councils have not seen fit to talk to them. You might say that is a problem for the councils; I think it is a problem for the government. It means you are not yet aware of what a full consultation process is with those people who have a stake in the outcome.

We would like to see the government go from a pseudo consultative model, where selected bodies are asked and then government does what it thinks best, to a more participatory model, one in which efforts are made to identify those affected and in which the groups consulted have some direct control in the decisions that are made, the way they will be implemented, and also have some ability to review the decisions and implementation, and change them if change is required. This might seem strange, outrageous and revolutionary, but if what you are talking about is a massive change in Australia in terms of competition policy, for want of a better phrase, you have to start thinking about what the real processes are and use that community network to find out what the real impacts may be of these decisions. Otherwise, you will go too far, too fast and it will be too late to change.

To sum up, we think the government has made an effort to set a regulatory framework for privatisation of airport management. We congratulate them for attempting the effort, while feeling that they could have done more. However, this effort is predicated on the fact that regulation is required because the airports will be leased. It sets the regulation as lease conditions but community participation requires notification and plans can change. If what is required is that those private bodies are required to present their plans to the community, there is not necessarily anything in here to the effect that if they change their plans they once again have to present that to the community for community participation.

It sounds like it is not required, but how will the community ever challenge the level of environmental assessment if they do not know that something is happening? It might be that government, CEPA or whoever, in their wisdom or otherwise, decide that such a thing is not going to have great environmental significance. They might not be aware of the significance. It might be Aboriginal heritage, it might be environment, it might be community noise, inconvenience or safety. If the community have not had to be alerted to the nature of changes as they occur, the accountability enforcement may simply become a private matter between a private business enterprise and the Commonwealth government. Okay, you trust the government; however, there needs to be some realistic mechanism by which the community can feel confident that their level of community participation is a real one and that there is some requirement that major changes—even sometimes what might be considered by the Commonwealth to be minor changes—are advised. People must have a right to ask for an assessment and, as is often the case in environmental assessment, to challenge the level of assessment if it appears to be inappropriately low.

All in all, we reject the current proposal to lease airports. We reject the way it has been rushed through. We reject the fact that the only groups that seem to have participated are the ones already affected by bad planning. Therefore, you are missing the opportunity to do things better by having a better process. We will be voting against the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is currently debating legislation that will provide for the leasing of all Australian airports. That follows the government's announcement as part of the 1994-95 federal budget that it would proceed with this privatisation program during this year. They are quite determined to do it. The Australian Democrats will not be supporting this legislation.

PARA.TAB: Few pieces of government legislation have generated so much mail to my office as this one has. Virtually all the representations which my office has received on this issue have been from Sydney residents pleading with the Democrats to reject the legislation and criticising the federal government for totally ignoring community concerns about what the legislation will lead to. We believe those concerns are well founded. Residents near airports, and especially those in Sydney, have every reason to fear what privatisation will lead to. There is no doubt that for many of them a privatised Kingsford Smith will only exacerbate their problems.

When the Senate Select Committee on Aircraft Noise was established, the Democrats ensured that the privatisation option was included for close examination within the committee's terms of reference. When the Democrats suggested to the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton), quite reasonably, I thought, that he consider delaying the introduction of the legislation until the committee had the opportunity to report its findings on privatisation to this parliament, this suggestion was rejected out of hand.

In fact, during the debate on the Airports Levy Bill earlier this year, senators will recall the fact that the Senate passed a second reading amendment to the bill urging the government to delay the introduction of this legislation that we are dealing with today until the committee had reported. The opposition supported that amendment at the time but we now find they have changed their mind and they are of the opinion that the legislation should be treated as a priority.

At no stage has either the government or the opposition explained why they believe this legislation is so important that it should be given such a high priority over other legislation currently on the Notice Paper. For that matter, neither has explained why it is that this legislation is so important that the parliament cannot await the findings of the Senate select committee which is due to report shortly on this issue.

This legislation represents another sorry chapter in the government's disgraceful program of selling off everything and anything which once belonged to the people of Australia. At times, it is extremely hard to believe that a Labor government has been in power during the last 13 years. The government's program of privatisation and sell-off has been carried out so comprehensively and with such speed that a conservative coalition government could scarcely have carried out a similar program with such vigour.

No one is misled by the government's usage of the euphemism `leasing of airports', as is used in this legislation—certainly not the hundreds of people who have written to me or who have phoned my office outraged that the government is embarking on this privatisation program of Australia's airports. The fact is that leasing for a period of 99 years, as set out in the terms outlined in this bill, effectively means forever. It effectively means selling off. Unfortunately, this now means that a future Australian government will have no aviation policy options on this matter and will be forced to make decisions within the confines of this legislation regardless of what it might consider is in Australia's best interests into the future or even the local public interests of specific airport sites around the country.

A government that sets such a framework in concrete for years to come will undoubtedly be judged harshly by future generations. None of us can predict the future with any certainty but what we do already know is that privatised airports will undoubtedly choose to resolve problems, such as the ones currently being played out at Kingsford-Smith, on the basis of the private interests of a few and not what is in the overall public interest.

The problems that we currently have at Sydney are likely to be replicated elsewhere in Australia. That could include Melbourne, Brisbane, Perth and many of the regional airports as decisions are made on the basis of short-term private interests. This has enormous implications for things such as volume of air traffic around Australia, flight paths to be used and whether a curfew is set in place. The list is endless. As the volume of air traffic grows and more space is required, there will continue to be a conflict between the interests of surrounding residents and how best to operate any airport.

When an airport is privatised, it is inevitable that the interests of the private operator will overrule the public interest every single time. The government may well respond that there will be regulations in place to provide some form of protection but, as we all know, how much difference has the government's regulatory regime made to the communications area in this country? The reality is that just as private interests in that field reign supreme behind a veneer of government regulation, so too will private interests dominate in airport policy. Indeed, many of the problems now being experienced at Kingsford Smith airport are the result of successive governments—Labor and Liberal—allowing private interests to dominate, and hence compromise, government policy in the development of Sydney airport.

The third runway saga, for instance, was primarily about both major parties giving into the demands of private air operators. Worst of all, the government abandoned all its existing environmental impact assessment regulations to fast-track the construction of the third runway and then proceeded to gloat about how it would finish construction ahead of time. This point has been made before by the Democrats in debates on Sydney airport. It probably needs to be made again here. If more attention had been paid to due process and if the proper environmental safeguards had been adhered to, many of those problems which we are now experiencing at Sydney could have been foreseen and could ultimately have been prevented.

Unfortunately, this bill marks a continuation of the pattern already set in place by this government. The minister's office boasts that they have had numerous discussions with potential private investors for Australia's airports. Public consultation does not appear to have been as high on the agenda. The reality is, of course, that hardly any of the relevant community groups have been consulted on what they consider to be the adverse impact that will flow from the passage of this legislation. Important community representative groups such as the Australian Mayoral Aviation Council and the Local Government and Shires Association of New South Wales have written to the Democrats in recent weeks expressing profound disappointment with this legislation and with the government's complete lack of interest in consulting with affected groups. Frankly, this is totally unacceptable on the part of the government.

Ultimately, there is nothing in this legislation to assure Sydney residents that the problems at Kingsford Smith will not get worse under a privatised regime. There is an expectation in Sydney that if the Sydney West airport ever comes on line, it will take over from Kingsford Smith as the main international and domestic airport for Sydney. Understandably, many residents fear that when KSA is privatised, there will be absolutely no incentive at all to have the site at Sydney West fully developed as Sydney's main point of entry for air traffic. Equally, people who live at Badgerys Creek near the site of Sydney West are also worried about what conditions will be like for them under privatised or, indeed, not privatised, conditions.

One of the significant deficiencies in the Airports (Transitional) Bill is the failure to require the Federal Airports Corporation to conduct either an environmental impact statement on its activities or require the FAC to conduct an environmental audit of assets and liabilities. This is remarkable given that these days it is standard practice for organisations the size of the Federal Airports Corporation to be subject to environmental audits.

The Democrats believe that given the size of the amount involved in the whole privatisation program, such an audit should be mandatory. In the case of Sydney airport, for instance, an environmental audit would also highlight the liabilities of Kingsford-Smith, in particular to potential litigation over airport and air traffic management, noise pollution, carcinogenic effects of aircraft activities and toxic contaminants as well as other forms of pollution in and around the vicinity of the airport. It is worth while noting that no Commonwealth legislation exists to deal with the hazardous wastes or pollution and, thus, it is likely that in this case New South Wales legislation would apply.

Given that under the legislation an environmental master plan is required to be developed for each airport site, it would seem appropriate that prior to the sale or lease an environmental investigation should be carried out. Under the Environmental Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act an activity of this scale should undoubtedly require an environmental impact statement. The requirement for environmental management and environmental assessment cannot be understated. The Democrats fear that under the legislation the need for such environmental safeguards have been substantially overlooked.

The Democrats are also concerned that these bills provide for significant controls, both environmental and corporate, to be included by way of regulation. There is considerable discretionary power vested in the minister. This makes a mockery of any public consultation process when it is possible to override or totally ignore for all practical purposes any public comment. The use of delegated legislation in this way to control environmental activities and to regulate and protect the environment runs against the trend of an open, transparent and public decision making process.

Likewise, there is no provision in the legislation for any decision maker to determine which factors must be considered paramount. It is usual to provide a hierarchy of goals to enable decision makers to assess in an objective manner specific criteria. For example, there is no guidance as to whether commercial, environmental or social objectives take priority, but I bet I can guess which one always would. Inevitably, this will lead to confusion as to exactly how decisions are to be made under this legislation. The Democrats believe that the legislation should mandate that the minimisation of noise impacts is a primary consideration and should outweigh commercial interests. The absence of such safeguards represents a significant oversight.

Another significant oversight in this legislation is that it does not make it clear that state laws have a role in the operation of Australia's airports. It has previously been demonstrated that while the courts believe that the Commonwealth has covered the field in environmental legislation, in practice, that is not the case. The Democrats believe that it is entirely inappropriate to legislate in a way so as to enable a commercial operator to ignore environmental considerations that are applicable to all other corporate enterprises. If competition is deemed desirable, it must be competition which is carried out on an equal basis.

The reality is that these bills are substantially flawed. The Democrats will not, however, be moving any amendments to the legislation because, frankly, what we have before us is an absurd situation. The government knows that this legislation will effectively be gutted by the amendments proposed by the opposition. Those amendments will render the legislation next to useless. I have no idea why they are so determined to proceed with the bills under these circumstances.

At the same time, the opposition's amendments are nothing short of remarkable, given their history of support for privatisation generally over the years. In their case they need to spell out fairly clearly what their intentions would be on privatising Australia's airports and, in particular, Kingsford-Smith, if they happen to win the next election. Given the opposition's history of support for privatisation over the years, it is perhaps not surprising that many Sydney residents concerned about the future of Kingsford-Smith are somewhat surprised by the opposition's proposed amendments. As I said during the recent debate on the Sydney Airport Curfew Bill, the electorate is not stupid.
