TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The airports bills implement the decision of this Labor government to have a Clayton's sell-off of federal airports. It is a sell-off you are having when you are not having a sell-off because, instead of selling the airports outright, we are selling the right to run airports for 50 years. I wonder what we might expect to happen in 50 years time, if we are around then.

PARA.TAB: This sell-off will be done in two stages, with the four major airports—Sydney, Melbourne Brisbane and Perth—leased in the first phase, a phase in which Sydney will be jointly leased with the new airport at Badgerys Creek, Sydney West airport. The government's intention is for the first stage to be completed by the end of 1996, with the second stage involving the remaining FAC airports taking place throughout 1997-98.

The bill provides several principles underlying the leasing process. These principles provide that airports must be majority owned. We have been promised that before. I have now been around long enough to know what happened when we had the Aussat debate. I know what happens when you say this in principle. You then say, for example, `Oh, gosh. We couldn't actually achieve that, so we'll have to sell it down a bit more than we thought.'

I have been here only five years and I have seen that happen, so do not ask me to take your word again on this one. The only proviso would be that we may have greater institutional shareholdings now and we may have more savings with which to invest, but tell me how the culture has changed so much that Australians want to invest in Australia to this degree. The second underlying principle states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the government will seek diversity of ownership to the maximum extent possible;
Yeah, well, I am watching. The third one states:
. . . the government will encourage transparency and benchmark competition between the airports;
I will come to that in a moment. Other principles are:
. . . as a minimum, there will be the separate ownership of Sydney, including Sydney West, from Melbourne and Brisbane airports;

PARA.TAB: ownership of the airports by individual airlines and associated interests will be restricted to five per cent;
the Commonwealth will retain responsibility for land use, planning and building controls at the major airport;
the Commonwealth will retain reserve powers to deal with demand management issues that may arise during the 50-year leases.

SPEECH.PARA: The Airports Bill sets out the details of the post-leasing regulatory arrangements to apply to the airports. Of course, we will all watch with great interest the work of the regulator because we know that the competition that is supposed to follow will be directly related to how well the regulator works.

PARA.TAB: I return to the fundamental question: why is the privatisation of airports deemed okay by this government and this opposition? Virtually all major airports overseas have traditionally been publicly owned and operated. That is a fact, and Australians should be asking why we are deviating from this. The government has tried to dress up its decision to sell airport leases as a major micro-economic reform, but we know it is not. We know what it is about. It is about raising some quick dough by a government that wants to carry on with this psychology of a surplus.

I suspect, though, that we may end up selling our airports for a price a lot less than the net present value of retaining them—a concern echoed by public finance expert Professor Bob Walker and by FAC managing director, Bill Swingler. Last year, Mr Swingler predicted that the sale could raise as little as $1.5 billion—$1.2 billion less than that predicted at the time by Treasury. This would follow the less than expected return on the Qantas sale—a sale regarded as of almost fire sale proportions by former Qantas chief Jim Leslie.

The Australian Democrats would argue that little, if any, micro-economic benefit will flow from the new airports regulatory regime. We are told that competition will force down airport usage prices. Senator Cook, I know you still maintain that line, but we were told that a decade ago about banks too. I doubt it greatly.

Let us think about the rhetoric here because the reality in the case of airports is that the scope for competition between Sydney and Melbourne airports or between Sydney and Perth airports is very remote. Not just is disaggregation against the world best practice of keeping airports together in a network; it is against the advice of the FAC. Mr Swingler scoffed at the competition argument, arguing that there is no competition between airports because people fly to destinations because of location attractions—not just the airport. That is just plain obvious, particularly in Australia.

The merit of breaking up the very profitable FAC into a string of single airport companies is not immediately evident. The FAC and many industry observers are not convinced. Community and industry leaders in regional Australia are absolutely horrified. Airports by their very nature have a monopoly aspect to them. The only place where there was the potential for competition was between Kingsford Smith and Sydney West, but the government wants to sell them as a package.

As a monopoly, the consumer benefits of the private sector running airports are only as good as the regulator overseeing them. We need to ask some fundamental questions, beginning with: are our airports now inefficient and will the private sector run them so much better that the regulators might be able to force them to deliver lower costs? The Democrats think that the answer is no.

The FAC is a very profitable GBE. This year it recorded a record profit of $128 million, Sydney airport recording $69 million; Melbourne, $52.3 million; and Brisbane, $43.5 million. By the standards of the Stock Exchange, its earnings over assets ratio is up there among the top three or four firms, ahead of the Big Australian, BHP, and ahead of News Corporation. Its productivity, measured by the passenger per employee ratio, increased by 14 per cent in 1994-95 following the 15 per cent improvement the previous year. Its fees are the fourth lowest of a world representative listing of 40 major airports, with increases kept below the CPI over the past five years. So the FAC is doing a pretty good job. Who should benefit from that? Mr Swingler asked the question last year: if an organisation is achieving the shareholders' objectives, why sell it? Australians, as shareholders, are entitled to still ask that question.

Why indeed sell it? Not just are airports a natural monopoly being run fairly efficiently in the public sector; airports are by their nature incredibly influential on the quality of life of nearby communities. Communities should be entitled to express their views on demand management at airports—on curfews, on usage, on tourism promotion, on the balance between general aviation and commercial aviation, and so on. The running of an airport every day requires a long string of decisions made in the public interest. It is impossible to divorce the commercial aspect of running an airport from the public policy aspect. For more than almost any other utility, the Democrats believe this is the case. In short, there is a good, long list of reasons why airports should stay in public hands and few good reasons why they should be in private sector hands.

Despite the privatisation wave across the world, virtually no country outside the lunacy of Margaret Thatcher's Britain has sold its airports because other governments throughout the world realise that to do so is to get rid of a utility that is too vital to a community, to its commerce, to its quality of life and to its environment to be trusted to private sector hands. That is not to disparage the private sector but that is to point out a few obvious things. There are no market forces to constrain the private sector on airports. Competition will be at the margins only.

In this place we have a difficult enough time getting publicly owned companies to stay accountable to their consumers. I remember, Senator Cook, the AIDC CEO salary level debate we had in here recently where you said, `Oh, we can't do anything about it even though we are the major shareholder.' The chance of a privately owned company—one where the major shareholder is not the government but, more than likely, an overseas investor—having accountability to the Australian people as its primary objective is practically zilch.

Whenever we have given up public ownership in this country, we have given up a whole range of accountability processes—a point made by the Commonwealth Ombudsman, Phillipa Smith, in her recent annual report. It becomes much harder for the public interest to get a look in when the company is run solely for the private interests of the shareholders.

I heard people talking about how ideas change with the times, as if to say all privatisation is a good thing. We should assess privatisation on a case by case basis. In doing so, we should be seeking to determine whether, in all the circumstances, it is of economic benefit and of community benefit for the asset to pass from public to private ownership.

On airports, we can unambiguously state that the benefits of this bill to the community at large will be negligible. The big beneficiary of this decision is the government, desperate to raise fast cash in this way and wanting to avoid the harder task of engaging in public dialogue to decide what is the best and fairest way to raise revenue for the kind of expenditure that is needed to maintain a decent level of services in this country in future.

Senator Bourne dealt with the issue of this bill and its impact on Sydney airport. I wish to note only in passing that more noise from Sydney airport will be an inevitable consequence of this bill. I hope I am wrong, but there are some pretty compelling realities we cannot ignore, such as: how will airport lessees increase their profits? They have two main ways: cutting costs or increasing airport usage.

At Sydney airport, where the number of movements is regulated, the lessees will seek to increase revenue, in my view, by reducing the number of smaller, low fee-paying aircraft using the facility and increasing the number of high fee-paying jet movements. Operators such as Hazelton have expressed concern that they may be squeezed out by such movements.

The government will say the regulator might try to restrict such occurrences. In the absence of tough initial legislation, in the Democrats' view, such attempts are doomed to be unsuccessful. The government has already shown a strong reluctance to make this legislation as tough as it ought to be. To do so, they fear, will reduce the ultimate sale price. And we would not want to do that. We would not want to put the community impact first.

The passage of this bill will mean that pressure to land bigger, louder planes more often at Australia's airports will increase dramatically. In dealing with a private sector company which bought a lease on the understanding that it could increase its revenue in this way, the public will have less control of the skies above their heads than ever before. That is the human and community aspect of this bill.

All we have heard, in the main, from the government and the opposition are the old buzz words `micro-economic reform' and `economic impact'. We should learn from the third runway debates in this country that the legislation has demonstrated that community impact is just as important as financial impact dressed up as micro-economic reform.
This is a bad time to be asking the Senate to vote for this bill. I urge senators to vote against it, on economic grounds, on public policy grounds and on environmental grounds.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to debate this government's failure to effectively address the problem of youth suicide in this country. The Keating government is showing a callous disregard for mental health and the social crisis as a result that is facing this nation. This is the other disgrace of the Minister for Human Services and Health, Dr Lawrence—a disgrace that relates fairly and squarely to her responsibilities as minister for health in this country.

PARA.TAB: This minister has set back progress on addressing the problem of youth suicide by years. The allocation of $12.9 million over four years is inadequate by any measure. The sum total of this government's initiatives in the past year is absolutely pathetic. They have announced the expenditure of the money twice. They have sacked one advisory committee dealing with suicide prevention and replaced it with another. That is some record in the last year! All of this mismanagement has occurred while the nation faces economic loss and people face great personal pain because of the very high rate of suicide, particularly youth suicide, in Australia.

The response to this crisis by Minister Lawrence and the Keating government is an absolute disgrace. The cold statistics of suicide in Australia scream out for robust action. The problem has been documented by the minister's own department of human services in a paper called Youth suicide in Australia: a background monograph 1995. This paper indicates that Australia is recording one of the highest rates of suicide in the world. The youth suicide rate has doubled under this government in the last 10 years. We now rank in the three highest rates of youth suicide in the industrialised world.

World Health Organisation figures show Australia in 1993 as having the fourth highest rate, on a list of 14 countries, for youth suicide deaths among young males between the ages of 15 and 24. Some estimates place suicides in Australia at 3,000 a year. It is a more common death for young Australians between the ages of 15 and 24 than road accidents. There is said to be, according to the minister's own department, 30 to 40 suicide attempts for every actual suicide amongst young people. That is around 100,000 attempts per annum. One hundred thousand young people in Australia try to take their lives every year. Young males living in rural and remote areas of Australia have a consistently higher rate than the rest.

Yet what is the government's response to this? The response is $12.9 million over four years on suicide prevention. Compare this with the $800,000 bill—and still rising—for the legal fees on a private matter for the health minister, Dr Carmen Lawrence, that has absolutely no connection with her ministerial duties. I think the comparison of those two figures puts into some perspective the priorities of this Keating government. Self-interest is obviously reigning supreme in the Keating government.

The Lawrence blueprint for kerbing this unacceptably high rate of youth suicide is full of holes. It is a deceptive and incompetent approach. Minister Crowley, representing Dr Lawrence in this chamber, outlined these inadequate policies in full detail. Let us examine what information Senator Crowley provided the Senate on 25 October this year on behalf of Minister Lawrence. We are told that the youth suicide prevention initiative was going to cost $12.9 million, the initiative commenced at the beginning of the current financial year and the money is to be spent over four years. This financial year $1.3 million will be spent. What a pathetic figure for the scale of this problem.

If you look more closely at the detail, you can see that the Keating government and Minister Lawrence are peddling a dishonest and ineffective policy. Of the $12.9 million trumpeted by Dr Lawrence only $1.3 million will be spent initiating several projects in this 1995-96 financial year. We are told that the projects are national demonstration projects that will be thoroughly evaluated before dissemination across Australia. We should have best practice models for suicide prevention in place now ready for implementation. This government have been in power for 13 years, yet they are setting up demonstration projects in this major area of social concern in Australia. This crisis will continue on and lives will be lost while the government just tends to dally with these sorts of activities that are greatly delaying what should be an effective range of strategies.

Let us have a look at the statement, and I refer the Senate particularly to the following aspects. The statement says that there will be support for general practitioners and community health personnel to identify, refer and treat young people at risk of suicide and that this project is currently proceeding to tender and will be advertised in November—a pilot project that still has not even got off the ground. This pattern is repeated throughout the minister's statement. Let us deal with another one. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: An initiative in rural areas to prevent and respond to suicide. The tender . . . will be advertised in December of this year.
What is the detail? Why the delay in getting started? It also says:
Development and demonstration of hospital and health service protocols . . . tenders for implementation will be advertised in . . . April 1996.

It goes on to deal with intervention programs for persons with suicide tendencies and says that this project will be advertised for tender in 1996. This statement tells us that there is planning for a youth suicide strategy, but it has been greatly delayed under this minister. We have the worst suicide rate in the world, and after 13 years the government is still considering its strategy.

PARA.TAB: The Senate should condemn this minister, Dr Lawrence, for failing to note the contents of the NHMRC expert group report drafted in October 1994. Professor Peter Baume and a panel of specialists in the field of suicide prevention drafted this report and the minister at that point just ignored its contents. Lawrence said that the NHMRC dissolved the committee, and she ignored their recommendations. Valuable and precious time was lost between that point and now, when they are calling for tenders of particular projects. How many lives have been lost during that time and how many families have been devastated by the effects of youth suicide in Australia while this government dallies?

Now the government has formed another youth suicide prevention group. It has been formed to inquire and bring down another report. What will be its fate? Will it suffer the same fate as the Baume committee? This minister has now set up two committees and announced the same allocation of money twice. Her record on this is appalling. Her plan for the future is too little too late. Suicide is costing us, in money terms, $100 million a year, but the personal misery is incalculable. Lawrence has failed the people of Australia by her incompetent handling of this major health crisis.
