We are very concerned—
at QUT, because—

We have never had any reports of gambling problems before the new casino opened. There were certainly opportunities previously to gamble at the TAB and with the introduction of poker machines in clubs and pubs.

PARA.TAB: But now we are getting significant numbers. We are monitoring the situation very carefully.

SPEECH.PARA: He goes on to describe the problems that the QUT has uncovered with its students because of the new casino which opened just a couple of blocks away from the university. I do not want to take up the time of the Senate this evening but I do intend on another occasion to place on the record the research that has been done and the concerns that have been raised.

PARA.TAB: I conclude by saying that this is an issue which cannot be swept under the carpet. It is an issue which governments ought to take seriously. As Australians, we ought to be ashamed of allowing such institutions to proliferate in our society while not admitting that there are problems associated with them and, certainly, in no way using sufficient of the funds generated to assist those for whom the abuse of gambling has become a real problem.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I have been informed that Senator Coulter is retiring from the Senate and I want to say a few words on this occasion. In particular, I want to congratulate him on his contribution to public life through the Australian Senate.

PARA.TAB: I know that Senator Coulter made a very considerable contribution to public life before he got here. Nevertheless, my relationship with him has been through this forum and I wish to put on record my acknowledgment of the work he has done, the commitment he has demonstrated to the Senate, and his commitment to the Australian public generally. On behalf of coalition senators, I want to wish him well for the future. I am sorry that some health difficulties have brought on a decision to retire early from this place. I trust that he will quickly recover his health and continue to pursue the causes that he has pursued so passionately through the Australian parliament.

I guess that is the aspect of Senator Coulter that most of us will remember first—his commitment to his causes, his passionate and dedicated and determined commitment to pursuing issues that he has always regarded as so important.

I guess highest on that list, from the point of view of someone who has observed him, have been issues relating to the environment. He clearly has sought to carve out that niche for his party, the Australian Democrats, and has been recognised both within the parliament and out of the parliament as a leader for the environmental cause.

Also, I want to particularly mention tonight, with appreciation, the contribution that he has made to lifting the profile of science and recognising the role of scientists in our community. That is a contribution by science not only to economic benefit but to the broader quality of life issues. Science and scientists do not have many advocates within this place, unfortunately.

Senator Coulter has marked out his ground as somebody who has been continually prepared to demonstrate the vital role of science to the benefit of all society. I am sure that all Australian scientists—particularly some within the CSIRO for whom he fought with great determination—will be sorry to see him leaving the parliament.

Obviously, I had dealings with Senator Coulter at the time he was Leader of the Australian Democrats. At all times he treated me in a principled way and with great courtesy. Therefore, from my perspective, he was always easy to deal with.

On behalf of my colleagues, Senator Coulter, I can say that we are sorry that you are retiring at this time. You obviously still have a great capacity to contribute more to public life. I am sure that outside this place you will continue to do it just as effectively as you have been able to do it here. We recognise and appreciate the work you have done through the parliament and we wish you well in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight the Democrats are farewelling our most notable and certainly longest serving environment spokesperson. John Coulter is known throughout Australia and indeed in worldwide circles for his incredible dedication and passion on a wide range of environmental issues. His work on the environment went on well before he came into this place. Although we are farewelling John here tonight, I am sure that the environment movement has not heard the last of him and that he will continue that work in the community.

PARA.TAB: In the short time available to me tonight, I will give only a brief potted history of some of the things that John has done and some of the issues on which he has campaigned very heavily since he came into this place in 1987. A well known area to which he has committed an enormous amount of time and energy is that of preserving what little remains of our old growth forests—forests of enormous environmental significance; forests that are still under threat, as this very week this government is making further decisions that will impact on what little remains of those incredibly valuable forest areas of great scenic beauty.

John has been commenting about this issue since he first came into this place. He has called time and again for the development of an ecologically sustainable management strategy for our forests and for the forest product industry. He has called on the government time and again to remove barriers to investing in plantations and to retain and expand the tax exempt status for recycled paper products. He has called on the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories ((Senator Faulkner) to enforce the national forest policy statement's moratorium clause. Indeed, we are still waiting for that, as that clause has not been enforced.

John has forced the government to admit that there was no conclusive research showing that natural regeneration was a viable method of achieving sustainability for tree fern harvesting in our native forests. In January 1994 John stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Most Australians want to see old growth and wilderness forests protected—now, before it is too late. The Federal Government must take genuine and effective action to protect forests such as the Karri and Jarrah forests of south west Western Australia, the Great Western Tiers and the Tarkine in Tasmania, along with the Errinundra Plateau in Victoria's East Gippsland.

John has called for the government's consultation process on old growth forests to be upgraded. He has highlighted it as being totally inadequate and has said that it is impossible to reconcile the various interests if we do not take notice of the scientific evidence that is before us and only listen to the states.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats have called for the urgent development of a comprehensive national reserve program. John has been at the forefront of trying to establish this and ensuring that that it is based on a scientific assessment of the range and types of areas which need to be protected. In 1993 John reaffirmed the Democrats' support for an independent role for the Australian Heritage Commission. He called on the government to redefine its forestry policy and the role of the Australian Heritage Commission. He also called on the federal government to follow its own national forest policy and act to ensure areas of high conservation value were protected from logging while the national reserve system was being established. Last year he called on the government to stop logging the Huon and Picton valleys, which was further degrading world heritage areas. Shoalwater Bay has been another area on which John has spent a lot of time and energy. The day before the final report was released by the commission, John—with Peter Garrett—presented a documentary on Shoalwater Bay to a media conference in Canberra after an extensive visit of that area.

Looking through the records of all that John has said and done regarding the Great Barrier Reef, I cannot do justice to him in the few minutes available to me tonight. However, I will briefly detail some of John's achievements.

He has warned that an oil spill disaster on the Great Barrier Reef was only a matter of time and called for greater regulation, including mandatory double hulls, of oil tankers in Australian waters. He has welcomed funding for the management of the Great Barrier Reef world heritage area via a commercial operator levy. He has raised questions about the role of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority in the failed Magnetic Quays development on Magnetic Island.

John called for greater scrutiny of development applications in sensitive marine and coastal environments. He highlighted the impact of fishing, tourism, coastal development, mariculture, agriculture and other activities in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park and urged the federal government time and time again to maintain its responsibility to the marine and coastal environments.

John raised concerns about maritime safety on the Great Barrier Reef again this year. In March he successfully moved amendments to enshrine the precautionary principle in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act. John said at that time:

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments mean the onus of proof for ensuring the reef is free from environmental harm now lies with developers and others seeking to exploit the reef area.

On the Daintree, John welcomed the launch of the Daintree rescue campaign and called for a well funded government package to protect the Daintree rainforest. But he also noted with concern the Queensland government's failure to provide matching funding for the Daintree rescue package in its state budget last year, and he criticised the federal government for making the rescue package contingent upon funds from the state, calling it a haphazard approach to the environment.

PARA.TAB: Water quality and water usage issues have been high on John's agenda. He has continually criticised the federal government for its failure to honour its promises to actually do something to clean up the Murray-Darling river system. He pointed out that research demonstrated that timber harvesting in eucalypt forests can reduce water production from those forests by as much as 50 per cent. He asked whether Commonwealth government approval of export woodchip licences was in breach of section 100 of the Australian constitution, which covers actions by the Commonwealth which impact upon water production.

On the United Nations World Day for Water last year, John called on the government to get serious about water pollution problems in Australia and to fund a national urban stormwater and sewerage program. He drew attention to the reports by the Sydney Water Board detailing the pollution of rivers, estuaries, harbours and oceans in that state from sewage and stormwater run-off.

I will very briefly mention a range of other issues that John has been involved in. In 1993 he called for a moratorium on sandmining and for an inquiry by the Resource Assessment Commission into the mineral sands industry. Again in 1993 and on through 1994, he condemned the government for letting Australia become the only country in the world to seek an exemption to the London dumping convention to allow us to continue to dump industrial waste in the ocean. He reiterated his call in March of this year for the purchase of Canadian Air CL215 aircraft to assist in the protection and surveillance of shipping along the Great Barrier Reef.
John is best known nationally and indeed internationally for his strong stand on nuclear issues, including his passionate opposition to the mining of uranium. In May 1988, John said:

SPEECH.PARA: No reliance can be placed on safeguards whatsoever. The process is a lie behind which the civil and military nuclear programs are established and maintained.

In 1992 John warned of a recent Swedish analysis which concluded that all RMBK nuclear reactors would be susceptible to a Chernobyl type explosion. He said that Australia could be a target for nuclear fallout should Indonesia build a nuclear reactor. He pointed out that, if we were exporting uranium to Indonesia, the fallout could well be of Australian origin.

PARA.TAB: In 1993 he introduced the Nuclear Power, Uranium Enrichment and Reprocessing (Prohibition) Bill to prohibit activities in relation to nuclear power production, uranium enrichment and reprocessing. John has continually reaffirmed the Democrats' opposition to uranium mining and to other parts of the nuclear cycle, and earlier this year he introduced a bill to prohibit the export of uranium to France while it continued to conduct its nuclear tests in the Pacific.

I cannot finish without mentioning John's work on endangered species and biodiversity but, with my time running out, perhaps all I can say is that John's work inside and outside parliament on both these issues is well known. I am sure it will continue in that way after he leaves this place. I just want to say in closing that we certainly will miss John's contribution in this place, not just in relation to environmental issues, as Senator Hill pointed out, but in so many other ways—particularly on the science issue and keeping that on the agenda.

We congratulate John for all he has done and all he has achieved. We wish him well in his retirement and hope that he recovers very quickly. We look forward to his continuing involvement as we move on to fight all the issues that I have mentioned and many others. The continuing battle will, I hope, still include his name time and time again. We wish him well in his retirement.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by apologising to Senator Coulter for not being present in the chamber to open this debate, as I would very much have liked to be. For once in their lives, the opposition were not nearly as longwinded in the opening adjournment speeches as I had been led to believe they would be.

PARA.TAB: This is the last appearance in this place of Senator Coulter. I suppose it is typical of the man and his interests that he should use his very last opportunity in question time today, in the aftermath of the triumph of APEC, to put a question without notice to me asking me whether the expected $3 billion worth of increased farm exports to Australia arising from the anticipated agreements are going to be ecologically sustainable and whether any consideration has been given to increased greenhouse gas emissions arising as a result of the increased trade in bulk goods.

Good taste forbade me from talking about the way in which at least some of those emission problems might be reduced by having nuclear vessels transporting the bulk goods in question and good taste inhibits me from further dwelling upon that theme tonight and similar themes about the actual conceivable value to Australia of increased trade and economic activity of this kind. But it has been typical of Senator Coulter here. We have had our differences at question time. I cannot think of anything very much on which we have agreed but, nonetheless, it has been quite enjoyable sparring over the eight years of his presence here. He has made a unique contribution to this place which I do believe deserves recognition and respect on an occasion such as this.

We are all products of our background and our experience. So long as I am not running the risk of this being taken as a condolence motion rather than a valedictory, I would like to say a little about John Coulter's background because it is very much a part of understanding the man that he is and the senator that he has been. He was born in Perth in 1930, attending the Nedlands Primary School, Wesley College and then the University of WA and the University of Adelaide, from which he graduated in medicine. After undertaking his medical residency at the Royal Adelaide Hospital and spending a short period in private practice, he became a medical resident at the Institute of Medical and Veterinary Science in Adelaide.

It was during his subsequent career of over 20 years as a medical researcher that Dr Coulter really did make a significant and pioneering contribution on matters which he has pursued in this place with great vigour, in particular the dangers to humans of agricultural chemicals. It is well known that his commitment to speaking out on this issue—a matter about which he did feel then and continues to do today so strongly—in effect inhibited his advancement and, maybe, even put an end to his career with that institute.

At the same time a whole variety of his interests outside that work environment did reflect themselves in the issues that he took up and made contributions to advancing. His interest in yachting and diving led him into the conservation movement and environmental protection, with particular interest, obviously, on the marine environment and the fishing industry.

His concern about planning matters, which he took up separately, led to his involvement in the Town and Country Planning Association in the 1960s and a stint in local government in the early 1970s. He was a foundation member of the Conservation Council of South Australia and an office holder of that organisation. On a number of occasions, he was a councillor of the Australian Conservation Foundation. Prior to being elected to the Senate in the 1987 double dissolution, he lectured in environmental studies at the University of Adelaide.

Senator Lees has admirably taken us through many of the quite specific scientific contributions that John Coulter made during his career, both before the Senate and subsequently. I think the contribution to this place for which we will most remember him is his work over the years on a whole variety of committees—initially, on the Industry, Science and Technology Standing Committee from 1987 to 1991 and then the Environment, Recreation and the Arts Standing Committee from 1987 to 1990 and its successor until 1994. He was until recently a member of the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee and the chair of the companion references committee.

The select committees of which he was a member—the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs; Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia; and Health Legislation and Health Insurance—gave him a particular opportunity to contribute in areas in which he had expertise and a capacity as well as an interest in proposing alternative solutions.

He was the first Australian Democrat chair of any Senate committee, from May 1993—in this case, the Functions, Powers and Operation of the Australian Loan Council, which posed certain challenges to the government at the time—

TALK.START.PARA: —What a committee that was!
—If I can put it gently and acknowledge Senator Sherry's interjection, it was, indeed. This is an occasion for grace, Senator Sherry.
—I am being graceful.

—Okay. Senator Coulter became Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats in the parliament in 1990, acting leader of the party in August 1991 and leader from October of that year until just after the last general election. I do not want to say anything about the circumstances either of his elevation to, or his departure from, the leadership of his party.It might conceivably have something to do with that quality of political judgment which led him to say in January 1993 that, having moved around the country and been intensely and closely involved with the voters, despite the horrendous policies of the Liberal Party, Dr Hewson nonetheless would be elected Prime Minister because the electorate wanted change. With that kind of perception—well, there it is.
—That's Evans's best attempt at grace!

—I don't think it is too bad in all the circumstances. Senator Coulter brought to this chamber a background and an interest, as I hope I have already indicated, in a wide spectrum of subjects which have in the past not received the kind of consideration in the Senate that they almost certainly deserved. I am talking about the protection of the environment, the dangers to human health of modern society and its work practices.

PARA.TAB: That contribution was marked by an unswerving commitment to his ideals—some of us may have been inclined to argue, at the cost of more practical, political and economic considerations—but was always combined with an uncompromising desire to achieve those objectives, those goals, that he set himself. While wanting to argue at all sorts of times and places about those particular objectives, particularly when expressed in legislative form, I do not contest for one moment that John Coulter's bona fides were absolutely clear-cut and straightforward. There was never any doubt about the intent and the motivation which lay behind it.

I have to say that I have always personally admired people of fierce passion and fierce conviction, even when I have thought that from time to time they might be a bit off beam in terms of some of the solutions they have proposed. Certainly, I admire that kind of contribution to public life and public policy infinitely more than I admire the trimming, the hypocrisy and the unwillingness to take seriously public policy issues that is so characteristic of so many people in public life.

It is always a matter of regret when a senator leaves at a time other than entirely of their own choosing, particularly due to ill health. We do appreciate that the rigours of an election campaign, even the relatively refined rigours of a Senate campaign—and I am now acutely aware of the difference!—can take a tremendous toll on those involved. But I do think it is unfortunate that Senator John Coulter is unable to stay until the end of these sittings.

I am sure he will not be wanting to `retire', in every sense of that word, to his farm with his wife, Phyllis. I do hope that, to the extent he is able to do so, he will continue to take a very active interest in the very wide variety of issues which have been his lifelong concern and very much his concern in this parliament. I really do believe that I speak for everyone in this chamber when I wish John and his family all the very best in the future.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on behalf of the National Party in the Senate to join the valedictory motion moved for Senator Coulter. We are all very sorry to hear of your illness last year and we are very sorry you are leaving this place prematurely now.

PARA.TAB: I have known you personally since you came to this place in 1987, I think it was, when you were elected as a Democrat. I have travelled with you on a number of occasions on Senate committees, and I have come to know you as a decent man who is very committed to the cause of the environment and some of the social issues you have espoused in the Senate. I think there probably would not be too many people who would be as far apart politically on most issues as you and I. Nevertheless, I believe that you have a conviction and you are prepared to stand up for that conviction. I think the parliament is made a better place when you have people, as Senator Gareth Evans has said, who are passionate for their cause.

You are now leaving us. You have told me that you have a little farm up in the foothills of Adelaide which you enjoy very much. Our wishes are that you and your wife have many years of enjoyment on that farm. I also would join with both Senator Gareth Evans and the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Hill—as no doubt will Senator Harradine and the Greens also join with all of us—in wishing you a long retirement and a speedy recovery to good health.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to acknowledge Senator Coulter, first of all, as having been the leader of our party when I was elected to the Senate and, secondly, for the contribution he made, during that election, to my election to the Senate. I would underline that and certainly acknowledge that contribution.

PARA.TAB: But, of course, I became aware of Senator Coulter much earlier than at the time I became a Senate candidate. In fact, I remember a very early speech he made that I was listening to on the radio. As that speech concluded, the comment was made—and I do not know whether it was someone from the government or the coalition who made it: `Senator Coulter, I'm not sure whether I understand what you've been saying, and if I did understand it I think I would disagree'. That was the comment they made, which perhaps says more about them than about Senator Coulter.

Certainly, as a scientist, as I have listened to him over the years, I believe that he has made, on many occasions, thoughtful and very significant comment on these issues. As an environmentalist, of course, we recognise John's absolute commitment to the environment. I do not think anyone in our party, which has always been known as a party committed to the environment, has a stronger commitment than his.

I recognise John as an economist. I am not sure many of you think of him in that way. But I remember a number of contributions he made that I think are quite unique and which I would like to underline. It was John who first, as far as I am concerned, raised the issue of the need for a steady state economy. He was one of the first—before it became a popular kind of buzz word—to speak about the need for an environmental and economic sustainability; many years before other people were talking in those terms, John Coulter was raising that issue.

I remember a number of speeches that I found stimulating and which opened up for me a whole lot of new thinking—about the need to change the way that we measure economic growth not only in Australia but in the world; the problem of simply measuring gross domestic product as cash flow, without in any way measuring the loss or gain of national and natural assets such as soil, water and air; and the need to change to a measurement which took account of those things. It is only now at long last, after many years, that we have the Bureau of Statistics beginning to recognise something that John Coulter has been talking about to my knowledge for at least 10 years, but probably much longer.

Finally, I want to remember John Coulter's philosophy. He is certainly not a theist, but he and I come very close in terms of our appreciation of the need, in my terms, for a creation spirituality that appreciates the fundamental call to care for the earth. Perhaps that is his most enduring contribution. I certainly want to thank him for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too was very saddened to hear of Senator Coulter's decision to retire because of ill health. I suppose that this is particularly so after this past 12 months, when I have spent time serving with Senator Coulter on two standing committees and one select committee. It is almost fair to say that I have nearly spent more time with Senator Coulter than I have with my wife this year. I would not want you to read anything into that, but it is a fact.

PARA.TAB: Senator Coulter, I was particularly saddened to hear of your decision to retire because of ill health. I did not realise in the 12 months I was working with you that you were not well, although I knew of the trouble you had had prior to Christmas last year. It is fair to say that when I was first elected to the Senate you were the leader of your party. It is no wonder that I did not really have very much to do with you in the first 18 months that I was in this place. It was only after the last election that I found myself working very closely with you on the two standing committees, one which you chaired and one which I chaired, and on the select committee.

One of the more satisfying aspects of committee work is the opportunity to get to know and understand senators from other parties involved in politics in this place. The time spent together, particularly when travelling on committee hearings, allows for the sharing of ideas, thoughts and views. Senator Coulter is a very willing sharer. Your company was very much appreciated on those trips.

We seem to spend so much time in this chamber concentrating on our differences. Out of this place, we have a chance to share our common beliefs. It is amazing just how much we agree on when we get the chance to sit down and talk to each other on a private basis or when the pressures of this chamber are not involved in those discussions. Certainly I appreciated the opportunities I had to sit and talk with you. I know that it was very wet one night in Melbourne when I spent about an hour under a tram shelter while you had an umbrella and I did not. Apart from that, I remember those times. I certainly enjoyed your company while I was involved on that committee work with you.

Senator Coulter is a man of integrity, passion, conscience and genuine goodwill. His academic knowledge and experience and his love of science and the environment are well known. They have been spoken about by other speakers here tonight. I reiterate all those comments because I know how much we have appreciated particularly your knowledge of science when those of us who are not so academically qualified in that field have found ourselves at public hearings and questions have been asked about which we have had no idea and answers have been given about we have had even less an idea. You have no idea how much we have appreciated your presence. I particularly remember the CSIRO inquiry and your input into that.

Your love of science and the environment is well known. I know that you will be sorry not to be able to complete the inquiry into marine pollution on the Senate Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee, where you were responsible for drawing up the terms of reference. You initiated a very important inquiry that will probably go on for quite some time. I know how disappointed you must be at not being able to complete that inquiry, because it is one that you have been talking about for a long time. Only now has the committee had the chance to be able to go ahead with that inquiry. I think of how you sat through all those soccer hearings, being such an ardent soccer fan, to eventually get to an inquiry that you were interested in.

TALK.START.PARA: —It took me to my first game.

—Yes, that is right. It did get you to your first game. I do remember that. I am just sorry you have not had the opportunity to go through and complete that inquiry that you really love. I must say that you are a pleasure to work with on committees. When we get to that terrible time for all committees which is writing the reports, I have to say that you were always totally frank, totally honest and trustworthy when it came to your work and involvement in all of those areas.

PARA.TAB: I am quite sure we have not heard the last of John Coulter. I think your passion for the environment and science will have you working to your absolute limit. All I can say is: God help that marvellous computer you have because I am sure it will be working overtime. But I know that also is a source of a great deal of pleasure for you because you have often talked about your love of computing and the information that you are able to gain and share.

I think modern technology has been a marvel for people like you because you will be able to use it to its fullest. Certainly I know that is one area where your health does not have to be quite as good as others because you can spend a lot of time there. I knew you were healthy because I remember when we were completing a fishing inquiry and we just happened to be on Lord Howe Island you and Phyllis climbed Mount Lidgbird while I pursued some rather less strenuous activities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Golf.

—You're dead right. Senator Coulter, I wish you well. I hope you and Phyllis have a lot of time to spend together. I hope you enjoy that time. I hope your health will allow you to fulfil your post-retirement period the way you would want.

—I, too, rise to speak briefly on the adjournment. Senator Margetts will also speak because we both want to place on the public record our thoughts and feelings on Senator Coulter's decision to leave this place.

PARA.TAB: Senator Coulter, I want to express my deep respect and appreciation of the depth of your knowledge, experience and commitment that you have consistently demonstrated since the time I have been in the Senate. You preceded me by many years, entering the Senate on 21 September 1987. I think you should feel very pleased with your input over the eight years—work that has taken place both in this chamber and on the committees and all the other aspects of the work you have done for your electorate in South Australia. You will certainly be remembered with fondness and respect by all of us who have known you in this place.

I have four years of memories that spring to mind. I just want to mention a few of them as illustrations. I think Senator Ferguson summed it up really well when he said he thinks of you as a person of `integrity, passion, conscience and goodwill'. Your passion, your conscience and integrity springs to mind when we think of you as a scientist and also a whistleblower.

I also remember the extremely hard work you put into the endangered species legislation. That was my first piece of detailed environmental legislation I was able to witness in this place in 1992, prior to Senator Margetts coming. I was really impressed by that, and it was a very good model, I believe, of how we should tackle these issues.

I have always valued Senator Coulter's support on all the issues that the Greens have wanted to support in this chamber, in particular, the environmental issues that I deal with and also the nuclear issues that Senator Margetts has in her portfolio. In particular, I value the debate that we have had quite recently on the goldmine tailings dams. I think that was a moment of consensus in the chamber which was quite special. Each of the parties was unanimously concerned about the hazards those tailings dams do present to the environment, to the fauna of the areas, and about the need for them to be monitored and for the standards of best practice to be implemented by the mining industry in this regard.

The most wry memory I have is the ozone protection debate where I rose and tried to make intelligible the notes that I had been provided by Dhanu River, who clearly knows far more than I do, and then sat down to have Senator Coulter rise and explain to the rest of the chamber what I had just said. I noticed a subtle tendency creeping in as well that when Senator Kemp, in his role as shadow minister for the environment, had any detailed questions he did not even do me the courtesy of mentioning my name but simply asked you, Senator Coulter. I was quite relieved because if he had not I would have stood up and asked you.

TALK.START.PARA: —You get the answers you like.

—No, we do not always agree with the answers that Senator Coulter provides; I think the opposition doesn't. But, certainly, it has been of wonderful help to me to have somebody in the chamber with your scientific background and your deep commitment. I have always been really happy to defer to your far better knowledge and exposition on the topics that we have shared in this chamber. I have sympathy for your deputy leader, Senator Lees, who will have to replace you in that portfolio. I am sure we will be struggling and will think of you often with great regret that you are not able to be with us during those debates. You will be greatly missed. I hope you realise that that goes across all the parties.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, I regret that Senator Coulter is not in the best of health. I certainly wish him well and a speedy recovery through the rejuvenation and refreshment that retirement from this place will indubitably give. Most senators when they leave seem to gain 10 years on their lives; they certainly look 10 years younger. I certainly wish you and your wife, Phyllis, well because you certainly deserve to have a very profitable and enjoyable retirement from your efforts in this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Besides the adjectives that have been used by other speakers to describe Senator Coulter, I would like also to say that to me he has always been a sober, hardworking member of this chamber. I am not suggesting that all of us qualify for that particular title but certainly John Coulter did.

PARA.TAB: I have not had the pleasure of accompanying John on any of the delegations that have gone overseas. In fact I cannot recall the last time I went on an overseas delegation; perhaps I have forgotten it.
Senator Bell interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, that was not a delegation. Actually, that was a meeting of the population conference in Cairo. Now did anyone want to take that up? That was the last straw. Anyhow, they did not pay my fare nor my accommodation; that was out of my parliamentary allowance. I digress.

PARA.TAB: Yes, John has been a very hardworking senator. He has approached things from a logical and, by and large, informed scientific viewpoint. There would be, I am sure, quite a number more senators in the chamber than there are now if it was not for the fact that there are other circumstances in this parliament which have called them away. I, for example, am a participating member of the legal and constitutional committee, and I have some questions to ask that committee. Unfortunately, whilst my back was turned, the Senate must have agreed to that committee sitting at the same time as the Senate. I do apologise on their behalf, and I do apologise for my not being here for the entire valedictory.

John would know that on some occasions we had differences of view on some areas of public policy, not on all. As a matter of fact, the Patents Amendment Bill is coming up and I had the opportunity of pointing out to one of your colleagues, John, last week that you had an amendment to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —The speech is written.
—That is fine. I will read the amendment out for the record. The amendment adds at the end of clause 18:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . not to be regarded as possessing the quality of novelty or inventiveness for the purposes of this section:
(a) naturally occurring genes;
(b) naturally occurring gene sequences; and
(c) descriptions of the base sequence of a naturally occurring gene or a naturally occurring gene sequence.

I am certainly looking forward to the debate when the patents bill comes forward. I do not think it will be this year, but I am certainly looking forward to seeing what the fate of that particular amendment will be. I will certainly have something to say about it because I happen to agree that areas such as the areas of genetic manipulation of the human genome are facing this world with enormous problems, both ethical and otherwise.

PARA.TAB: We have had debates about population in this chamber. I happen to have, I feel, a great deal more confidence than John in the gift of intelligent inventiveness given to human beings which will ensure the food and resources needed to meet the challenge of population whilst upholding and protecting the prior rights of families. But that is not a matter which is proper for this particular valedictory.

I think John probably had more trust or hope in the legislative and regulatory process than I do. I happen to agree with what Plato said at the end of The Republic, where he indicated that the very existence of politics makes it mandatory to believe in the immortality of the soul, because it is patent to everybody that politics does not provide justice at all times, nor does it provide proper rewards. Nevertheless, as John and I would agree, there is the existence of greed, there is the existence of evil, there is the existence of exploitation, which of course demands on the populous through their elected representatives' attention to and some regulation of human activities.

John, I join with my colleagues here in wishing you a speedy recovery and wishing both you and your wife a very happy retirement. I know that for you, and no doubt for your wife, it will not be entirely retirement. You will be keeping up with things probably in a much better way than we are able to because you will have more time to contemplate the pressing issues which are for us to resolve.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with my colleagues in rising to express my best wishes to Senator Coulter on his early retirement from the Senate. Whether or not we agreed with Senator Coulter, he had a great deal to contribute to debate in this Senate. It is a sad thing that, because of reasons outside his control, he has decided to bring the curtain down and call it a day. It reminds us all that our time in this chamber is but a few moments of history and that we are judged by our contribution during our time here.

PARA.TAB: It has to be said that Senator Coulter and I had a very bad start. In a sense, Senator Coulter, these comments will tie in with my concluding remarks. It has been many years since a senator was thrown out of this chamber. Senator Coulter, if you can cast your mind back to that historic day—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I can.
—I think it was the day that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) replaced Mr Hawke—
—The night.

—Yes, the night. There was a somewhat robust debate in the chamber. I must have said a few things. I cannot remember exactly what I said. But I was warned and then I was named. It was particularly awkward for the Labor Party that evening. All the people in the other place were waiting for all these bills to come down from the Senate so that they could go home and close up with that particular session. I stood up and gave an explanation of what I thought had occurred. I am not sure it was a very good explanation but, from memory, the Labor Party was very keen to accept that explanation. But, Senator Coulter, you tricked us all. You moved that I be suspended from the chamber. As a result, after a somewhat vigorous debate, I was then asked to leave.

PARA.TAB: That incident enabled us to include ourselves in the history book, although not in a way that we would have preferred. After a senator is excluded from the chamber, it is very unusual for that senator to be asked back. Two hours later, after vigorous debate, it was decided that I should be asked back into the chamber so that the debate could be completed and the bills could be returned to the other place. Senator Coulter, although we have not had a great deal to do with each other over the years, in the seventh edition of Odgers' Senate Practice that particular incident is mentioned and, in that way, our relationship early on was recorded.

I agree with the sentiments that have been expressed by my colleagues in regard to the integrity of Senator Coulter, his hardworking nature, his great love of science and his commitment to the environment. I would agree with all those things, and I do not think they bear repeating. Despite the somewhat bad start to our relationship, I think Senator Coulter is a man who is true to his own light. It may not be the light that we see in the distance all the time, but Senator Coulter is true to that. He has pursued those interests with a great passion.

In his dealings with his opponents, Senator Coulter has been honest, even if he has not agreed with them. I know Senator Coulter has had his good times and his bad times in this chamber, but I do not think anyone here would have felt that Senator Coulter was not acting in a way which was integral to his own beliefs and values. I cannot draw on a widespread sharing of committee work with Senator Coulter. In fact, I am not too sure that we have ever served on a committee together. So our relationship over the years has not been as close as that of some other people in the chamber.

The concluding point I would make, which somewhat draws together my uncertain start, is that the great thing about this chamber and this parliament is the reinforcement that we all have of a democratic culture. We all come into this place with passionate beliefs and it is a good thing that they are retained.

In some ways it is a pity when you find people who change course regularly and shift as required for more base political purposes. Being in this chamber teaches one a degree of tolerance. You have to recognise that people of goodwill can differ in opinions. You and I probably do not agree in relation to quite a number of assumptions on how Australia should function. If we explored this at some length I think we would find quite a number of areas where we do agree.

I think all of us learn a degree of tolerance. With the contributions you have made, I have no reason to feel that that is not an adjective that can be added to the many that have been attributed to you. In relation to all of us and the need to protect the democratic culture, I think tolerance is very important.

I am sorry that you are leaving, Senator Coulter. I felt during the debate on the ozone legislation that I was starting to understand some of the things you were saying. As Senator Chamarette reminded us, a couple of the questions went to you. I am not saying I received answers that I was completely on top of, but it did show on that particular occasion the strong commitment you have to particular issues and the science background you bought to this chamber which will certainly be missed. Some will miss it in a happy sense and others will miss it because of the contribution that you were able to make. I wish you well. I am sorry that you felt that it was time to call it a day. I hope many years are given to you in which you can pursue the many interests that you have.

TALK.START.PARA: —John's life so far—and I hope it goes on a lot longer—has been rich and diverse. It has been full of achievements of which he can and should be very proud. He has served the Democrats not just as a senator, even though that takes a great toll, as I know, but as the deputy leader and the leader, which both, as other people in this chamber can attest, also take a great toll. Before that he was a medical practitioner, a medical researcher and a university academic. They are the things I know about. There are probably more. John was a founder of the conservation and environment movements in Australia. He is well known for his work, particularly at the ACF, where he was a councillor for many years.

PARA.TAB: Put simply, John early on accepted that it was his responsibility to do everything in his power to save the world. That is why he came into this place. He did not enter politics for personal power or kudos, but to make sure that parliament got it right. I have known him for 10 or 12 years now and I would probably characterise him as a modest hero—somebody with an absolutely single-minded determination to bring about change.

I cannot think of one other person who did more to expose the cover up on nuclear weapons testing and waste disposal at Maralinga. It did not stop at Maralinga. There is also the very famous contretemps with Bayer. There is John's absolute implacable opposition to nuclear weapons and uranium mining which brings about the possibility of nuclear weapons and his opposition to pollution in all its forms down to the most minute level. There is also his work on the Great Barrier Reef that has been mentioned tonight.

It is not unusual for a person to be single-minded, especially around here, but John is someone less common. His drive is based absolutely on doing what he sees, quite single-mindedly, as being right. That comes sometimes, and it has for John, at a considerable personal cost. It cannot be easy being a prophet, always looking ahead, always searching for what is right. I am probably not the only person in this chamber who has more than once been frustrated by John's vision, which always remains unclouded. It is never clouded by what is politic or possible in the so-called real world. He sticks to what is right. I think that he is right not to have taken the easy option in many cases.

We have been lucky to have had John and his conscience in the party room. He would probably say that he has not achieved enough, that time is short around here—and so it is—and that there is much more to be achieved. Of course, that would be right. But I cannot think of many other individuals who have fought as long or as hard as John has on so many fronts. Although they may not know it, this generation and future generations of Australians have a lot for which to thank John.

I will miss having him in the party room and next to me in the chamber. I will miss his experience, which no-one can ever replace, and his scientific knowledge and background. It is very unlikely that any of us will have that. I see Phyll up in the gallery. I will miss having Phyll around as well. I do wish Phyll and John all the very best in the next phase of their lives together. I cannot see it as being a retirement. I do not think that will happen. I can see John coming in here and giving us—I hope—the benefit of his experience in the future, and I look forward to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Many people have talked about the contribution that John Coulter has made in the Senate. I knew of John Coulter's work, and admired his work long before he knew of me, on such common concerns as the need for an ecologically sustainable world. In recent times, common ground and common issues that we have both worked on have included greenhouse, energy and nuclear waste issues. That reminds me of the committee that we have both been working on for the last few months on radioactive waste.

PARA.TAB: In the end, we could almost tell when John was going to ask a question of the scientist who had said that you can swallow radionuclides and it will not do you any harm, or you can turn them upside down and make an upside down footpath out of radioactive waste. There were all kinds of things. People actually believed that you did not actually need to wear a gauge in Lucas Heights, because, `Well, it is only the dose you receive all at once that is the real problem and, senators, it is really not a problem.' We began to be able to tell when the question, `Do you believe in the linear dose hypothesis?' would arise.

I got to know John quite well in the three weeks that I was fortunate to be in the Southern African delegation, the first since the change of government to a democratic structure in South Africa. I shared those three weeks with Phyllis and got to know them both quite well. I enjoyed the times. I guess that in a way we were holding the line against most other people who seemed to be looking only at how much money Australia could make out of SADC. Of course, we were wanting to know about how the social system was working and what kind of equity and fairness was there, about environmental problems and how they related to Australia's problems, and about trade issues—all those kinds of things that are of common concern to both the Greens and the Australian Democrats.

I have a request from two of my staff who are with me in Canberra—from Alan, who travels with me, and Diana, who stays in Canberra. They have asked me to say how much they have appreciated John Coulter's taking the time to talk through issues about which they have been concerned. There are not a lot of people in this whole system who will take the time to sit down with staffers and work through those kinds of technical issues. John, we all shall miss you, and we wish you and Phyllis a long and happy retirement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have enjoyed very much my experience working with John Coulter on various committees. He has always been forthright and has applied knowledge in a very constructive way. His concern for the environment and the way people live in the environment has always been to me a very important approach. John, you can leave this place and look back on your history here, as I am sure you can on your life until the time you entered the Senate, with a great deal of pride. All of us can walk away from criticism by other people, but the one thing you can never walk away from is your own conscience and your judgment of your worth and what you have done in your life on this planet. I am sure you can live with yourself very, very comfortably and be proud of your role up to this point, and, I am sure, as you live a long and fruitful life ahead.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in two capacities on the retirement of Senator John Coulter: firstly, as a senator, and therefore as a colleague, in this chamber; and, secondly, as science minister and someone who acknowledges that Senator Coulter, as the science spokesman for the Australian Democrats, has in this chamber and as a political representative contributed to raising the profile of science in the Australian community quite importantly and quite strongly. He deserves national recognition for that as one of his achievements out of a myriad of other quite important achievements.

PARA.TAB: Senator Coulter will not know this, but I was aware of his impact on national affairs well before he would ever have been aware of me. It is a long and complicated story as to why that is the case, but let me shortly tell it. My father was a waterside worker from Port Adelaide and he transferred to Fremantle—I think this was in the very early 1970s—and rented a room in a house on Stirling Highway at Cottesloe, which was a house of Dr Coulter's mother, and rented the same room in which Dr Coulter as a younger man had resided.

My father, who had a thirsty knowledge for anything of a political nature, had some discussions about Dr Coulter's career then, and his career then was of a person making an early and fundamental impact in the environmental debate in Australia, specifically in South Australia. When my parents returned to Adelaide, they followed Dr Coulter's career and kept me advised of it and, when he was elected to the Senate and I was elected to the Senate, they followed both our careers.

While they never voted for any political party other than the ALP, nonetheless they sometimes took up the points that Dr Coulter made in public debate in order to press some of these principles on their second eldest son—that is, me. You had an unknown, Dr Coulter, but nonetheless quite powerful lobby group—quite extraneous to your party—within my family. Therefore, I was aware of many of your early achievements as an environmental advocate in South Australia and only regretted that you chose the Australian Democrats, not the Australian Labor Party, to pursue those objectives politically. However, that is how it turned out.

During my political period here and Dr Coulter's, he and I have not got to know each other personally, but what we are here tonight to pay due recognition to is a Senate life of someone who has been, and who obviously will remain, active in Australian politics. I do not think being an elected representative means that you have a political career; it means you have a privilege to put forward the views that you hold and the views of the people who have appointed you to express them in a public domain. I think all of us have an obligation to pursue our political ideals, both inside and outside of politics. I have the very strong view, Senator Coulter, that your period here, while fertile in commitment and effort, is nonetheless not the end of your political career but simply by moving out of this place is transforming itself in another way and will continue.

I join with all of those who regret that you are retiring prematurely for health reasons. I think that is unfortunate, but I do recognise that you will have more time now, as has been said, to pursue your political objectives.

What I think is always difficult at a time like this is to assess the value of an effort that people make to politics. This is a demanding chamber. It calls for great energy and effort and commitment, not only by those of us elected to serve here but by our nearest family. In many respects, they bear the weight of it but they get none of the recognition or very little of the recognition.

In assessing a senatorial life, one has to look for what are the characteristic marks of respect from colleagues. I think that you have that. In my observation, you have a lot more than that but, from where I have sat in the chamber, your commitment has always been strong to the ideals that you hold.

I accept without question the views of your colleagues that often that may have meant some personal setback for you in pursuit of an ideal that you saw as important. That is the mark of someone who is a genuine person, and someone who has a genuine sense of purpose about their life. Whether I always agree with that sense of purpose is another matter, but to have worked out what is important and to have placed it ahead of personal gain deserves tribute.

In my experience you would always seek to argue within a logical framework, to pursue your views with passion, to call up an encyclopaedic knowledge in defence of your own arguments and in prosecution of them, to be a worthy advocate for your cause and an enviable foe for those of us who sometimes found ourselves arraigned against you and for those of us who sometimes exalted in the fact that we were arraigned with you. In terms of what I have seen on the science front, there is no doubt, Senator Coulter, that you have a strong commitment to science. It is a commitment more to the understanding and creation of new knowledge about science, to pure science, than it is to any other part of it; to understand the nature of things and of the world and to pursue that in order to understand the meaning of things more profoundly, to do that with a certain joy and the happiness of discovery. I would like to think that as a science minister I might grudgingly perhaps make you proud of some of the changes we would bring to this policy for the government, but that is a matter for another time and another place. I do understand your commitment on this front. I commend you for it. I regret the reasons for your decision to retire but I wish you happiness and I wish you well in your retirement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on this series of valedictory speeches that mark a very happy occasion in the Senate because we are celebrating the contribution to this place of Senator John Coulter. Next week he will be known as `Dr John Coulter', and to all of us as `John'. I wish to join with all those who have made remarks commending the service to this country and to the Senate that John has contributed and to wish him, his wife Phyllis and his family all the best wishes in the future.

PARA.TAB: All of the Democrats sitting around you, John, have had really close times of warmth. I have tried to express warmth to you individually on various occasions, especially when we agree, but even when I know the sincerity of the argument that you are putting and we still disagree. I look directly at all of your colleagues about you, and at the Greens and Independent Senator Harradine opposite, and know that there are large parties that have the potential of government—I think we in the coalition have a huge potential for government in the coming few months—but that there is a very important place for those with particular concerns that lead to a minority vote. We are all alike in having our rights here because we are elected by the people of our states and territories.

I rise following the remarks of Senator Hill, Senator Lees and Senator Ferguson, amongst a number of South Australians who have spoken. As a South Australian senator, like you, I wish to salute you in your retirement and wish you well. In the first contest I had to be elected here in 1977 I was successful by only 1,000 votes over your colleague the Hon. Ian Gilfillan. I came here; that Democrat did not. The second contest, a month later, was as to who would replace Senator Steele Hall. The Labor government had a majority in the South Australian parliament and the provision was that they would determine amongst the nominees. Senator Haines became for six months the one who got the numbers in the state parliament and, I the other nominee, did not.

I feel keenly the initial tussle with Ian Gilfillan and then with Janine Haines. I then came to occupy the room she had. You were the third Democrat involved in elections but in fact the second South Australian Democrat to come here. In 1987 you added to the number of Democrats in this chamber. Later, Senator Lees also came to the chamber as a Democrat from South Australia.

I have always disagreed with the strategy of being a minority party. I have some very strong views that are sometimes regarded by even my colleagues, who are patient, as outspoken views. I like to think they are for justice. But I have determined not to seek election to this place without a chance of being in government. I respect the alternative decision that all of you whom I have just named have made to come here—at the moment, as seven, two and one—to contribute to this place. I feel most comfortable conscientiously being a part of a major party which genuinely has the ability to be in government, but to put views that we believe are just, right and well founded.

I first met Senator Coulter 23 years ago when I attended a number of meetings of the Town and Country Planning Association. Our mutual friend, Ralph Middenway, who I still see quite often, encouraged me to take an interest in the flora and fauna of the countryside in South Australia, and also our urban and regional planning. At the time I was elected urban chairman of the Liberal Party—it was the first executive office I held—in 1973. As urban chairman, my first project was to see an end to the then Dunstan Labor dream of Monarto. He was proposing a city which I thought was abysmally planned, in the wrong place and not properly worked out. Fortunately, that project of mine, joined by other allies in the Town and Country Planning Association, led to the demise of the Monarto concept and we do not see a city, not even one building, at that site which then Premier Dunstan outlined.

I continue, despite scepticism from time to time even from John, to be a clear thinking, I hope, and careful environmentalist. I can never match the positions that John has taken on the environment but I remain within the coalition, in the chamber as well, a spokesperson for a secure environment where development is sustainable along with the environment. We may differ on some judgments but I, as a genuine environmentalist, salute Senator Coulter as, above all, a person committed to the environment. With your medical training, your scientific research and your knowledge of chemistry, you have brought an enormous concentration of effort to the issues of the environment in this country and, indeed, in the world. All of us have to look at the global environment, not just at this nation's environmental concerns.

The term `sustainable development' is now writ large in the policies of all parties, whereas in the years before you came, Senator Coulter, it was only just emerging. You were ahead of others in the use of terms like this. I recognise those earlier speeches in this debate that emphasised this contribution which you have made.

There are a couple of areas on which I do not think we will ever agree. For instance, the way you want to have a John Coulter definition for GNP will probably lead to a book. It will probably lead you to make some contribution to the theory of economics. I have tried to listen carefully—to your first speech here, out on the hustings and in various questions you have put which touch upon your view of GNP—and I am afraid I am still not convinced.

Similarly, with regard to trade. It appears even in your question today, as Senator Gareth Evans recalled it, that you are haltingly acknowledging that there ought to be any trade. I think you would want all of us to have sustenance just from our own efforts in our own little region. That is the impression you gave.

I remember a solar energy debate that we were engaged in during the last election campaign, in which you were the spokesman for the Democrats and I for the Liberal Party. Certainly, the impression that I gained was that it is no good having any kind of trade—that is as I perceived it from Senator Coulter—because that will expend energy, which will lead to a greenhouse effect that is negative, and it is much better if we just live in our own little environments and not have the exchange of goods across the world.

When the Hindmarsh Island bridge is eventually built, whether the royal commission finds that the so-called claims are fabricated or not, I do not think you will be cheering but I will because it is a count for the development of South Australia. I want to assure you that, in my assessment, I believe it will not damage the environment. I must conclude by saying that I recognise your great contributions to the debates in this chamber. I wish you, Phyllis and all your family every happiness in the years ahead.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not keep the Senate long because, after all, it was John Coulter who calculated that every word we utter in this place costs the taxpayer—what was it, John?
—Twenty-six dollars.

—There you go, $26 per utterance. That is the sort of thing we have relied upon John Coulter for in our party. You sort of get the general direction right, then you just take a side word to John Coulter and he gives you down to the last, probably the fourth decimal place, what the particular precise matter is.

PARA.TAB: John and I are a fair way apart in many ways: with me being fairly casual and not too fussed about details, with a general knowledge about nothing in detail and a couple of university degrees in arts; with John being a specialist, a scientist with precise detailed knowledge—a formidable array and amazing breadth of knowledge—and a person who enjoys stretching his own frontiers of knowledge. When I say `enjoys' it, you should have seen him in Papeete with the telsat satellite telephone. I knew that you had to just wiggle it around a bit and point it up to the stars. There is John—he could have had an azimuth and a calculator, the details had to be precise—but when he turned it on, click, there we were straight through. It was fairly symptomatic of John's relationship with me. Often with information technology, computers and such like, I have had a bit of an idea about how to get the agriculture direction right. But then John comes along with the precise knowledge that has enabled me over a number of years to get the eventual picture in a much more precise and useful way.

I had several introductions to this John Coulter. One was in 1988 when he came to Hobart as my guest. I had not really worked out much about him. I think I had seen him once or twice in South Australia. He came to Hobart at my invitation to enlighten us a little more about the emergence of this greenhouse theory. Again, I had a fairly agricultural understanding of the general implications of it. I stood up at the University of Tasmania and introduced him to an audience by saying that he was a bit older than me and that he knew a bit more about the environment and stuff like that. Then I had to sit back and get overwhelmed with this incredible detailed knowledge and a scientific expose of what it involved.

Then, having been a little embarrassed by that introduction, some couple of years later I was with several other Democrats essentially as John's guests in a houseboat on the Murray and we were returning to port. I did not quite know where we were—I knew we were on the Murray—but it was getting very dark. There was Coulter at the wheel. Here he was demonstrating his immense breadth of knowledge and practical skills because he is a practical man. I do not know how we got through these guideposts and against the current and docked at the port, but we had John Coulter at the wheel using the stars, the currents, the satellites and some sort of mental logarithmic calculations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which you can't handle.

—Senator Panizza is right. I get the general direction right; you must appreciate that. But there was John Coulter with his incredible navigational skill and practical capacity to berth this rather large houseboat without sinking us into the perilous depths.

PARA.TAB: I have been indebted to John for being able to bring precision to my generalities in a number of areas. I have invaded his portfolio responsibilities on a number of occasions because I have had a certain passion about certain subjects and John has been able to put me straight and fill in the details for me, whether that be about information technology or one of my earlier interests in this place, recycling. I took on a personal interest in agriculture and veterinary chemicals to find that the Australian authority as far as what ought to be done was sitting next to me.

John is a person who lives his commitment to subjects, whether they be the ones that have been mentioned in a quite lengthy way here tonight or whether they be the ones that we do not know much detail about. Here is the man who uses fuel efficiency as his criteria for selection of his DAS car that he is going to lease. I wonder how many others use that as their criteria. He argues that the tax regime ought to be reorganised as far as automotive taxation is concerned. He argues and lives that. That is the criteria that he uses. I admire that.

John will be remembered by those who have tried many times in Australia to advance the fledgling motor fuel industry based on ethanol. It is John who must be remembered for the contribution that he brought to that, for his passion and deep understanding of the real advantages to be gained from encouraging that fledgling industry to develop and for being able to follow it through through the budget negotiations to the stage where we should now be able to correct, after the government recognises the wisdom of the amendments that he proposed some years ago, and finally get it right.

There is much detail that I could repeat here that other people have raised. But I remind the Senate that it was John Coulter's instinctive knowledge, passion and researched knowledge which enabled him, with the environmental problem which scourged much of our Australian waters earlier this year with the death of pilchards, to bring instinct, research and science to suggest what the cause was and to pursue that cause and to be vindicated in the end for demonstrating that, if only he had been listened to a little earlier, we might have been able to resolve that problem earlier.

I will conclude by saying that I think that is typical of the contribution that John has made, both at a personal level to me and at a level in public life. If only we were able to pay some attention to the sorts of things he raises; there are problems which confront us that I am sure John Coulter would be able to assist us in resolving.

John, I farewell you from this place with a genuine feeling of sadness because I now know you as a friend, after having been introduced to you as an expert. You have become a friend and you will remain a friend, and I think we should acknowledge that you are a gentleman as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a speech slightly longer than 10 minutes. I hope that the chamber will indulge me for about 15 minutes because there are some things that I need to say and I want to say as this is the last opportunity that I will have to say them. I thank all those who have spoken already, particularly Senator Kemp, who reminded us tonight of that earlier episode where I was responsible for him leaving the chamber. It was very gracious of him to mention that with such joy and a smile on his face after this time. I am sure he did not quite feel it at the time. I was not aware that it was recorded in the annals of the Senate in any other way than in the Hansard. He reminded me of that.

PARA.TAB: Senator Peter Cook: it was very pleasing to know that there might have been an influence going back into the 1970s through your family in relation to work that I had done in the environment movement long before I got into this place. I remind the Senate that I was at the university in the late 1940s with Bob Hawke and, believe it or not, we were both members of the student Christian movement at the time. Although John Woodley mentioned my lack of theistic attachment at the moment, that was not always the case. While Bob Hawke and I took somewhat different paths, we both lost our belief in God. Nonetheless, as John Woodley reminded me, I have retained a very strong ethical and moral commitment to those issues that I feel are important.
I thank all those others who have spoken in various ways. In my prepared speech I would like to pick up some of the points which have been made. Let me begin with this prepared speech.
If you can keep your head when all about you
Are losing theirs and blaming it on you
