SPEECH.PARA: I grew up with Kipling's If framed on the wall of my bedroom. Little did my mother suspect, nor I know, that the last years of my working life would be spent in an environment in which those qualities would be so needed.

PARA.TAB: My mother died before I was elected into the Senate but she always wanted a son to be a doctor. When I spent most of my life in medical research I know very well that she did not approve of that, and I am sure that she would have approved even less of the time that I have spent after entering party political life. But it was, indeed, a natural progression for me.

Although I did not join a political party until 1980, I had been politically very active at all levels of the conservation movement since the mid 1950s. Just as with party political activity, this work often separated me from my family for considerable periods of time—something that several others have mentioned.

There are many who criticise those of us who seek a better world for our descendants through political activity. They frequently rail against the travel and perceived perks of office but fail to recognise the costs borne by the families of political activists in the pursuit of a better world. I think Senator Ferguson mentioned spouses.

I should like to thank my family for their forbearance over many years and their understanding and support of what it was that I thought was so important that it took me away from them at many critical times. My two children, Peter and Kiersten, put up with a lot when they were very young in the 1960s. It is hard to believe now that in the 1960s each time I appeared on television speaking on a conservation matter my son would be criticised by his peers next day at school because of the views of his father.

At that time not a single government in this country had a department of environment. The views I then expressed are now common place, although still not accepted or acted upon by governments. But every government has a department of environment, although none accords it the central place in decision making that it deserves. We still have a very long way to go.

My wife, Phyllis, who is here tonight knew what she was letting herself into in marrying someone so committed to change through political activity, for she was warned by her best friend who said to her, `Don't do it.' Phyllis has given me constant and untiring support without which I could not have carried out my function as a senator.

This is not news to any of my Senate colleagues, but I say these things to put on the record the enormous support, effort and sacrifice made by both male and female spouses. My time away from home on parliamentary business would be fairly typical of every other senator. In eight years I estimate that I have spent five years away from home on parliamentary business.

It is much easier to run a line that the perks are what attracts people to politics. In office it is impossible for politicians to say how much pay they get, but as I am about to leave let me say that, calculated at standard rates for 36 1/2 hours and time and a half for overtime, a senator's base pay at present is the equivalent of just under $29,000 per year. This is far below my former income as a research scientist and would be far below the income that most well-qualified people are paid outside parliament.

I have been served by a marvellous staff. Merilyn Pedrick has been with me for most of my term in the Senate. She has been a source of sunlight and constant good humour in every office that I have occupied. No-one could wish for a better key person holding the whole office together with her always pleasant manner. I will miss my daily contact with Merilyn very much.

When I was Leader of the Democrats, I had on my staff a number of excellent researchers, to whom I would like to pay tribute: Richard Bolt, with a sound science background and an ability to get on top of those complex matters very quickly and with considerable insight and clarity of understanding and expression; Imogen Zethoven, with a total dedication to environmental sustainability combined with a grasp of an incredible range of detail on environmental issues; Jacqui Flitcroft, an extremely able person with a very sound perspective and incredible technical skill and able and willing to work under extreme pressure for long hours without crumpling; Isobel Mayer, who worked on Aboriginal issues and industrial relations with equal facility, grasp and dedication; Chris Fry, with his remarkable memory of tax and related legislative detail and with an innovative approach to amendments in this area; and Natasha Stott Despoja, to whom I shall return in a moment. These researchers formed a close-knit and remarkable team. I thank them again for the support that they gave me and to the whole Senate team while I was leader. All save Jacqui Flitcroft have now gone to other jobs.

Kym Winter Dewhirst has produced my magazine Canopy and has been a whiz at media releases which compel reading. To Kym I owe a special debt for mastering the complexities of desktop publishing and producing quality material for my office.

Without exception, I found all the staff of Parliament House always helpful and hardworking, going beyond what could reasonably be expected to serve the functioning of the parliament. Those who organise our transport, the Clerk of the Senate and his staff, the secretaries and researchers of the Senate committees and the staff of the library have all created a particularly happy and helpful working environment. I shall be here tomorrow clearing up my office, and I hope to get about and say a more personal thankyou to many of those people.

Turning to Natasha Stott Despoja: she was one of over 60 applicants for a job when I became leader of the party. At that stage she was only 21; but even then she stood out above most others, some with better paper qualifications. She was on my staff for several years, was then on Senator Kernot's staff for several years and has been back on my staff for another year. The confidence I placed in her five years ago has been amply justified, and I am delighted that the membership of the South Australian division of the Australian Democrats voted overwhelmingly for Natasha to be the senator to assume the vacancy I will shortly create.

I know that senators and other parliamentarians from both the larger parties have had their eyes on Natasha—and there is at least one in this chamber tonight—and have expressed eagerness to have her should she be willing to join their ranks. So I know she will prove to be a great senator, and I am extremely pleased at the prospect of my position being filled by such an exceptional young and talented person. I hope her entry into this chamber will be made before the end of this session.

Just picking up on this theme of young people—and I thank Senator Chamarette for her notice of motion today—Australia needs its gifted young people from a wide range of educational backgrounds in its parliaments, especially its federal parliament. Not surprisingly, some young people are some of the most disillusioned with the political process. Disillusionment catalyses disillusionment through discouraging quality entrants into our parliament. It is a dangerous trend, and it is already well under way. I believe we must all do more to remove the impediments in the way of our gifted young entering a political carer. I hope that Natasha's appointment and next year her election to the Senate will assist the reversal of this trend of disillusionment and mediocrity in political life in Australia.

My Democrat parliamentary colleagues have been a small team throughout my time in the Senate, but I believe we have discharged our responsibility to the people of Australia with care and concern for the three broad principles that underpin all Democrat policy: ecological sustainability, social justice and equity and democratic process. We have had our differences but in the Democrats we have a conscience vote on every issue. This is one of the prime reasons I joined the Democrats and not either the Labor or coalition parties. I am picking up here on what Senator Baden Teague said this evening. To me it is fundamental to the proper fulfilment of representative democracy.

People of good conscience, having argued all the pros and cons, can still hold different views and should be judged by the people they represent by those views. People of good conscience who represent constituents should not hide behind the views often held by a slim majority in their party room. Many of you in the Labor and coalition parties will have been discomforted from time to time by divisions that I have called when I have known your private views. I have done this quite deliberately for I have known that many of you did not share the view of your spokesperson or your party on a particular matter. I believe loyalty to party above conscience is a travesty of the notion of representative democracy and is another matter which brings the present parliamentary process into disrepute with so many voters. There have been a number of occasions on which I have voted differently from my parliamentary colleagues.

In summary of my eight years in the Senate, I make two points. Firstly, because of my activity through the conservation movement and in various educational capacities through several decades, those who elected me—and this I think has been borne out by the speeches tonight—knew the values I would carry to this office. I believe I have continued to espouse those values and to hold true to those values and therefore discharge my responsibility to the electors of South Australia as a representative of those values. Secondly—and several people have presaged this tonight—as regards moving the juggernaut of government closer to the adoption of those values and the implementation of them, I must confess to being an almost total failure.

When I entered the Senate and made my first speech—they were still called maiden speeches at that stage—I outlined, and I think this was also mentioned earlier tonight, the failure of presently used economic indexes to measure the right things, the inclusion of costs as benefits in the measurement of GDP, for example—I will not go into this now, but some time I must take Senator Baden Teague aside and explain in simple terms what I mean by that—and the absence of a national capital account which gives a totally misleading impression of becoming richer by squandering natural capital and turning it into cash, cash which is then frittered away without turning it back into capital.

I pointed to the way in which these distorted indexes were seriously misleading and to the way in which the correction of these distortions would indicate different and more reliable paths to be followed, the paths toward ecological sustainability and a more humane society. After the speech, Fred Chaney, who was the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate at that time, came over to me with his congratulations, which as you all know is usual, and said, `A most unusual maiden speech. I don't think I understood it, but if I had I think I would have disagreed with it.'

Nothing has changed. We still hear all our senior ministers, including the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), daily, talk about sustainable economic growth, without realising that that term is an oxymoron to beat all oxymorons. Growth, as growth of GDP, is measured exponentially. Sustainability refers to ecological sustainability and the ecology of the planet is finite. It is quite simply proven that economic growth can only continue at the expense of either the environment or equity between people. Either way economic growth is not sustainable. But then whoever noticed economists or ministers wedded to the ideology of economic rationalism looking at the empirical evidence. To the rationalist economist the real world is a special case. Ignoring the real and empirical, we are destined to make the same mistakes over and over again.

There's the story of the Prime Minister, the deputy and the Treasurer hiring a light plane to go kangaroo shooting one weekend. Before the plane took off the pilot explained that it was only a small plane and that they could only bring back one large kangaroo. Come Sunday afternoon each minister has shot a large kangaroo and they prevail upon the pilot to load all three. The plane limps into the air and then crashes. The Prime Minister struggles out of the wreckage saying, `Where, where are we?' The Treasurer then fights his way out of the debris and says, `About 100 metres from where we were last year!'

Economic commentators and journalists compound the problem by lack of publicly expressed alternative analyses. By and large, they have accepted economic rationalist language and analysis without looking independently at the empirical evidence. How many television interviews have you seen in which the discussion is centred on the rate of economic growth required to reduce unemployment by a certain percentage? On this, the empirical evidence is clear. There is no relation whatsoever between the rate of economic growth and the reduction in the rate of unemployment.

To give you a few figures: between 1970 and 1992 the US had a 76 per cent growth of GDP and a 45 per cent growth in employment. While France had a 75 per cent growth of GDP, almost identical to the United States, it had only a seven per cent growth in employment. Spain had the second highest economic growth of GDP of all European countries at 93 per cent, but employment actually fell by two per cent.

One of the most depressing aspects of the economic debate is that most of the journalists who interview and write about these matters have become enmeshed in the same false paradigm that guides government policy. Only last week I watched in growing anger an interview by Paul Lyneham with the federal Treasurer (Mr Willis) about the percentage point differences that the economy would need to grow to achieve certain employment benefits. I wanted to scream at Paul Lyneham, `Tell the Treasurer it's all a load of cow manure. Present him with some data from the real world.'

It is a sorry situation when most of our commentators have adopted the same unreal economic model and use the language and concepts of this false model. There is little analysis that starts from the real and the empirical, and none it seems in the advice which goes to government.

The economic rationalist has no clothes. Unfortunately, we are still at the stage at which very few are pointing to his nakedness. Most, with far more vivid imagination than I, still clothe the rationalist emperor in golden raiment and bow down before him. Question: how many economic rationalists does it take to change a light globe? Answer: none, if the light globe needed changing market forces would already have done it. Alternatively, question: how many economic rationalists does it take to change a light globe? Answer: none; see, it's getting brighter. It's really getting brighter, isn't it? See. Don't you believe it's getting brighter?

In my first speech I also pointed to the dehumanising force of this economic rationalist model. That also has not changed. We are still headed in the wrong direction. We are still in the process of turning market economies into market societies in which every transaction, every act of social intercourse, must take place within the nexus of cash and of self-interested individualism.

The dominance of economic rationalism within government policy also guarantees that Australia has failed to turn towards ecological sustainability. We are still among the world's worst greenhouse gas polluters and the policies now being put in place will do nothing to alter that situation. As we heard today from the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), and as has been mentioned again this evening, the deliberations which concluded in the APEC agreement just signed took no account of environmental considerations. Yet by 2010 we shall certainly be in a period of climate change. Governments around the world will be taking urgent action, and the context for trade will be totally different from today.

A solar hot water service on the roof of every house in this country would meet our 20 per cent reduction target and at the same time give us a magnificent manufacturing base to make a big difference in the countries to our north. What the government has done in this very simple example is paltry and tokenistic compared with what could and should be done. Again I disagree entirely with Senator Baden Teague. It is not a matter of going back to living in caves. There is a lot of very exciting science and technology which we are not properly developing.

We continue to lose topsoil to erosion faster than natural processes can replace it. Salinisation continues to spread. Pollution of our water courses continues apace and rare and endangered species become rarer and more endangered. Yet government ignorance assumes that we will continue to increase agricultural production. Not only is scientific advice being ignored, but the scientific effort required to understand these threatening processes and methods for their reversal is also being steadily undermined, as is our basic science research effort.

The reports of the ESD working group set up under the Hawke government are gathering dust, its recommendations ignored and, in many cases, actively and deliberately impeded. The Business Council of Australia, for instance, describes greenhouse as a myth and the government acts as though the Business Council is a better source of advice than the 200 scientists who advise the intergovernmental panel on climate change.

I would like to pick up on something that Senator Harradine said. No person, no group, no political party has any understanding of or commitment to sustainability unless it or they develop a population policy. The population size is one half of the equation describing the human impact on the environment. Only the Democrats, among the Australian political parties, has a population policy; and it is built squarely on the principle of ecological sustainability.

The government has once quite specifically rejected a recommendation to develop a population policy. It has another before it, from the Barry Jones committee on long-term strategies, to which it has yet to respond. The opposition, by implication, has also rejected the development of a population policy for Australia.

I have had some minor successes, such as the $36 million for fuel ethanol which my colleague Senator Bell mentioned earlier. That is $36 million for research from the bounty in that area. This work has the potential to provide renewable fuel for transport, to give Australia a new and economically very profitable lead in this area and to save Australia an enormous import bill for petroleum, as well as very substantially reducing the pollution from oil consumption. But these successes aside, the broad picture is that Australia is still heading in the wrong direction, destroying the environment of our descendants and dissipating the natural wealth of our country in unsustainable ways.
I therefore leave to you all, and especially to my Democrat colleagues, the task of con-

SPEECH.PARA: tinuing to hold before the people of Australia an image of a different future, one in which people look more towards cooperation than competition, one in which there is greater equity for our citizens and, above all, one in which people come to see themselves as integral to the total environment, not separate from it; caring for the natural environment, recognising that it is at once our origin and our destiny and that, biologically speaking, we are a very young animal.

PARA.TAB: Most of our evolution still lies before us. Yet, if we continue to behave as we have been, we shall certainly fail to realise our evolutionary potential, truncating a yet to be fulfilled long and exciting future. While I leave the Senate—and many have referred to this tonight—I shall not give up attempting to bring about the changes to which I am committed. I shall simply continue my efforts in a different setting. To all my colleagues: goodbye.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 16 October 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Given that carbon dioxide is recognised as a major contributor to global warming, can an explanation be given as to why the 1997 Australian Design Rule 37/01 does not provide carbon dioxide vehicle emission levels.

(2) With reference to the General Motors Holden catalogue for the new Holden Commodore which advises that their new ECOTEC V6 engine `meets the tough 1997 emission standard ADR 37/01 right now' and the fact that General Motors Commodores `produce 15.1 per cent concentration of carbon dioxide during hot idle and constant speed cruise' which represents a 20 per cent higher amount of carbon dioxide than produced by a standard unmodified 6 cylinder Holden (12 per cent) manufactured by the same company: given General Motors acknowledgment that its latest designed engine is now producing 20 per cent more carbon dioxide, will the Government legislate, under ADR 37/01 to set carbon dioxide emission levels to those the company, and other manufactures could achieve 30 years ago.

(3) Given that Australian technology is currently available which has the potential to reduce carbon monoxide and unburnt hydrocarbons to zero while maintaining low nitrogen oxide levels and significantly reduce carbon dioxide to 7 per cent by volume without use of a catalytic converter or heat, what is the Government doing to promote this technology.

(4) With reference to fact that the third most common method of suicide in Australia is the connection of a hose to the exhaust of a car, and given that concern is mounting in the Australian Medical Association (AMA) and the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries in seeking a solution, such as fitting tail-pipe baffles: is the Government aware that toxic emissions can be reduced to 0.001% carbon monoxide, while increasing the free oxygen from about 1 per cent to 13 per cent by volume in the exhaust.

(5) With reference to the AMA summit held in Canberra on 13 October 1995 to examine the impact of environmental degradation on public health, was the Government represented at the summit to address motor vehicle fuel emissions or fuel efficiency.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Carbon dioxide is a product of the combustion of fossil fuels and has not been controlled as an air pollutant. The intention of Australian Design Rule 37/01 is to limit evaporative and exhaust emissions from motor vehicles in order to reduce air pollution.

The gases targeted under ADR 37/01 are known as criteria pollutants and comprise unburnt hydrocarbons, carbon monoxide and oxides of nitrogen. These gases, as well as the secondary pollutants they create, for example ground level ozone, are subject to ambient air quality guidelines promulgated by the National Health and Medical Research Council and by agencies such as the World Health Organisation.

The controls on vehicle emissions contained in ADR 37/01 are intended to ensure that ambient air standards for criteria pollutants are maintained within the standards adopted by State environment agencies. No ambient air quality standards have been established for carbon dioxide.

(2) No. The amount of carbon dioxide produced by an engine is directly related to the fuel consumption. Fuel economy of the motor vehicle fleet is being addressed through a code of practice which is currently being negotiated with industry.

(3) The Government's research and development tax concession provides a 150 percent tax deduction for expenditure by eligible companies on R&D activities, which may include those aimed at pollution reduction. The Australian R&D tax concession is among the most generous in the world.
(4) Yes.
(5) The AMA summit on environment was held in Canberra on 20 October 1995 not 13 October 1995. The Government was represented at the conference.

(2) What proposals are being considered to protect Reserve's interests on call-out by guaranteeing a return to employment.
(3) What financial compensation for employers is being considered.

Its further progress is to be reviewed by the Vice Chief of the Defence Force before the end of the year.

(2) Employment is only one of the issues under consideration to protect Reserve's interests on call out, but is one of the most important. A draft discussion paper has been passed to the Department of Industrial Relations, the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry for comment. Initial responses have been received and further development and consultation is now under way. Different models for guaranteeing a return to employment are being considered, but some form of overarching legislative provision is likely to be included.
(3) The draft discussion paper canvassed the question of financial compensation for employers to recompense costs involved in temporarily replacing and then reinstating an employee called

PARA.TAB: Discussions with relevant bodies are continuing.

(4) Consideration of other Australian and overseas (notably United Kingdom and United States of America) legislation is being conducted as part of the review and consultative process. When this is complete an announcement will be made by the Government.

(5) The issues involved are complex and wide consultation is required, therefore it is too early to suggest when the draft legislation will be available for public scrutiny. TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 October 1995 (Hansard page 2237) Senator Kernot asked me a question without notice concerning the investment strategies of superannuation funds: in particular, whether I could:

ANSWER.PARA: ". . . give the Senate any assurance that the Government will release a position on this issue before the Senate has to vote on the super co-contribution."

PARA.TAB: Mr Willis has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Government's policy position on this issue is already clear and unequivocal. The Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1994 provides, in essence, that the trustees of superannuation funds are responsible for the investment of the superannuation savings they administer, having regard to the best interests of their fund members. The Government has no intention of altering its position on this issue.

It is expected that the legislation giving effect to the 1995 Budget announcements for the introduction of employee superannuation contributions and matching Government contributions will be introduced into the Parliament in 1996-97.
